IronParameters None Help
 
 

All Parameters

Preview mode

Adjusts the toolpath display to the level of detail you require. Higher levels are more demanding on the display.

Mode

Switches between the coloring and highlighting options.

Layers

Skipping layers during toolpath preview can make the preview less crowded but may hide some details.

Animation

Switches between animating only the current layer and looping it, and animating all layers in succession.

Note: Changing the setting does not modify a currently playing animation. Only once stopped will this setting come into effect.

Toolpath width

Changes the line thickness for display.

Statistics

Shows information about the current state of displaying the toolpath.

Current layer

Shows the number of the currently displayed layer. If you have chosen to not display every layer, but skip some, this is reflected here.

Current height

Shows the absolute height of the currently displayed layer. If you have chosen to not display every layer, but skip some, this is reflected here.

Layer count

Shows the total count of layers in this build room.

Build statistics

Shows some numerical information regarding the slicing.

Support

Defines the regions that require supports.

Set the Supported Model and Support Overhang Angle parameters below.

Support

Defines the regions that require supports.

Set the Supported Model parameter below.

Support

Defines the regions that require supports.

Set the Supported Model parameter below.

Support

Defines the regions that require supports.

Set the Supported Model parameter below.

Supported Model

Defines the faces, bodies, or components that you want to be supported.

Click the individual faces of a body. A double-click selects the whole body.

Selected faces

Supported Model

Defines the faces, bodies, or components that you want to be supported.

Click the individual faces of a body. A double-click selects the whole body.

Selected faces

Supported Model

Defines the bodies or components that you want to be supported.

Supported Model

Defines the bodies or components that you want to be supported.

Supported Model

Defines the bodies or components that you want to be supported.

Supported Model

Defines the bodies or components that you want to be supported.

Support Overhang Angle

Determines the angle at which supports get generated for down-facing surfaces.

The angle is measured from the horizontal plane. Enter a value between 0 degrees and 90 degrees.

15 degrees

55 degrees

Avoid

Lets you choose faces, bodies, or components that you do not want to be supported.

Selected faces

Selected faces not supported

Avoid

Lets you choose faces, bodies, or components that you do not want to be supported.

Selected faces

Selected faces not supported

Avoid

Lets you choose bodies or components that you do not want to be supported.

Avoid

Lets you choose bodies or components that you do not want to be supported.

Avoid

Lets you choose bodies or components that you do not want to be supported.

Avoid

Lets you choose bodies or components that you do not want to be supported.

Avoided Model

Defines the faces, bodies, or components that you do not want to be supported.

Click the individual faces of a body. A double-click selects the whole body. Specifying avoided models could be used to create two different support actions on the same body. For example, the avoided model for this support can then be the supported model for a different support.

Selected faces

Selected faces not supported

Avoided Model

Defines the faces, bodies, or components that you do not want to be supported.

Click the individual faces of a body. A double-click selects the whole body. Specifying avoided models could be used to create two different support actions on the same body. For example, the avoided model for this support can then be the supported model for a different support.

Selected faces

Selected faces not supported

Avoided Model

Defines the bodies or components that you do not want to be supported.

Avoided Model

Defines the bodies or components that you do not want to be supported.

Avoided Model

Defines the bodies or components that you do not want to be supported.

Avoided Model

Defines the bodies or components that you do not want to be supported.

Support Angle

Areas of down-facing triangles angled at least this much away from the horizontal can be used to widen the cluster area beyond the critical angle, to smoothen the support contour or to merge critical areas.

Value should be between 0 and 90 degrees.

Advanced Area Filter

Defines detailed settings on how supports are applied to critical areas.

The Advanced Area Filter parameters let you fine-tune support generation.

Minimal Area

Sets the minimum size of a detected area. If the size of a detected area is below the specified value, no supports are generated.

The value should be at least 0.0 cm² and below the Maximal Area value.

Maximal Area

Sets the maximum size of a detected area. If the size of a detected area is above the specified value, no supports are generated.

The value should be at least 0.1 cm². This setting is useful if you want to generate a different type of support for large areas. For example, areas smaller than the defined Maximal Area could use bar supports, while everything larger could use volume supports.

Cluster Type

Generates different supports based on the shape of the area.

For example, convex clusters need fewer but stronger supports, while concave clusters need more but lighter supports.

Duplicate Support

Controls whether areas get supported multiple times, even when a previous support type has already been applied to that area.

By overlapping supported areas, and combining different support types, you can create reinforced support structures. For example, reinforcing volume supports with bar supports.

Cluster Inside or Outside

Specifies if supports should be generated on the inside or the outside of a body.

Areas are considered inside when they belong to a fully enclosed cavity with no connection to the outer skin.

Minimal Area Above Part (in %)

Sets the minimum percentage area for supports. If supports from an overhanging area intersect with a face below, and the percentage is less than the specified value, no supports are generated.

The value should be a percentage between 0 and 100.

Maximal Area Above Part (in %)

Sets the maximum percentage area for supports. If supports from an overhanging area intersect with a face below, and the percentage is more than the specified value, no supports are generated.

The value should be a percentage between 0 and 100.

Minimal Z Height

Sets the minimum height for supports. An overhanging face must be higher than the specified value for supports to be generated.

This is useful when you want to create different support types based on the height of the overhanging face.

Maximal Z Height

Sets the maximum height for supports. An overhanging face must be lower than the specified value for supports to be generated.

This is useful when you want to create different support types based on the height of the overhanging face.

Minimal Jut Distance

Specifies the smallest overhang for which supports are needed. If an overhang is smaller than the specified value, no supports are generated.

Example of a 5 mm overhang with different minimal jut distances:

0 mm

6 mm

Respect CAD face groups

When a cluster is found to intersect with one or more face groups, every section thus created is handled as if it were a separate cluster.

Keep Distance to Support

Enforces a distance between newly created and existing supports if their support areas overlap.

This can be helpful if you have two or more support types with overlapping support areas and want to avoid collisions between the supports.

Distance to other Support

Determines the gap between support entities.

This can be helpful if you have two or more support types with overlapping support areas and want to avoid collisions between the supports.

Structure

Determines the polyline type and the intersection between the body and the supports.

The polyline type allows you to switch between thin or thick walls of material and walls with a hole pattern for the supports. The distance settings let you define the connection strength between the body and the supports.

Polyline Type

Determines the pattern of the polyline.

The selection of different types affect stability, print time, and material consumption of the support structure.

Surface (left), Solid (center), and Structure with Hole Patterns (right)

Distance to Part

Sets the distance from the top of the support to the bottom of the part.

A positive value creates a gap between the supports and body for easier support removal. Likewise, a negative value offsets the supports so that they overlap with the body.

Wall Width

Specifies the thickness of a solid wall. Applies to solid polylines only.

Value should be between 0.1 and 10 mm.

Rounded End

Applies a radius to the ends of solid walls with thickness instead of leaving them square. Applies to solid polylines only.

Filling Type

Switches the support walls between Closed Volume and Structured.

Closed Volume uses a square column-style of support, and a solid wall encases all six sides of the columns. Structured uses a patterned style of support, for example Diamond, which you set in the Volume Properties tab.

Closed Volume

Structure

Top Distance to Part

Defines the distance between the top of the support and the bottom of the body.

A positive value creates a gap between the supports and body for easier support removal. Likewise, a negative value offsets the supports so that they overlap with the body.

0 mm

1 mm

Bottom Distance to Part

Defines the distance between the bottom of the support and the top of the body.

A positive value creates a gap between the supports and body for easier support removal. Likewise, a negative value offsets the supports so that they overlap with the body.

0 mm

1 mm

Contour Accuracy

Defines how close a support structure follows a contour. The value defines the maximum allowed distance between the contour and the support structure.

Having a low Contour Accuracy value might lead to a high amount of data, which slows down calculation times for support generation and slicing.

Lower value

Higher value

Anchor Distance

Specifies the separation between the supports on the build platform.

Large distance

Small distance

Supported Tip Shape

Determines where bar supports get generated.

Sharp adds supports at corners (vertices). Blunt by Cluster Detection adds supports in critical areas at the center of clusters. Sharp Node Outside Cluster adds supports at corners (vertices) that are not within clusters. A cluster is a continuous area identified as needing support, as defined by the Support Overhang Angle.

Sharp

Blunt by Cluster Detection

Contour Offset to Wall

Sets the distance between the wall of a body and the support's outer boundary, which is known as the contour.

0.01 mm

2 mm

Free Contour Offset

Sets the distance between the edge of a body and the support's outer boundary, which is known as the contour.

A free contour is defined as the boundary of the support structure that meets the edge of a body rather than a body's wall.

2 mm

0.01 mm

Anchor Density

Determines the compactness of the bar supports. You can choose from predefined options or specify custom values.

Sparse

Dense

Anchor Distance

Specifies the distance between two anchor points or bars.

Value should be between 0.2 and 1000 mm.

Contour Offset to Wall

Enforces a distance between a cluster contour and a wall (a concave border).

Value should be between 0.01 and 1000 mm.

Free Contour Offset

Enforces a distance between a cluster contour and the next edge (a convex border).

Value should be between 0.01 and 1000 mm.

Anchor Alignment

Switches between rectangular and hexagonal anchor placement.

Minimal Z Value

Specifies the minimum height of the top of a support from the build platform. If the top of a support is below the specified value, no support is generated.

The value should be at least zero and be less than the Maximal Z Value.

Minimal 25 mm and maximal 45 mm

Maximal Z Value

Specifies the maximum height of the top of a support from the build platform. If the top of a support is above the specified value, no support is generated.

The value should be greater than the Minimal Z Value.

Minimal 0 mm and maximal 35 mm

Lattice Support

The determined support volume is subdivided into unit cells which are then filled with lattice topology. From the scaffolding thus created, individual bars support the respective downskin clusters. If possible, and desired, whole groups of eight cells (2×2×2) are collapsed into single cells.

Cell Width

Determines the width of the smallest cell, and indirectly the angle of diagonal support bars. You should keep the ratio of width to height above a certain value so as to keep the diagonal bars printable.

Value should be larger than 0.01 mm.

Cell Height

Determines the height of the smallest cell, and indirectly the angle of diagonal support bars. You should keep the ratio of width to height above a certain value so as to keep the diagonal bars printable.

Value should be larger than 0.01 mm.

Adaptive Step Count

The rule of collapsing multiple fully intact lattice cells into the next larger cell size is applied up to this many times. Note that this is only the permissible maximum. If there aren't enough intact cells in a contiguous 2×2×2 arrangement, no collapsing is performed.

Value should be between 0 and 10.

Part Distance

This minimum distance is enforced between lattice and part surface when hugging the surface contours with the lattice scaffolding.

Value should be larger than 0.01 mm.

Around Part

If enabled, a wider volume in a pyramid-like fashion is created and filled with lattice. This fills even more volume with rigid support but consequently consumes significantly more buildspace on the platform.

Down Points

With this switch, this support action can also see to supporting downward-facing protrusions whose sides do not qualify for cluster detection such as when they are steeper than the critical and non-critical angles. This is off by default.

Grow Behavior

Controls the spread of lattice supports. You can choose to allow the supports to spread without any restrictions, to restrict the spread to near the build platform, or to prevent any spread at all.

Grow at Adaptive Step

Grow at Platform

Constant Shape

Lattice on Upskin and Sidewalls

Controls whether lattice supports are generated on upskin and sidewall surfaces.

When deselected, bar supports are generated. When selected, lattice supports are generated, and the number of connections on downskin surfaces may be reduced, which can increase surface quality.

Deselected

Selected

Tree Structure

Determines the size of the branching for bouquets. You can choose from predefined options or specify custom values.

Bouquets are where multiple bar supports join to form a tree-like structure, with a single anchor at the build platform and multiple anchors at the selected face, body, or component.

None

Medium

Diameter of Bouquet Structure

Specifies the maximum diameter of single bouquet structures. Smaller diameters cause creation of more, and smaller, bouquets.

Value should be between 0.1 and 10000 mm.

Height of Bouquet Structure

Enforces a minimum distance between the first branch of a bouquet structure and the part.

Value should be between 1.0 and 10000 mm.

Recursive Depth of Bouquet Structure

Limits the amount of branches per bar between the first branch and the part.

Value should be between 0 and 5.

Maximal Vertical Bar Gradient

Specifies the largest angle for bar supports from the vertical as they branch out. Reducing the angle lowers the point at which branching starts, which can help to make supports more stable.

Enter a value between 0 and 90 degrees.

60 degrees

40 degrees

Project Bar to Platform

Activates the option to project bars down to the build platform to avoid part-to-part support. The bar is angled to go all the way down to the build platform.

Part-to-part support causes a lower surface quality and increases post-processing times of the part.

Selected

Deselected

Maximum Projection Angle

Limits the angle of the bar projection.

The angle is measured from the vertical plane. If a bar cannot be projected to the build platform within the specified angle, the bar runs vertically down until it contacts the part.

10 degrees

30 degrees

Anchor Distance

Sets the distance between two anchor points for each polyline.

Value should be between 0.2 and 1000 mm.

Hatch Distance

Specifies the distance between the polylines.

A smaller hatch distance leads to denser, and therefore stronger, support structures. But denser support structures are harder to remove.

4 mm

2 mm

Rotate by Z

Rotates the arrangement of polylines by this value.

Value should be between 0.0 and 180 degrees.

Offset to Border

Enforces a distance between the cluster contour and the end points of the polylines.

Value should be between 0.0 and 10 mm.

Minimal Edge Length

Defines the distance between the cluster's contour and the cluster's volume supports that is required for a skeletal polyline to be created.

Value should be at least 0.01 mm.

Offset to Border

Describes the distance between an anchor point and the next edge.

Value should be between 0.01 and 10 mm.

Anchor Distance

Sets the distance between two anchor points.

Value should be between 1 and 100 mm.

Contour Offset to Wall

The anchor points along the contour can be moved further apart from the edge. The offset describes the distance from the edge to the next wall.

Value should be between 0.01 and 5 mm.

Free Contour Offset

Describes the distance between an anchor point and the next edge.

Value should be between 0.01 and 5 mm.

Contour Accuracy

Specifies maximum permissible deviation when following a contour

Value should be between 0.01 and 0.5 mm.

Existing Support

Determines whether polylines are added around existing support structures.

Around

Ignore

Bar Size

Determines the thickness of the bar supports. You can choose from predefined options or specify custom values.

Small

Large

Bar Size

Determines the thickness of the bar supports. You can choose from a predefined default or specify custom values.

Default

Custom example

Width on Part

Sets the contour width for bar ends that terminate on a part surface.

Value should be between 0.1 and 10 mm.

Width on Platform

Sets the contour width for bar ends that terminate on the build platform surface.

Value should be between 0.1 and 10 mm.

Right Angle on Part

Determines whether bars have a small curve that terminates in a right angle at the supported surface.

No

Yes

Distance to Right Angle

Sets the distance away from the supported surface after which the bar should start to bend towards the other end.

Value should be between 0.1 and 20 mm.

Smoothing Distance

Sets the length of subdivisions that form the curve. The shorter the section, the finer the curve is resolved, resulting in a smoother transition but also increased triangle count.

Value should be between 0.5 and 100 mm.

Distance to Part

Sets the distance between part and support. A negative value will make supports intrude into the part mesh. When you also choose a custom bar contour, you can use this in conjunction with Angle at top to achieve a calculated contact patch, for instance. To calculate the appropriate value, use this simple trigonometry formula:

Distance to part (negative) = (desired spot diameter - Width on end) * (Breaking point width - Width on end) / Height on end

Value should be between -3 and 3 mm.

Bar Contour

Determines the cross-sectional shape of the bar supports. You can choose from predefined options or specify custom values.

Solid Bar

Solid Cross

Note: A Single Hatch Tube is the same shape as a Solid Bar, but the way the Single Hatch Tube is sliced during export is different. This is to support certain additive machines that otherwise fill the contour of the support with multiple hatches, increasing build time.

Bar Contour

Determines the cross-sectional shape of the bar supports. You can choose from a predefined default or specify custom values.

Solid Bar

Custom Solid Bar example

Polygon Corner Count

Determines the number of corners for the solid bar. The more corners, the more rounded the bar's cross section becomes, but also the more triangles this generates. Applies to Solid Bar only.

Value should be between 3 and 30.

Angle at Top

When set beyond 0, a pointy end is added to the normally blunt end that terminates evenly in the part surface.

Note: This point intrudes into the part mesh, so you may want to also work with Distance to part to reduce or avoid unwanted duplication of toolpath at the intersection.

Value should be between 0.0 and 60 degrees.

Cross Width

Sets the thickness of the contours for the solid cross.

Radial Type

Used to create solid bars with oval cross-sections. It aligns the oval cross section by the semi-major axis with either X or Y axis, or radially away from the supported object's outbox's center.

Radial Factor in %

Used to create solid bars with oval cross-sections. Makes the semi-major axis as long as the semi-minor axis times this factor.

Value should be between 100 and 200.

Use Breakpoint

Choose from presets, or specify custom values.

No

On Part

Offsetted to Part

Breaking Point Width

Sets the diameter of the bar at the breaking point.

Value should be between 0.01 and 10 mm.

Width on End

Sets the diameter of the bar past the breaking point where it attaches to the part surface.

Value should be between 0.01 and 10 mm.

Breaking Point Height

Sets the length of the breaking point itself.

Value should be between 0.01 and 10 mm.

Height on Start

Sets the length over which the bar should narrow towards the breaking point, as seen from the bar towards the part

Value should be between 0.01 and 20 mm.

Height on End

Sets the length over which the bar should narrow towards the breaking point, as seen from the part towards the bar.

Value should be between 0.01 and 20 mm.

Pad on Platform

Adds a wider section of bar where the bar meets the build platform.

The wider section improves bar connection to the build platform as well as bar sturdiness. For a pad to be generated, the Pad Height must be less than 40% of the total height of the supports. For example, if the total height of the supports is 50 mm, the height of the pads must be less than 20 mm.

Supports with pads (left) and without pads (right)

Pad Width

Sets the width of the pad of the bar support.

A wider pad provides a better base for the bar, improving the connection to the build platform. A narrower pad makes the bars less sturdy, but easier to remove and saves material.

Supports with narrow pads (left) and wider pads (right)

Pad Height

Sets the height of the pad of the bar support.

A higher pad height makes the bars sturdier. A smaller pad height means the bars are less sturdy, but easier to remove and saves material.

Supports with shorter pads (left) and taller pads (right)

Taper Angle

Specifies the angle of the taper from the pad to the bar support.

The angle is measured from the horizontal. Enter a value between -60 degrees and 60 degrees. Depending on the type of additive machine selected in the setup, you might want a negative or a positive taper. For example, for SLM (selective laser melting), a negative taper can mean that the supports are easier to remove from the build platform when using a tool, such as a scraper.

Negative taper (left), no taper (center), and positive taper (right).

Structure

Determines the filling type and the intersection between body and supports.

The filling type allows you to switch between a hollow structure, which creates a solid block of material, and structured, which creates open supports that work better for different processes. With the distance settings you can define the connection strength between body and supports.

Structure

Determines the intersection between body and supports.

With the distance settings you can define the connection strength between body and supports.

Structure

Determines the type of support structures and the perforation of the support structures.

Hole Pattern

Determines the type of the support structure.

The selection of different types affect stability, print time, and material consumption of the support structure.

Diamond (left), Oval (center), and None (right).

Density

Controls the perforation of a support structure. A higher density setting leads to smaller and fewer holes in the structure.

One structure is a template that generates the support structure through repetition. For a higher density, more structures are created for the same distance compared to a lower density setting.

Sparse

Dense

Width

Specifies the width of the hole shapes.

Value should be between 0.2 and 10 mm.

Height

Specifies the height of the hole shapes.

Value should be between 0.2 and 10 mm.

Interval Width

Specifies the distance between neighboring holes to the sides.

Value should be between 0.01 and 10 mm.

Interval Height

Specifies the distance between neighboring holes above and below.

Value should be between 0.01 and 10 mm.

Maximum Height

Limits the length of support structures, measured from the downskin they originate on. If necessary, supports terminate in mid-air, not reaching the build platform.

Value should be between 0.0 and 10000 mm.

Solid Structure for Height

Configures structured polyline supports to have solid sections to improve strength for supports spanning greater Z distances.

Value should be between 0.0 and 1000000 mm.

Thickening Up Structures

Extrudes the support structure by a defined value, adding thickness to it and generating a volume.

Thickening up a support structure increases its strength. But it also increases build time, material usage, and especially the size of the build file because more triangles are needed to generate the structure.

Deselected

Selected

Main Structure

Applies a thickness to the entire support structure.

Thickening up a support structure increases its strength. But it also increases build time, material usage, and especially the size of the build file because more triangles are needed to generate the structure.

Top Connections

Applies a different thickness to the top connections of a support structure compared to the main structure.

Top Connections refers to the interface between a support structure and a body above it. There are different connection types, which can be set in the Connections tab. A larger thickness makes for a stronger connection to the part, but in turn makes it harder to remove the support structure.

Bottom Connections

Applies a different thickness to the bottom connections of a support structure compared to the main structure.

Bottom Connections refers to the interface between a support structure and a body below it. There are different connection types, which can be set in the Connections tab. A larger thickness makes for a stronger connection to the part, but in turn makes it harder to remove the support structure.

Fin Structures

A fin is a vertical strip added at a right angle to a polyline or polyline fragment as a backbone. A closed polyline, like a non-fragmented contour polyline, does not get a fin.

Fins add strength to individual polylines

Width

Sets the width of fins.

Value should be between 0.1 and 20 mm.

Keep Distance to Support

Sets a distance between support and fin, if desired.

Value should be between 0.0 and 20 mm.

Top Distance to Part

Sets the distance that the fin will keep to the support's top end.

Value should be between 0.0 and 20 mm.

Bottom Distance to Part

Sets the distance that the fin will keep to the support's bottom end.

Value should be between 0.0 and 20 mm.

Raster

Specifies the settings that make up the raster of a volume support structure.

The raster is made of single polylines that are aligned in a grid to support the downskin of a part.

Rotate by Z

Specifies the rotation angle for the support raster. The value should be between 0 and 90 degrees.

Rotating the support raster is necessary to minimize the contact between the support and the recoater blade for some additive processes. Having the support raster oriented parallel to the recoater blade can lead to build or machine damage and should be avoided by rotating the raster at a slight angle.

Rotated by 5 degrees (left) and 30 degrees (right)

Hatch Distance

Defines the distance between the raster's grid lines. This affects the number of created lines and the density.

A smaller hatch distance leads to denser, and therefore stronger, support structures. Keep in mind that denser support structures are harder to remove. Hatch Distance is not available when the Filling Type is Hollow.

Hatch distance of 2.5 mm (left) and 5 mm (right)

Filling Strategy

Defines in which directions the raster is generated. Hatches in X and Y creates a grid, while Hatches Just in Y creates lines in Y.

Creating lines in X can be created by using Hatches Just in Y and setting Rotate by Z to 90 degrees. Filling Strategy is not available when the Filling Type is Hollow.

Hatches in X and Y (left), Hatches Just in Y (center), and Without Filling (right)

Contour

Defines the contours that are placed around the edges of a cluster that needs supports.

Contour Count

Defines how many contours are created around the supported surface.

Contour count of 1 (left) and 2 (right)

Contour Distance

Defines the gap between the contours. The value should be between 0 and 30 mm.

Contour distance of 2 mm (left) and 4 mm (right)

Smoothing Distance

Adjusts the resolution of the supporting structure's contour below the body's face.

For a body with a detailed supported face, a lower smoothing distance means a higher sampling and therefore a more accurate representation of the face. This creates a support structure contour that more closely follows the supported face, creating a better support-to-body connection. However, smaller values can cause longer calculation times and higher memory usage. The value must be between 0.1 mm and 10 mm.

Small value

Large value

Fragment Size and Gap

Fragmenting the polylines makes breaking off supports easier after printing.

Fragment Size

Choose from presets, or define custom values for fragment sizes.

Small fragments

Large fragments

Fragment Contour Length

Sets the fragment size in X and Y direction. Modifying this will reset the individual values for X and Y to this value.

Value should be between 1.0 and 200 mm.

Raster Fragment Size X

Set a custom fragment size in X direction.

Value should be between 1.0 and 100 mm.

Raster Fragment Size Y

Sets a custom fragment size in Y direction.

Value should be between 1.0 and 100 mm.

Raster Offset in X

Set a distance in X by which to displace the rastering against the filling.

Value should be between 0.0 and 10 mm.

Raster Offset in Y

Sets a distance in Y by which to displace the rastering against the filling.

Value should be between 1.0 and 10 mm.

Fragment Gap

Choose from presets, or define custom values for the gaps between fragments.

Small gap
0.4 mm

Large gap
1.5 mm

Fragment Contour Gap

Sets the gap width between two envelope polyline fragments.

Value should be between 0.05 and 100 mm.

Raster Fragment Gap

Set the gap width between volume-filling fragments.

Value should be between 0.01 and 100 mm.

Support Connection

Choose from presets, or configure the connection parameters numerically.

Connection type presets
From left: Breaking points, offset breaking points, strip

Angled Support

Controls whether the supports between the selected faces, bodies, or components and the build platform are angled. When selected, the supports are angled towards a reference point, which is based on the origin of the model. When deselected, the supports extend vertically down.

Angling helps avoid generating supports that connect downskin regions with upskin regions. Supports are then easier to remove after the build process is complete and helps with the surface quality of parts. To adjust the position of the reference point, use the manipulator in the canvas or enter values directly in this dialog.

Deselected

Selected

X Distance

Sets the X offset of the reference point, which the supports are angled towards.

Click and drag the arrow on the manipulator in the canvas or enter a value directly in this dialog.

Y Distance

Sets the Y offset of the reference point, which the supports are angled towards.

Click and drag the arrow on the manipulator in the canvas or enter a value directly in this dialog.

Z Distance

Sets the Z offset of the reference point, which the supports are angled towards.

Click and drag the arrow on the manipulator in the canvas or enter a value directly in this dialog.

Tilt Below Angle

Controls whether the supports below the reference point are angled. When selected, the supports are angled according to specified Tilt and Direction angles. When deselected, the supports extend vertically down.

To adjust the Tilt and Direction angles, use the manipulator in the canvas or enter values directly in this dialog.

Tilt

Rotates the supports below the reference point around the X axis.

Click and drag the circular arc on the manipulator in the canvas or enter a value directly in this dialog.

Tilt of 0 degrees (left) and Tilt of 45 degrees (right).

Direction

Rotates the supports below the reference point around the Z axis.

Click and drag the circular arc on the manipulator in the canvas or enter a value directly in this dialog.

Tilt of -45 degrees and Direction of 0 degrees (left) and Tilt of 45 degrees and Direction of 45 degrees (right).

Triangular Fin on Platform

Adds a triangular fin at the base of the support to increase stability.

Selected

Deselected

Fin Spacing

Specifies the spacing between triangular fins at the base of the support.

5 mm

8 mm

Fin Base

Specifies the width of the triangular fins at the base of the support.

3 mm

6 mm

Shape

Type of connection.

  • Strip: A continuous band connecting to the part all along its upper edge
  • Trapoid: Triangles with truncated tips
  • Breaking points: Like trapoid, but with another, inverted row of trapoids stacked on top, forming X-shaped connections
  • Triangles: Triangles that simply terminate in pointy tips, for very delicate support attachment

Connection types
From left: Trapoids, breaking points, strip. The fourth type, triangles, is not shown as it is essentially trapoids without the truncation.

Connection Width

  • Does not apply to Strip.
  • For Triangles, this only applies to the vertical line at the beginning for the polyline, or contour.
  • For Breaking Points, this is the "waist" of the X-shaped connections.

Value should be between 0 and 4 mm.

Connection parameters
a marks the connection width.

Connection Height

 

Value should be between 0.3 and 6 mm.

Connection parameters
b marks the connection height.

Pin Distance

 

Value should be between 0 and 2 mm.

Connection parameters
c marks the pin distance.

Distance Connection to Structure

 

Value should be between 0.2 and 3 mm.

Connection parameters
e marks the distance connection-to-structure.

Pins per Structure

 

Value should be between 1 and 10.

Connection parameters
d marks the pins per structure.

Support Connection

Choose from presets, or configure the connection parameters numerically.

Connection type presets
From left: Breaking points, offset breaking points, strip

Connection

Type of connection. Select from: Strip, Trapoid, Breaking Points, Triangles.

  • Strip: A continuous band connecting to the part all along its upper edge
  • Trapoid: Triangles with truncated tips
  • Breaking points: Like trapoid, but with another, inverted row of trapoids stacked on top, forming X-shaped connections
  • Triangles: Triangles that simply terminate in pointy tips, for very delicate support attachment

Connection Width

  • Does not apply to Strip.
  • For Triangles, this only applies to the vertical line at the beginning for the polyline, or contour.
  • For Breaking Points, this is the "waist" of the X-shaped connections.

Value should be between 0 and 4 mm.

Connection parameters
a marks the connection width.

Connection Height

 

Value should be between 0.0 and 6 mm.

Connection parameters
b marks the connection height.

Pin Distance

 

Value should be between 0 and 2 mm.

Connection parameters
c marks the pin distance.

Distance Connection to Structure

 

Value should be between 0.2 and 3 mm.

Connection parameters
e marks the distance connection-to-structure.

Pins per Structure

 

Value should be between 1 and 10.

Connection parameters
d marks the pins per structure.

Support Connection

Choose from presets, or configure the connection parameters numerically.

Connection type presets
From left: Breaking points, offset breaking points, strip

Connection

Type of connection. Select from: Strip, Trapoid, Breaking Points, Triangles.

  • Strip: A continuous band connecting to the part all along its upper edge
  • Trapoid: Triangles with truncated tips
  • Breaking points: Like trapoid, but with another, inverted row of trapoids stacked on top, forming X-shaped connections
  • Triangles: Triangles that simply terminate in pointy tips, for very delicate support attachment

Connection Width

  • Does not apply to Strip.
  • For Triangles, this only applies to the vertical line at the beginning for the polyline, or contour.
  • For Breaking Points, this is the "waist" of the X-shaped connections.

Value should be between 0 and 4 mm.

Connection parameters
a marks the connection width.

Connection Height

 

Value should be between 0.3 and 6 mm.

Connection parameters
b marks the connection height.

Pin Distance

 

Value should be between 0 and 2 mm.

Connection parameters
c marks the pin distance.

Distance Connection to Structure

 

Value should be between 0.2 and 3 mm.

Connection parameters
e marks the distance connection-to-structure.

Hatches

Replicates the lower section of connections in parallel, up to 15 copies in each direction. This creates tapered, pedestal-like reinforcements. Accepts odd numbers up to 31 only, ignores even numbers.

Value should be between 1 and 31.

Additional hatches can strengthen the connection with the build platform

Hatches Distance

Sets the distance between replicated hatches.

Value should be between 0.02 and 1 mm.

Additional hatches can strengthen the connection with the build platform

Target Component

Specifies the component on which you want to perform the Automatic Orientation study.

If the active setup contains only one component, that component is automatically selected.

Support Overhang Angle

Determines the angle at which supports are assumed will get generated for down-facing surfaces.

If supports are needed, they are considered when generating the orientation results. The angle is measured from the horizontal plane. Enter a value between 0 degrees and 90 degrees.

15 degrees

55 degrees

Support Bottom Surface

A flat surface in direct contact with the build platform would normally not require support and would therefore be ignored for area calculation. Use this switch to enforce including such surfaces in the calculation of the support area anyway.

Distance to Platform (Z)

Enforce a distance above the build platform that must be maintained for a component in any of its suggested orientations.

Smallest Rotation

Viable orientations might be found, rotationally, in close proximity. Use this setting to reduce the number of results to the most relevant ones: If multiple viable orientations are found up to this rotational angle apart, the best one is selected and the other ones discarded. Smaller values significantly increase the calculation time and the amount of results presented.

Value should be between 5 and 180 degrees.

Rotation Axis

Optionally, restrict rotation around the X or the Y axis when looking for orientations.

Fit in tray

Some orientations of a part may make it come close to the buildspace borders, even exceed them. Use this option to discard any such results.

Distance to Tray (XY)

Some orientations of a part may make it come close to the buildspace borders, even exceed them. Specify a padding to the physical buildspace borders here.

Value should be between 0 and 40 mm

Limit Build Height

Some orientations of a part may make it come close to the buildspace height, even exceed it. Use this option to discard any such results.

Limit

Some orientations of a part may make it come close to the buildspace height, even exceed it. Specify a padding to the physical buildspace height here.

Value should be between 0 and 200 mm.

Support Volume

Determines the importance of having a small support volume.

Support Area

Determines the importance of having a small support area. Note that the area is also affected significantly when having components are lying flat on the platform as you can enforce including the area of the surface in contact with the platform in the calculation even when it wouldn't actually get supports generated on it.

Bounding Box Volume

Determines the importance of having a small bounding box volume. The bounding box is always calculated parallel to the cardinal axes; so, this value can vary with the component's rotation around the Z axis even when the component's actual size remains unchanged.

Part Height

Determines the importance of having the component's height be as small as possible.

Center of Gravity Height

Determines the importance of having the component’s center of gravity be as low as possible to the build platform.

Original orientation

Orientation that reduces the height of the center of gravity

Hatch Angle

Determines the direction of hatch-type and cross-type bar support. A direction of 0° aligns the ribbon-like (or cross-like, respectively) bars parallel to the Y axis, and higher values rotate this direction clockwise.

Value should be between 0 and 360 degrees.

Bars on Cluster Geometry

Determines where bar supports get generated around clusters of the selected face, bodies, or components.

A cluster is a continuous area identified as needing support, as defined by the Support Overhang Angle.

Down Oriented Points

Controls whether bar supports get generated at downward-facing points of clusters, which are continuous areas identified as needing support.

Deselected

Selected

Corner

Controls whether bar supports get generated at corner of clusters, which are continuous areas identified as needing support.

Deselected

Selected

Medial Axis

Controls whether bar supports get generated along the medial axis of clusters, which are continuous areas identified as needing support.

The extent of the supports at the medial axis is defined by the Medial Axis Contour Offset to the border of the clusters.

Deselected

Selected

Medial Axis Contour Offset

Specifies the distance between supports and the border of the clusters. Increasing the value helps prevent supports generating too close to borders.

5 mm offset

10 mm offset

Borders

Controls whether bar supports get generated at border of clusters, which are continuous areas identified as needing support.

Deselected

Selected

Bars on Global Features

Controls whether bar supports get generated in regions that might otherwise get missed because of the orientation of the body.

Down Oriented Points

Controls whether bar supports get generated at downward-facing points.

Sharp Edges

Controls whether bar supports get generated at downward-facing sharp edges.

Maximum Edge Angle

Specifies the angle of edges below which supports get added. The angle is measured from the horizontal.

Enter a value between 0 degrees and 90 degrees.

25 degrees

40 degrees

Groups

Controls whether bar supports are grouped, so they can be tapered, include base plate supports, and include braces. When selected, bar supports are grouped. When deselected, bar supports are not grouped.

Base plate supports can help improve adhesion to, and reduce wear of, the build platform. While braces can help prevent bar supports from buckling during the build process.

Selected

Deselected

Bars per Group

Sets the maximum number of bar supports for each group.

4 bars per group

6 bars per group

Group Taper

Sets how close a group of bar support taper toward the center of the group. Tapering can help make the bar supports easier to remove after the build process is complete.

0% means that the bar supports are not tapered. 100% means that the bar supports are tapered fully and merge at the center of the group.

50% taper

100% taper

Baseplate for Groups

Controls whether the bar supports include base plate supports at the build platform. When selected, base plate supports are added. When deselected, base plate supports are not added.

Base plate supports enables a strong connection between the build platform and the bar supports. Base plate supports can also help improve adhesion to, and reduce wear of, the build platform.

Selected

Deselected

Height

Sets the thickness of the base plate supports on the build platform.

2 mm thickness

4 mm thickness

Contour Offset

Sets the distance between the contour of a group of bar supports and the outer limit of the group's base plate supports. A bigger offset ensures that the bar supports better connect to the build platform.

0.1 mm offset

1 mm offset

Taper Angle

Sets the angle of the taper from the bottom to the top of the base plate supports. Tapering can help make the base plate supports easier to remove after the build process is complete.

The angle is measured from the horizontal. Enter a value between -60 degrees and 60 degrees.

Positive taper

Negative taper

Brace

Controls whether braces are added to the bar supports. When selected, braces are added. When deselected, braces are not added.

Braces can help prevent bar supports from buckling during the build process.

Selected

Deselected

Type

Determines the pattern of the braces between bar supports. The patterns are described by the shapes of the letters K, X, and N.

Brace types that have lots of connections, such as X-shaped braces, make a stronger support structure but need more material and time to build.

K-shaped braces

X-shaped braces

N-shaped braces

Links per Bar

Sets the approximate number of other bar supports that one bar support is connected to using braces.

A bar support can connect to other bar supports only within the same group and the braces cannot intersect.

A bar connects to 1 other bar

A bar connect to 2 other bars

Link Angle

Sets the maximum angle of the braces between the bar supports.

The angle is measured from the horizontal. Enter an angle between 30 degrees and 80 degrees.

35 degrees

65 degrees

Junction Shape

Determines whether the braces are straight or curved as they join the bar supports.

Straight braces have the best physical properties because they can better transfer force. Curved braces avoid hard edges at junctions, which might be useful in some workflows.

Straight

Curved

Offset

Determines the distance between the bodies or components and the outer limit of the support structure.

3 mm offset

6 mm offset

Height

Determines the thickness of the base plate.

Value should be between -500 mm and 500 mm.

Maximum Height

Specifies the thickness of the support structure.

2.5 mm offset

4 mm offset

Taper Angle

Specifies the angle of the taper from the bottom to the top of the support.

The angle is measured from the horizontal. Enter a value between -60 degrees and 60 degrees.

0 degrees

60 degrees

Fill Inner Contour

Controls whether support structures are generated below inner contours, such as holes.

Yes

No

Fill Pattern

Determines the structure type of the support and, if a non-solid structure is chosen, the dimensions for the rectangular or hexagonal holes.

Pattern Type

Determines whether the support structure is solid or uses a patterned design based on rectangles, hexagons, circles, or columns. For example:

Rectangular

Hexagonal

Circular

Column

Cell Size

Specifies the length and width of the shapes in a non-solid patterned support structure.

5 mm

8 mm

Wall Thickness

Specifies the distance between the shapes in a non-solid patterned support structure.

3 mm

5 mm

Vendor

This is who manufactured or distributed this machine.

Description

Introduction and useful notes on this machine.

Model

Name of this machine. By default, this is the model name.

Image

The thumbnail image of this machine. Accepts PNG images.

Default print setting

This print setting is selected by default whenever you load this machine into your setup.

Platform origin X

Platform origins, bed offsets, and similar concepts are used to tell Fusion 360 what position the target machine considers as zero along the three cardinal axes. Usually, machines take zero as the central (X, Y), bottom-most (Z) point, but some machines may count from the farthest left corner, for example. In such cases, use these fields to move the zero point from the default center-bottom position.

Platform origin Y

Platform origins, bed offsets, and similar concepts are used to tell Fusion 360 what position the target machine considers as zero along the three cardinal axes. Usually, machines take zero as the central (X, Y), bottom-most (Z) point, but some machines may count from the farthest left corner, for example. In such cases, use these fields to move the zero point from the default center-bottom position.

Platform origin Z

Platform origins, bed offsets, and similar concepts are used to tell Fusion 360 what position the target machine considers as zero along the three cardinal axes. Usually, machines take zero as the central (X, Y), bottom-most (Z) point, but some machines may count from the farthest left corner, for example. In such cases, use these fields to move the zero point from the default center-bottom position.

Platform clearance

This distance between platform surface and lowest point of the part is enforced when Automatic Arrangement is active.

Platform scaling

The mesh loaded as a platform visualization is scaled to match the build room dimensions.

Platform positioning

The mesh loaded as a platform visualization is automatically moved to be flush with bottom surface of the build room.

Platform mesh

This 3D model is used to visualize the platform of this machine in Fusion 360.

Laser count

This is how many lasers the machine has currently available, regardless how many you end up using for your manufacturing runs.

Max extruders

This is how many extruders the machine has currently available, regardless how many you end up using for your manufacturing runs.

Max extruders must be greater than 0.

Bed temp max

If supported, you can limit the bed temperature through code rather than leaving the setting to the machine.

Home position X

This position is typically used as the starting point for the homing process, the automatic detection of actual available space along X, Y, and Z. This is an absolute parameter, ignoring any bed offsets. This parameter may be ignored by the post you choose to use with this machine.

Home position Y

This position is typically used as the starting point for the homing process, the automatic detection of actual available space along X, Y, and Z. This is an absolute parameter, ignoring any bed offsets. This parameter may be ignored by the post you choose to use with this machine.

Home position Z

This position is typically used as the starting point for the homing process, the automatic detection of actual available space along X, Y, and Z. This is an absolute parameter, ignoring any bed offsets. This parameter may be ignored by the post you choose to use with this machine.

Park position X

At the end of print, the print head moves to this position only when part Z < park position Z < bed size Z. This parameter may be ignored by the post you choose to use with this machine.

Park position Y

At the end of print, the print head moves to this position only when part Z < park position Z < bed size Z. This parameter may be ignored by the post you choose to use with this machine.

Park position Z

At the end of print, the print head moves to this position only when part Z < park position Z < bed size Z. This parameter may be ignored by the post you choose to use with this machine.

Extruder offset x (mm)

If your print head's nozzle is at a different position than the default one, you can compensate for this here.

Extruder offset y (mm)

If your print head's nozzle is at a different position than the default one, you can compensate for this here.

Extruder offset z (mm)

If your print head's nozzle is at a different position than the default one, you can compensate for this here.

Diameter (mm)

This is the nozzle's extrusion diameter. It determines the track width that the toolpath calculation uses. This is not the filament diameter which is set in the Print Settings. Hint: To compensate over- or underextrusion, use Extrusion Width Multiplier, also in the Print settings.

Maximum temperature (°C)

This is the temperature that the nozzle is allowed to reach at most.

Maximum volume per sec (mm³s)

Specify here the maximum volume of material that the extruder is allowed to melt and extrude per second.

Maximum extruder speed (mm/s)

This limits the speed of the print head while material is being extruded.

Maximum x/y speed (mm/s)

This limits the speed of the print head in X and Y during times the extruder is not extruding.

Maximum z speed (mm/s)

This limits the speed of the print head in Z during times the extruder is not extruding.

Fan enabled

Enables a cooling fan for this extruder to be used.

If your print head's nozzle is at a different position than the default one, you can compensate for this here.

Extruder offset y (mm)

If your print head's nozzle is at a different position than the default one, you can compensate for this here.

Extruder offset z (mm)

This is the nozzle's extrusion diameter. It determines the track width that the toolpath calculation uses. This is not the filament diameter which is set in the Print Settings. Hint: To compensate over- or underextrusion, use Extrusion Width Multiplier, also in the Print settings.

This is the nozzle's extrusion diameter. It determines the track width that the toolpath calculation uses. This is not the filament diameter which is set in the Print Settings. Hint: To compensate over- or underextrusion, use Extrusion Width Multiplier, also in the Print settings.

Laser name

Name of this laser. Leave on default, or rename as needed to recognize them by their respective areas, for example.

Laser operating area (min x)

Specifies the ranges along X and Y that are accessible by this laser.

Laser operating area (max x)

Specifies the ranges along X and Y that are accessible by this laser.

Specifies the ranges along X and Y that are accessible by this laser.

Specifies the ranges along X and Y that are accessible by this laser.

Name of this laser. Leave on default, or rename as needed to recognize them by their respective areas, for example.
