General

Determines generic support settings relating to chosen support types.

Maximum Angle to XY-Plane

Specifies the angle of edges below which supports get added. The angle is measured from the horizontal.

Enter a value between 0 degrees and 90 degrees.

20 degrees

35 degrees

Bar Distance

Specifies the maximum distance between individual bar supports. Reduce the distance to generate a denser support structure.

3 mm

6 mm

Minimal Z Value

Sets the minimum height for supports. An edge must be higher than the specified value for supports to be generated.

Maximal Z Value

Sets the maximum height for supports. An edge must be lower than the specified value for supports to be generated.

Minimum Edge Length

Sets the smallest length an edge can be for supports to be generated.

Any edge less than the specified value is ignored for support generation. This value should be at least 0.01 mm. The example here shows how a punched-plate polyline has been generated around the volume support for the two larger bodies, but not for the smaller one.

Maximum Edge Length

Sets the largest length an edge can be for supports to be generated.

Any edge larger than the specified value is ignored for support generation. The example here shows how a punched-plate polyline has been generated around the volume support for the two smaller bodies, but not for the larger one.

Border Type

Allows you to specify at what border types the polyline support is generated.

When set to Free Border, the polyline is generated at borders that do not meet a wall. When set to Border to Wall, the polyline is generated at borders that meet a wall. When set to All, the polyline is generated at all borders.

Free Border

Border to Wall

Contour Type

Allows you to specify which contour of the polyline is to be generated.

When set to Inner Contour, only the inner contour of a part is generated. When set to Outer Contour, only the outer contour is generated.

Inner Contour

Outer Contour

Include Support Structures

Includes the support structures in the 3MF file.

The support structures and the part are saved as separate bodies in the 3MF file. Supports can be generated directly in Fusion 360 or another software. Deselect the checkbox if you want to generate supports in another software.

Include Support Structures

Includes information about the selected machine in the 3MF file.

When importing the file into other software for further build preparation, the software uses this extra information to display the machine.

Include Process Simulation Data

Lets you choose extra information to include in the 3MF file for process simulation.

Auto-Repair Support Bodies

Prepares the substitute mesh of the support structures in the 3MF file for process simulation.

The 3MF file contains two support meshes for each body. The first is the real support mesh as seen in the software, and the second is a substitute support mesh for process simulation only. If exporting the 3MF file fails, this might be because of the complexity of the substitute mesh. If this happens, deselect the checkbox, but be aware that you run the risk of the process simulation failing.

Split Supports with Individual Density

Applies a different volume fraction to different support structures in the 3MF file for process simulation.

The 3MF file contains two support meshes for each body. The first is the real support mesh as seen in the software, and the second is a substitute support mesh for process simulation only. Deselect the checkbox to apply a uniform volume fraction for all substitute meshes. For example, when you are using the same style of support structures or the same style with slightly different settings.

Keep Thickening Structures

Allows you to include the thickening applied to support structures in the 3MF file for process simulation.

This applies only to support structures that are generated with Thickening Up Structures selected. Deselecting the checkbox means that a pre-thickened substitute support mesh is used for the process simulation.

Include Support Structures

Includes the support structures in the Form file.

Supports can be generated directly in Fusion 360 or in the SLA machine's build preparation software. Deselect the checkbox if you want to generate supports in the other software.

Exporter

Specifies what format you want the build file to be. The exporter options depend on the machine selected in the active setup.

Gap

Specifies the distance between the bodies or components and the support structure.

0.1 mm

2 mm

Tolerance

Specifies the acceptable range of the deviation in the gap between the bodies or components and the support structure.

For example, a 2 mm gap with a tolerance of 0.5 mm means the gap can vary between 1.5 mm and 2.5 mm.

Tight tolerance

Loose tolerance

Note: A smaller, tighter tolerance takes longer to calculate.

Z Overlap

Specifies whether the support structure is or is not generated above the component.

Remove

Keep

Bounding Shape

Specifies the shape of the support structure in the XY plane. Silhouette follows the outline of the bodies or components. Rectangle creates a simple rectangle around the bodies or components.

Silhouette

Rectangle

Components

Specifies the components that you want to arrange in the additive machine's build volume.

Arrangement Type

Determines how the selected components are arranged in the additive machine’s build volume.

If the setup is using an additive machine with FFF, SLA, or MPBF capabilities, you can arrange only in 2D, that is, on the build platform. If the setup is using an additive machine with MJF, SLS, or binder jetting capabilities, you can arrange in 2D or 3D.

Arrange in 2D

Arrange in 3D

Note: For a component to fit inside the build volume, it must have at least 1 mm free space in its X, Y, and Z directions.

Platform Clearance

Specifies the distance between the bottom of the components and the additive machine's build platform.

Frame Width

Specifies the distance between the boundary of the arrangement and the edge of the build volume.

Smaller frame width

Larger frame width

Note: The Frame Width must be the same as, or larger than, the Voxel Size. To ensure a better arrangement calculation, enter a value that is a multiple of the Voxel Size.

Ceiling Clearance

Specifies the distance between the top of the components and top of the additive machine's build volume.

Note: The Ceiling Clearance must be the same as, or larger than, the Voxel Size. To ensure a better arrangement calculation, enter a value that is a multiple of the Voxel Size.

Object Spacing

Specifies the minimum distance between components in an arrangement.

Smaller spacing

Larger spacing

Note: The Object Spacing must be the same as, or larger than, the Voxel Size. To ensure a better arrangement calculation, enter a value that is a multiple of the Voxel Size.

Voxel Size

Specifies the edge length for the voxels, or elements, which are used to represent the components when calculating the arrangement.

The smaller the voxel size, the more accurately the shape of each component is represented, giving an arrangement that makes better use of the available space.

Note: Using a smaller voxel size can take longer to calculate the arrangement.

Select Same Diameter

Check this to automatically select all holes with the same diameter as the hole currently selected in the selection box.

Example: To drill a single 6mm / 1/4" hole and all 12mm / 1/2" holes, first select the 6mm / 1/4" hole, then select one of the 12mm / 1/2" holes, and then check the Select same diameter option.

Using this option is associative to the model, so if additional holes with the same diameter are added later, regenerating the operation automatically includes the added holes in the drilling cycle.

Dwelling Period

Dwelling time in seconds.

Specifying a dwell time halts all axis movement for a specified time while the spindle continues revolving at the specified rpm. This can be used to ensure that chips are cleared before retracting from a hole, and will typically improve the finish of a hole.

Typically a dwelling time between 1/4 second and 1 second is sufficient.

Example: To dwell for 1/4 second, specify 0.25 or 1/4 in this field.

When post processing a drill cycle, the dwell time is specified as one of the drill cycle parameters (typically P), and in most cases it is output in milliseconds (ms).

250ms dwell time in G82

When posting using expanded cycles, the dwell time is output as a regular dwell command (G4).

To calculate the minimum dwell time that will ensure at least one complete revolution, use a value of 60 divided by the spindle speed.

Example: At 350 RPM the minimum dwell time should be 60 / 350 = 0.171s which could be rounded to 0.2s.

Note: If the operator is running the program with a speed override, then the spindle speed is slower, but the dwell time is constant. To ensure one complete revolution when using a speed override of eg. 50%, the dwell time must be doubled.

Finishing Overlap

The finishing overlap is the distance that the tool passes beyond the entry point before leading out.

Specifying a Finishing Overlap ensures that the material at the entry point is properly cleared.

No finishing overlap

0.25" finishing overlap

Note: The finishing overlap follows the selected contour, so it is safe to specify a large overlap.

Use Thin Wall

When milling part features with wall thicknesses comparable to sheet metal stock, or even thinner, the stock is subjected to the forces generated by metal removal. This can result in the delicate structure of thin walls moving relative to the tool, making it difficult to maintain dimensional accuracy and impart the specified surface finish.

This option can be used to reduce the vibration and chatter by ensuring that both sides of a thin wall are machined at the same time.

Thin Wall Width

The width of walls that should be considered thin walls.

Any wall with this width or thinner is machined on both sides at the same time to reduce vibration and chatter.

Direction

The direction option lets you control whether the program should try to maintain either climb or conventional milling.

Notice: Depending on the geometry, it is not always possible to maintain climb or conventional milling throughout the entire toolpath.

One way

Both ways

One way

Select One way to machine all the passes in a single direction. When One way is used, the program tries to use climb milling relative to the selected boundaries.

Other way

This reverses the direction of the toolpath compared to the One way setting to generate a conventional milling toolpath.

Both ways

When Both ways is selected, the program disregards the machining direction and links passes with the directions that result in the shortest toolpath.

Direction

The Direction option lets you control the cutting method. The default is to cut Both Ways, back and forth across the face. You may choose to cut in one direction by selecting either Climb or Conventional milling.

Both ways

Climb

Conventional

Note: Depending on the geometry, it is not always possible to maintain climb or conventional milling throughout the entire toolpath.

Use Chip Thinning

Enable and the tool will roll onto the cut, reducing the chip load of the cutting edge.

Disabled

Enabled

Both Sides

Enable to machine from both side of the part when multiple depth cuts are taken. The starting stepover is applied from each side of the part for each stepdown pass.

Pass 1 starts on the right
Pass 2 starts on the left

Pass 1 - Stepover
measured from the right

Pass 2 - Stepover
measured from the left

Transition Type

Specifies the type of connection between passes.

Smooth Transition

Straight Transition

Short Transition

No Contact (not shown) - Passes are not connected on the same Z level. The tool retracts between each connecting pass.

Direction

Lets you specify whether the program should climb or conventional mill the thread.

Conventional Milling

Climb Milling

Other Considerations. The cut direction, the type of hole (OD or ID) and the threading hand direction (left or right) have an effect on where the thread milling starts. It is possible to cut from top to bottom or bottom to top, depending on these settings.
Examples:
A right-hand thread on an OD (boss), with a climb cut will mill from the top to the bottom.
A right-hand thread on an ID (hole), with a climb cut will mill from the bottom to the top.

Use the Climb or Conventional Direction parameter to control Top to Bottom or Bottom to Top cut direction.

Direction

In conjunction with the turning mode, this setting determines the tool direction when cutting.

Front to Back

Back to Front

Both Ways

Front to Back - Select this option to cut from the front side of the stock toward the back side, that is, toward the main chuck.

Back to Front - Cuts from the back side, toward the front side. Away from the chuck. For tools with special geometry where chip thinning control is important. See the Use Back Cutting option shown on the Passes tab.

Both Ways - This option allows the tool to cut in both directions. The result is a back and forth cutting motion. Ensure that you are using an appropriate tool that can cut in both directions when selecting this option.

Cycle

In conjunction with the Turning Mode, this setting determines the tool cutting direction.

Horizontal Passes

Vertical Passes

Back Cutting

Horizontal - Cuts from the front side of the stock toward the back side. Toward the main spindle.

Vertical - Cuts from the outside, toward the centerline for OD machining. Cuts from centerline, toward the outside for ID machining.

Back Cuttings - For tools with special geometry where chip thinning control is important. Cuts from the back side, toward the front side of the stock.

Back Cutting

For tools with special geometry where chip thinning control is important. This activates additional controls to set the Entry Radius blend and Exit Distance.

Only available when the Cycle type is set to Back cutting.

C = Cut direction - Away from the Chuck
R = Radius for Back Cutting entry
D = Distance for feed reduction

Starting the toolpath closest to the chuck side, the Radius blends onto the cut and feeds in the positive direction. At a distance before the end of the cut, the feedrate is reduced to prevent chipping of the part or the tool.

Back Cutting

For tools with special geometry where chip thinning control is important. This activates additional controls to set the Back Cutting Radius blend and Back Cutting Exit Distance. Only available when the cutting mode direction is set from Back to Front.

C = Cut direction - Away from the Chuck
R = Radius for Back Cutting entry
D = Distance for feed reduction

Starting the toolpath closest to the chuck side, the Radius blends onto the cut and feeds in the positive direction. At a distance before the end of the cut, the feedrate is reduced to prevent chipping of the part or the tool.

Back Cutting Radius

This radius is used for the initial blend onto the cut. Consult your tooling supplier for their recommendation on the best blend size. Generally a size equal to, or larger than the Maximum Roughing Stepdown will work as a starting point.

R = Radius for Back Cutting entry

Back Cutting Exit Distance

Specifies the distance before the end of the cut to slow down the feedrate.

D = Distance before the end of the cut

Reducing the feedrate before the end of the cut helps to prevent chipping of the part or the tool. This uses the Lead-Out Feedrate shown on the Tools Tab. Consult your tooling supplier for their recommendation on the best distance and feedrate to use

Direction

Outside to Inside

Inside to Outside

Both Ways

Outside to Inside - Select this option to cut from the outside of the stock, toward the center.

Inside to Outside - Select this option to cut from the center of the stock, toward the outside.

Both Ways - For a face profiling operation, this option allows cutting in both directions.

Direction

Specifies if material is removed using Conventional Milling or Climb Milling, or a combination of both.

Conventional Milling

Climb Milling

Climb vs. Conventional Milling

Milling tools advance through the material so that the cutting flutes engage the material at maximum thickness and then decreases to zero. This is called Climb Milling.

Cutting in the opposite direction causes the tool to scoop up the material, starting at zero thickness and increasing to maximum. This is called Conventional Milling.

Conventional milling is used often on manual machines because backlash in the machine lead screws causes the tool to lurch when climb cutting. This is not a problem on CNC machines because they use ball screws.

Conventional milling causes the tool to rub against the cutting surface, work hardening the material, generating heat, and increasing tool wear. Raking chips across the finished surface also produces a poorer surface finish.

Unless specifically recommended by the tool manufacturer for the material being milled, always use climb milling on a CNC. Climb milling produces far less cutting pressure and heat, leaves a better surface finish, and results in longer tool life.

Note: When working with brittle materials, like acrylics, climb milling may be used so material does not "blow out" along edges.

Radial (Wall) Stock To Leave

The radial stock to leave parameter controls the amount of material to leave in the radial (perpendicular to the tool axis) direction, that is, at the side of the tool.

Radial stock to leave

Radial and Axial stock to leave

Specifying a positive radial stock to leave results in material being left on the vertical walls and steep areas of the part.

For surfaces that are not exactly vertical, the program interpolates between the axial (floor) and radial stock to leave values, so the stock left in the radial direction on these surfaces might be different from the specified value, depending on surface slope and the axial stock to leave value.

Changing the radial stock to leave automatically sets the axial stock to leave to the same amount, unless you manually enter the axial stock to leave.

For finishing operations, the default value is 0 mm/0 in, that is, no material is left.

For roughing operations, the default is to leave a small amount of material that can then be removed later by one or more finishing operations.

Negative Stock to Leave

When using a negative stock to leave, the machining operation removes more material from your stock than your model shape. This can be used to machine electrodes with a spark gap, where the size of the spark gap is equal to the negative stock to leave.

Both the radial and axial stock to leave can be negative numbers. However, the negative radial stock to leave must be less than the tool radius.

When using a ball or radius cutter with a negative radial stock to leave that is greater than the corner radius, the negative axial stock to leave must be less than or equal to the corner radius.

Axial (Floor) Stock To Leave

The axial stock to leave parameter controls the amount of material to leave in the axial (along the Z-axis) direction, that is, at the end of the tool.

Axial Stock to Leave

Both Radial and Axial Stock to Leave

Specifying a positive axial stock to leave results in material being left on the shallow areas of the part.

For surfaces that are not exactly horizontal, the program interpolates between the axial and radial (wall) stock to leave values, so the stock left in the axial direction on these surfaces might be different from the specified value, depending on surface slope and the radial stock to leave value.

Changing the radial stock to leave automatically sets the axial stock to leave to the same amount, unless you manually enter the axial stock to leave.

For finishing operations, the default value is 0 mm/0 in, that is, no material is left.

For roughing operations, the default is to leave a small amount of material that can then be removed later by one or more finishing operations.

Negative Stock to Leave

When using a negative stock to leave, the machining operation removes more material from your stock than your model shape. This can be used to machine electrodes with a spark gap, where the size of the spark gap is equal to the negative stock to leave.

Both the radial and axial stock to leave can be negative numbers, however when using a ball or radius cutter with a negative radial stock to leave that is greater than the corner radius, the negative axial stock to leave must be less than or equal to the corner radius.

Stock To Leave

Specifies the stock to leave behind on walls and floors.

Specifying a positive stock to leave value results in extra material being left on the part. For roughing operations, it is common to leave a small amount of stock that can then be removed by future finishing operations.

Stock To Leave

Specifies the stock to leave behind on walls and floors.

Specifying a positive stock to leave value results in extra material being left on the part. For roughing operations, it is common to leave a small amount of stock that can then be removed by future finishing operations.

Radial Stock To Leave

Controls the amount of material to leave in the radial direction.
Used for leaving stock on the ID or OD of the part.

Radial Stock 1mm

Radial Stock 1mm

Radial Stock 0.0

Radial and Axial Stock -1mm

For surfaces that are not exactly horizontal, the program interpolates between the Axial Stock value (wall) and the Radial Stock values. The stock left in the radial direction on these surfaces might be different from the specified value, depending on surface slope and the axial stock to leave value.

Changing the Radial Stock to Leave value automatically sets the Axial Stock to Leave to the same amount. You can manually enter a different Axial Stock value.

If you plan on roughing and finishing with different tools, set the rough operation to the amount of stock to leave for the next finishing operation.

Negative Stock to Leave You may use a negative value. This will cause the tool to machine material beyond the edge of your model shape.

Note: Maximum negative stock to leave must be less than the tool nose radius.
With an insert nose radius of .032, the largest negative stock would be -.032
You cannot compensate past the theoretical tip of the tool.

Axial Stock To Leave

Controls the amount of material to leave on the vertical faces being turned.

Axial Stock 1mm

Axial Stock 1mm

Axial Stock 0.0

Radial and Axial Stock -1mm

For surfaces that are not exactly vertical, the program interpolates between the Axial Stock value (wall) and the Radial Stock values. The stock left in the axial direction on these surfaces might be different from the specified value, depending on surface slope and the radial stock to leave value.

Changing the Radial Stock to Leave value automatically sets the Axial Stock to Leave to the same amount. You can manually enter a different Axial Stock value.

If you plan on roughing and finishing with different tools, set the rough operation to the amount of stock to leave for the next finishing operation.

Negative Stock to Leave You may use a negative value. This will cause the tool to machine material beyond the edge of your model shape.

Note: Maximum negative stock to leave must be less than the tool nose radius.
With an insert nose radius of .032, the largest negative stock would be -.032
You cannot compensate past the theoretical tip of the tool.

X Finish Allowance

Controls the amount of material to leave in the radial direction.
Used for leaving stock on the ID or OD of the part.

X Stock 1mm

X Stock 1mm

X Stock 0.0

X and Z Stock -1mm

For surfaces that are not exactly horizontal, the program interpolates between the Axial Stock value (wall) and the Radial Stock values. The stock left in the radial direction on these surfaces might be different from the specified value, depending on surface slope and the axial stock to leave value.

Changing the X Stock to Leave value automatically sets the Z Stock to Leave to the same amount. You can manually enter a different Axial Stock value.

If you plan on roughing and finishing with different tools, set the rough operation to the amount of stock to leave for the next finishing operation.

Negative Stock to Leave You may use a negative value. This will cause the tool to machine material beyond the edge of your model shape.

Note: Maximum negative stock to leave must be less than the tool nose radius.
With an insert nose radius of .032, the largest negative stock would be -.032
You cannot compensate past the theoretical tip of the tool.

Z Finish Allowance

Controls the amount of material to leave in the axial direction.
Used for leaving stock on the vertical faces being turned.

Z Stock 1mm

Z Stock 1mm

Z Stock 0.0

Radial and Axial Stock -1mm

For surfaces that are not exactly vertical, the program interpolates between the Axial Stock value (wall) and the Radial Stock values. The stock left in the axial direction on these surfaces might be different from the specified value, depending on surface slope and the radial stock to leave value.

Changing the X Stock to Leave value automatically sets the Z Stock to Leave to the same amount. You can manually enter a different Axial Stock value.

If you plan on roughing and finishing with different tools, set the rough operation to the amount of stock to leave for the next finishing operation.

Negative Stock to Leave You may use a negative value. This will cause the tool to machine material beyond the edge of your model shape.

Note: Maximum negative stock to leave must be less than the tool nose radius.
With an insert nose radius of .032, the largest negative stock would be -.032
You cannot compensate past the theoretical tip of the tool.

Extend to Stock

When enabled, applies the finish allowance (defined by the Stock to Leave) to the stock in addition to the model. This means that the toolpath does not dip as it comes off the shoulder on a model. Instead, the toolpath continues in a straight line, leaving a finish allowance on the stock as well.

When disabled, the finish allowance is applied only to the model.

Enabled

Disabled

Additional Offset

The additional offset is applied to the selected boundary/boundaries and tool containment.

A positive value offsets the boundary outwards unless the tool containment is Inside, in which case a positive value offsets inwards.

Negative offset
Tool center on
boundary option

No offset
Tool center on
boundary option

Positive offset
Tool center on
boundary option

To ensure that the edge of the tool overlaps the boundary, select the Outside tool containment method and specify a small positive value.

To ensure that the edge of the tool is clear of the boundary, select the Inside tool containment method and specify a small positive value.

Stock To Leave

Positive

None

Negative

Positive Stock Value - The amount of stock left for subsequent roughing or finishing operations.

No Stock to Leave - Remove all material up to the selected geometry or part model.

'Negative Stock Value - Removes material beyond the selected geometry or part model. This technique is often used in Electrode Machining to allow for a spark gap or to meet tolerance requirements of a part.

Stock To Leave

Positive

None

Negative

Positive Stock Value - The amount of stock left for subsequent roughing or finishing operations.

No Stock to Leave - Remove all material up to the selected geometry or part model. This is the default.

Negative Stock Value - Removes material beyond the selected geometry or part model.

Geometry

Allows you to select the drill positions from points (vertices, sketch points), sketches containing points, arcs (sketch or solid edges), or cylindrical faces.

Remove Duplicate Holes

Specifies that duplicate holes should be removed.

Order By Depth

When enabled this orders the cuts of multiple contours or cavities by Z level.

Model with multiple cavity selections

All cavities cut by Z level

Order By Area

When enabled this completes all depth cuts for each contour or cavity before moving on to the next.

Model with multiple
contour or cavity selections

Complete the first contour or cavity
before moving on to the next

Order By Depth

When enabled, cuts all of a single curve before cutting the next curve.

2 Edge Curves selected

Enabled
Curve 1 is cut complete
before curve 2

Disabled
Toolpath is generated by level
cutting both curves

Drill Location Selections

You can select drilling locations by Model Face, Hole Edge, Sketch Point, Sketch Circle or a Diameter Size Range.

Face Selection

Edge Selection

Sketch Point Selection

Sketch Circle Selection

Hole Mode

Determines what you can select for your hole locations.

Selected Faces - Model based selection.

Cylinder Face Selection

Chamfer Face Selection

Selected Points - Geometry based selection.

Feature Edge Selection

Sketch Point Selection

Sketch Circle Selection

Diameter Range - Size based selection.

The system will evaluate the model based on the Minimum and Maximum Diameter values. Use this range to include or exclude hole sizes.
Example: Select all .250 - .2501 diameter holes for drilling and all .2505 - .2506 diameter holes for reaming.

Using Model based selections insures associativity to any future changes of the feature.

Note: Spot Drilling Options
* If you select the modeled chamfered face of a hole. The Bottom Height (depth) will automatically be determined to the theoretical tip.
* If you select by Diameter Range to include all holes. Set the Bottom Height from Chamfer Width and set the Chamfer Width value.

Selection Mode

Determines the geometry selection process.

Selected Faces - Lets you manually select faces of holes and bosses.

Diameter Range - Automatically selects holes, bosses, or both, based on specified minimum and maximum diameter values.

Selection Mode

Determines the geometry selection process.

Selected Faces - Lets you manually select faces of holes and bosses.

Diameter Range - Automatically selects holes, bosses, or both, based on specified minimum and maximum diameter values.

Selection Mode

Determines the geometry selection process.

Selected Faces - Lets you manually select faces of holes and bosses.

Diameter Range - Automatically selects holes, bosses, or both, based on specified minimum and maximum diameter values.

Hole Faces

Shows the number of Faces selected for drilling.

Selected Faces - Model-based selection.

Cylinder Face Selection

Chamfer Face Selection

Note: To select geometry, switch the Hole Mode to Selected Points.

Hole Points

Shows the number of Points, Circles or Edges selected for drilling.

Selected Points - Geometry-based selection.

Feature Edge Selection

Sketch Point Selection

Sketch Circle Selection

Note: To select Model Features, switch the Hole Mode to Selected Faces.
Using Model-based selections insures associativity to any future changes of the feature.

Minimum Hole Diameter

Sets the range of the smallest diameter to select from the model. Eliminates the need to physically select features from the model.

Handy for Spot or Center Drilling when you need to select a variety of holes.

Tip: To Spot drill and create a chamfer - Select a Range for the holes to include. Set the Bottom Height from Chamfer Width and set the Chamfer Width value.

Minimum Diameter

Specifies the smallest diameter of holes or bosses to include in the selection.

In the image below, the diameter of the hole on the right is smaller than the Minimum Diameter value. As a result, the hole is not included in the selection.

Minimum Diameter

Specifies the smallest diameter of holes or bosses to include in the selection.

In the image below, the diameter of the hole on the right is smaller than the Minimum Diameter value. As a result, the hole is not included in the selection.

Minimum Diameter

Specifies the smallest diameter of holes or bosses to include in the selection.

In the image below, the diameter of the hole on the right is smaller than the Minimum Diameter value. As a result, the hole is not included in the selection.

Maximum Hole Diameter

Sets the range of the largest diameter to select from the model. Eliminates the need to physically select features from the model.

Handy for Spot or Center Drilling when you need to select a variety of holes.

Tip: To Spot drill and create a chamfer - Select a Range for the holes to include. Set the Bottom Height from Chamfer Width and set the Chamfer Width value.

Maximum Diameter

Specifies the largest diameter of holes or bosses to include in the selection.

In the image below, the diameter of the boss on the left is greater than the Maximum Diameter value. As a result, the boss is not included in the selection.

Maximum Diameter

Specifies the largest diameter of holes or bosses to include in the selection.

In the image below, the diameter of the boss on the left is greater than the Maximum Diameter value. As a result, the boss is not included in the selection.

Maximum Diameter

Specifies the largest diameter of holes or bosses to include in the selection.

In the image below, the diameter of the boss on the left is greater than the Maximum Diameter value. As a result, the boss is not included in the selection.

Same Diameter

Selects all holes with the same diameter as the currently selected feature. For example, if you select a single 6-mm hole and a single 12-mm hole, every 6-mm and 12-mm hole on the part is automatically selected.

A single selection can detect matching holes.

Note: This option is associative to the model. If additional holes with the same diameter are added to the model, regenerating the operation automatically includes the new holes.

Containment Boundary

Use this with Select Same Diameter and Diameter Range to include similar items inside the containment areas. Select any Edge or Sketch boundary to contain the drilling locations. Use multiple boundaries or nested boundaries, to include or exclude groups of holes. The toolpath will be inside the selected boundary unless the boundaries are nested. You can nest several boundaries inside each other.

In the examples below the selected boundaries are shown in blue.

Sketch Boundaries

Holes inside are included

Nested Boundaries

Inside areas are excluded

Selecting the rim area only

Excluding the rim area

Same Depth

Check to select all the holes that share the same top to bottom distance as the currently select feature.

Example: You can use this as a way to distinguish between 6mm tapped holes and 6mm drilled holes of different depths.

Short Depth 6mm Holes Selected

Short Depth ISO View

Short Depth Front View

Long Depth 6mm Holes Selected

Long Depth ISO View

Long Depth Front View

Arrow indicates the selected hole feature.

at the Mid Level Height.

at the Mid Level Height and

at the Lower Level Height.

Auto-Merge Hole Segments

Check to merge multiple hole segments. When enable all hole segments are included to determine the starting height for drilling.

Example: If a hole was Spot Drilled or Counter Bored first, you may want to start drilling from a clearance above that machined area. Enabling Auto-Merge will start the drilling from above the highest hole segment.

Left: Auto-Merge Disabled - Right: Auto-Merge Enabled
Blue line indicates the starting height for drilling.

Order By Depth

Controls the sorting of holes depending on their Z height.

When selected, holes are sorted from lowest to highest Z height. Multiple holes at the same Z height are sorted by the selected Order type. When deselected, no depth sorting is applied and the holes are sorted by the selected Order type.

From lowest to highest Z height.

Tip: To sort holes from highest to lowest Z height, select the Order by Depth checkbox and the Reverse Order checkbox.

Order

Specifies how the holes should be ordered for machining. Optimized hole movements can reduce cycle time.

Order selected

Optimized order

Inside to Outside

Order By X
ISO view

Order By Y
ISO view

Reverse Order

Changes the order of the currently selected toolpath to start at the opposite position.

Deselected
First hole is at the inner most location.

Selected
First hole is at the outer most location.

Drill Tip Through Bottom

When Enabled the tool tip will drill past the bottom of the hole. It positions the lip of the drill to the full diameter at the bottom of the hole.

Depth is to the Tip - Depth is to the Lip.
Left Side: Unchecked - Right Side: Checked

Note: When drilling through the bottom of the part, be aware of the fixture or material below the part.

Break-Through Depth

Specifies how far the lip of the tool drills past the bottom of the hole, to ensure a clean cut through the part.

Left: Break Through 0.0 - Right: Break Through 0.06

Note: When drilling through the bottom of the part, be aware of the fixture or material below the part.

Drilling Cycle Types

Selects the type of drilling cycle to use and displays the parameters for the selected drilling operation. Shown with the common industry G-Code.

Drilling: Feed to Depth & Rapid Out - For holes with depths of less than 3x the tool diameter. (G81)

Counterboring: Feed to Depth, Dwell, Rapid Out - A dwell is used to improve the bottom finish of a hole. (G82)

Chip breaking: Uses multiple pecks that periodically retracting the tool to break the chips and/or allow coolant to enter the hole. For holes with depths more than three times the tool diameter. (G73)

Deep drilling: Similar to Chip breaking, but retracts completely out of the hole to clear chips and/or flood the hole with coolant. Also known as Peck drilling. (G83)

Break through: Allows for reduced feed and speed before breaking through a hole.

Guided deep drilling: A gun drill has a single cutting edge. Guide pads burnish the hole to produces a straight, deep hole with a precision diameter.

Tapping: Taps right- or left-handed threads depending on the selected tool.

Left tapping: Feed to Depth, Reverse the spindle, Feed Out - Rotates counterclockwise as it enters the hole to cut a thread. (G74)

Right tapping: Feed to Depth, Reverse the spindle, Feed Out - Rotates clockwise as it enters the hole to cut a thread. (G84)

Tapping with chip breaking: Feeds in and out multiple times, going deeper each time, until it reaches the final depth.

Reaming: Feed to Depth and immediately Feed Out upon reaching the final depth. (G85)

Boring: Feed to Depth, Dwell, Feed Out. (G86)

Stop boring: Feed to Depth, Stop the spindle, Rapid Out. (G87)

Fine boring: Feed to Depth, Stop the spindle, Shift from the wall, Rapid Out. (G76)

Back-boring: Boring from the back of an existing hole. (G77)

Circular pocket milling: This can be used to call a custom cycle for circular pocketing.

Bore milling: This can be used to call a custom cycle for helical bore milling.

Thread milling: This can be used to call a custom cycle for helical thread milling.

Probe: Used to call a probe tool macro from the machine. Requires a custom post processors. See the advanced Probing function, under the Setup pull down.

Cycle Type

Selects the type of drilling cycle to use for the drilling operation. Shown with the common industry G-Code.

Drilling: Feed to Depth & Rapid Out - For holes with depths of less than 3x the tool diameter. (G81)

Counterboring: Feed to Depth, Dwell, Rapid Out - A dwell is used to improve the bottom finish of a hole. (G82)

Chip breaking: Uses multiple pecks that periodically retracting the tool to break the chips and/or allow coolant to enter the hole. For holes with depths more than three times the tool diameter. (G73)

Deep drilling: Similar to Chip breaking, but retracts completely out of the hole to clear chips and/or flood the hole with coolant. Also known as Peck drilling. (G83)

Break through: Allows for reduced feed and speed before breaking through a hole.

Guided deep drilling: A gun drill has a single cutting edge. Guide pads burnish the hole to produces a straight, deep hole with a precision diameter.

Tapping: Taps right- or left-handed threads depending on the selected tool.

Left tapping: Feed to Depth, Reverse the spindle, Feed Out - Rotates counterclockwise as it enters the hole to cut a thread. (G74)

Right tapping: Feed to Depth, Reverse the spindle, Feed Out - Rotates clockwise as it enters the hole to cut a thread. (G84)

Tapping with chip breaking: Feeds in and out multiple times, going deeper each time, until it reaches the final depth.

Reaming: Feed to Depth and immediately Feed Out upon reaching the final depth. (G85)

Boring: Feed to Depth, Dwell, Feed Out. (G86)

Stop boring: Feed to Depth, Stop the spindle, Rapid Out. (G87)

Fine boring: Feed to Depth, Stop the spindle, Shift from the wall, Rapid Out. (G76)

Back-boring: Boring from the back of an existing hole. (G77)

Circular pocket milling: This can be used to call a custom cycle for circular pocketing.

Bore milling: This can be used to call a custom cycle for helical bore milling.

Thread milling: This can be used to call a custom cycle for helical thread milling.

Probe: Used to call a probe tool macro from the machine. Requires a custom post processors. See the advanced Probing function, under the Setup pull down.

Pecking Depth

Specifies the increment to drill, breaking the full depth into multiple increments.

Sets the depth for the first peck move, which feeds in and rapids out of the hole to remove and break chips.

Peck Depth Amount

Accumulated Pecking Depth

Specifies the the total depth to drill, before the tool retracts to the Feed Height. This will extract the chips from the hole and allow coolant to enter the hole.

Total distance to peck before making a full retract.

Example: Pecking Depth of 8mm and an Accumulated Pecking Depth of 14mm, the cycle will complete 2 pecks before retracting to the Feed Height.

Boring Shift

Specifies an incremental distance to move the boring bar insert away from the wall, before the tool is retracted. This move is usually made in the X direction. This can be applied to boring bars and back face chamfering tools.

Some controllers will include a parameter to change angular orientation of the spindle, and position the insert tip to the 3 o'clock position.

Insert in contact with the wall

Insert shift

Insert shift

Note: It is important to know how your specific machine cycle works and where the insert positions, when the spindle is at an angle of 0.0 degrees. This may also require modifications to your postprocessor for proper, safe operation.

Spindle Shift Orientation

Specifies the orientation angle of the boring bar insert tip.

Ideally, the spindle orientation at 0.0 degrees, will position the insert tip to 3 o'clock. Depending on your tool holder and boring bar, 0.0 degrees may not put the insert in the correct location for an X axis shift. Use this parameter to shift the angle of the insert to the 3 o'clock position.

Shift Orientation 0.0 degrees.
Insert Position is off.

Shift Orientation 180.
Insert is at 3 o'clock.

Note: Not all CNC controls have full support for controlling the spindle orientation. It is important to know how your specific machine cycle works and the stopping position of your tools spindle. This may also require modifications to your postprocessor for proper, safe operation.

Back Boring Distance

Specifies the counter bore distance as measured from the Bottom Height position, defined in the Heights tab. Since the tool will feed in a positive Z motion this is a positive value.

A centrifugaly advance insert tool might be used, or a reverse counter bore tool with a quick disconnect can be mounted, after the bore shaft enters the hole.

The illustration shows a reverse counter bore.

Bar enters the hole

Counter bore added

Back Bore Distance

Note: Because of the complexity of the motion and the amount of manual intervention required, this type of operation is rarely used. It is important to know how your specific machine cycle works and the motion it will generate. This may also require modifications to your postprocessor for proper, safe operation.

Sideways Compensation

This setting determines the side of the toopath from which the tool center is offset. Choose between Left (climb milling) sideways compensation or Right (conventional milling) sideways compensation.

Climb Milling

Conventional Milling

Climb vs. Conventional Milling

Climb milling can be thought of as the cutter rolling along the surface that it is cutting. This generally gives a better finish in most metals, but requires good machine rigidity. Using this method, chips start at maximum thickness and get thinner towards the end of the cut, meaning more heat in the chip and less in the part.

With conventional milling, the cutter is rotating away from the surface it is cutting. This method is more commonly used with manual or less rigid machines. It does have some advantages, and can even give a better finish when machining certain materials including some woods.

Compensation Type

Specifies the compensation type.

  • In computer - Tool compensation is calculated automatically by the program, based on the selected tool diameter. The post-processed output contains the compensated path directly, instead of G41/G42 codes.
  • In control - Tool compensation is not calculated, but rather G41/G42 codes are output to allow the operator to set the compensation amount and wear on the machine tool control.
  • Wear - Works as if In computer was selected, but also outputs the G41/G42 codes. This lets the machine tool operator adjust for tool wear at the machine tool control by entering the difference in tool size as a negative number.
  • Inverse wear - Identical to the Wear option, except that the wear adjustment is entered as a positive number.

Note: Control compensation (including Wear and Inverse wear) is only done on finishing passes.

Sideways Compensation

Determines how to offset the cut from the selected edge.

Examples of Left, Right and Center cutting offsets.
Left and Right are always viewed from the direction of the cut.
  • Left - Compensate Left of the selected edge.
  • Right - Compensate Right of the selected edge.
  • Center - Puts the cutting head directly on the selected edge.

Left will compensate the head away from the edge, based on these rules.
* For an Outside cut, with a Clockwise chain selection.
* For an Inside cut, with a Counter-Clockwise chain selection.
Changing the direction of the cut requires a Right Compensation direction.

Note: Use Center for Etching.
This keeps the head directly on the selected chain.

Compensation Type

Specifies the compensation type.

  • In computer - The head position is calculated by the program, based on the Kerf diameter and the Sideways Compensation direction. The post-processed output contains the actual compensated position to cut the part to size. The Computer compensates for the width of the Kerf.
  • In control - The head position is output as the actual coordinates of the selected chain. Compensation is not calculated, but instead, compensation codes are output to allow the operator to set the offset amount at the machine tool control. The Machine Control compensates for the width of the Kerf.

Compensation Type

Specifies the compensation type.

  • In computer - Tool compensation is calculated automatically by the program, based on the selected tool diameter. The post-processed output contains the compensated path directly, instead of G41/G42 codes.
  • In control - Tool compensation is not calculated, but rather G41/G42 codes are output to allow the operator to set the compensation amount and wear on the machine tool control.
  • Wear - Works as if In computer was selected, but also outputs the G41/G42 codes. This lets the machine tool operator adjust for tool wear at the machine tool control by entering the difference in tool size as a negative number.
  • Inverse wear - Identical to the Wear option, except that the wear adjustment is entered as a positive number.

Note: Control compensation (including Wear and Inverse wear) is only done on finishing passes.

Maximum Stepover

Specifies the maximum stepover for each cut.

Maximum Stepover
The amount to cut per pass.

Number of Stepovers

Specifies the maximum number of stepovers.

Number of Stepovers
The total number of cuts
to make for this toolpath.

Maximum Stepover

Specifies the maximum horizontal stepover between passes.

Note: This is NOT the same as optimal load settings with adaptive clearing paths. With legacy 2D roughing, the tool still sees full cutter engagement when transitioning from one pass to the next.

Adaptive Clearing

Legacy 2D Clearing

Cusp Height

Specifies the desired cusp height to calculate the stepover, stepdown, or both.

Cusps are excess material that run along a toolpath and are a result of the gap between the position of the tool in successive passes. Generally, the smaller the stepdown and stepover, the smaller the cusp height.

In reverse, you can use a desired cusp height to calculate the stepover and stepdown value for a toolpath. Using the cusp height helps give an even surface finish across the part, independent of the tool selection.

1 - Cusp Height
2 - Stepdown
3 - Stepover

Cusp Height

Specifies the desired cusp height to calculate the stepover, stepdown, or both.

Cusps are excess material that run along a toolpath and are a result of the gap between the position of the tool in successive passes. Generally, the smaller the stepdown and stepover, the smaller the cusp height.

In reverse, you can use a desired cusp height to calculate the stepover and stepdown value for a toolpath. Using the cusp height helps give an even surface finish across the part, independent of the tool selection.

1 - Cusp Height
2 - Stepdown
3 - Stepover

Smoothing Deviation

The maximum amount of smoothing applied to the roughing passes. Use this parameter to avoid sharp corners in the toolpath.

Corner Deviation

The maximum corner deviation. Use this parameter to avoid sharp corners in the toolpath.

Smoothing Deviation

The maximum amount of smoothing applied to the roughing passes. Use this parameter to avoid sharp corners in the toolpath.

Finishing Passes

With Finishing Passes

Without Finishing Passes

Finishing Passes

Enable this option to perform the specified number of finishing passes.

Finishing Passes

Enable this option to perform the specified number of finishing passes.

Specifies the maximum stepover for each cut, when taking multiple finishing passes.

The amount to cut per pass.

Specifies the number of finishing passes.

Leads On All Finishing Passes

Forces a full lead in and out on every finishing pass.

Enabled

Note: Lead parameters are set on the Linking tab of the Operations dialog box.

Repeat Finishing Pass

Enable to perform an additional finishing pass with zero (0.0) stock.
Clears the stock left over from tool deflection.
Also refered to as a Spring Pass.

No Dragging

When selected, moves that apply negative pressure on the insert are eliminated. Removes cuts up vertical walls and faces. Before reaching the end of the cut, the tool retracts and changes position to cut down the wall from the outside.

No Dragging Disabled

No Dragging Enabled

No Drag Limit

Specifies the minimum angle between the part face and the cutting edge of the insert, that triggers the No Drag toolpath actions.

Minimum Angle

No Drag Clearance

Specifies the distance to stop before reaching the end face. Causes the tool to retract and change the cut direction.

Distance from Drag face

No Drag Overlap

Specifies the distance to overlap the last cut, before the retract.

Cut Overlap

Spring Pass

Enable to perform the final finishing pass twice to remove stock left due to tool deflection.

Multiple Depths

Specifies that multiple depths should be taken.

With Multiple Depth cuts

Without Multiple Depth cuts

Multiple Depths

Enable to specify the step to create multiple depth cuts.

Single cut to depth

.020 in. Maximum Stepdown

.020 in. Maximum Stepdown

Maximum Roughing Stepdown

Specifies the maximum stepdown between Z-levels for roughing.

Maximum Roughing Stepdown
Shown without Finishing Stepdowns

Note: Sequential Z-level stepdowns are taken at the Maximum Roughing Stepdown value. The Final Roughing stepdown takes the remaining stock, once the remaining stock is less than the Maximum Roughing Stepdown value.

Maximum Roughing Stepdown

Specifies the distance for the maximum stepdown between Z-levels.

Maximum Roughing Stepdown

Maximum Roughing Stepdown

The maximum stepdown is applied to the full depth, less any remaining stock and finish pass amounts. The Final Roughing stepdown takes the remaining stock.

Maximum Stepdown

Specifies the maximum stepdown between Z-levels for taking multiple depth cuts.

.020 in. Maximum Stepdown

.020 in. Maximum Stepdown

Maximum Roughing Stepdown

Controls the maximum amount to remove for each roughing cut. A larger value removes more material with each roughing pass. A smaller value reduces the amount of stress on the tool.

Smaller 2mm cut

Larger 4mm Cut

Depth of cut

Controls the maximum amount to remove for each roughing cut. A larger value removes more material with each roughing pass. A smaller value reduces the amount of stress on the tool.

Smaller 2mm cut

Larger 4mm Cut

Maximum Stepdown

Specifies the maximum stepdown between Z-levels.

Maximum Stepdown

Specifies the distance for the maximum stepdown between Z-levels.

Maximum Stepdown

Maximum Stepdown

The maximum stepdown is applied to the full depth, less any remaining stock and finish pass amounts. The Final stepdown takes the remaining stock.

Maximum Stepdown

Specifies the distance for the maximum stepdown between Z-levels. Each complete pass around the model will advance this distance in Z.

Ramp Maximum Stepdown

After reaching the final depth an additional pass is added to smooth the bottom cut.

Finishing Stepdowns

The number of finishing passes using the bottom of the tool.

Shown with three Finishing Passes

Finishing Stepdown

The size of each stepdown in the finishing passes.

Finishing Stepdown

Wall Taper Angle

Specifies the taper angle of the walls.

Defining a slope angle can be used to machine features with a 2D strategy that would have otherwise required a 3D strategy.

Note: The slope angle is NOT driven by model geometry, so it is possible that an error entering the slope angle can affect the finished machined part.

Slope Angle @ 0 deg

Slope Angle @ 45 deg

Geometry Selection

Bottom Selection

Top Selection

Note: When using a slope angle with the Adaptive Clearing strategy, geometry must be selected at the top of the pocket.

Finish Only At Final Depth

Perform finishing passes only at the final depth to avoid leaving marks on the walls.

Disabled

Enabled

Minimum Axial Engagement

Specifies the minimum length of the tool's flute that should be engaged with each cutting move.

Useful for engaging with sufficient material. The tool could experience excessive vibrations if it does not have sufficient material to engage with when cutting.

In the example below, the tool performs a cut at a large depth and then performs finer-step moves in the upwards direction. With no minimum axial engagement limit, all the finer-step moves are machined.

With a Minimum Axial Engagement of 1 mm, any cutting move that causes the tool to engage with less than 1 mm on its flute is removed. The remaining material can be machined with a future operation that engages with more of the stock.

Minimum stepdown

Specifies the minimum distance for stepdowns.

Useful for taking larger cuts to engage more of the cutter's length for even tool wear. If the stepdowns are too small, the bottom of the tool may wear excessively compared to the rest of the tool.

Small stepdowns
Excessive wear at edge

Larger stepdowns
Even wear across tool

Minimum stepdown

Specifies the minimum distance for stepdowns.

Useful for taking larger cuts to engage more of the cutter's length for even tool wear. If the stepdowns are too small, the bottom of the tool may wear excessively compared to the rest of the tool.

Small stepdowns
Excessive wear at edge

Larger stepdowns
Even wear across tool

Tolerance

The machining tolerance is the sum of the tolerances used for toolpath generation and geometry triangulation. Any additional filtering tolerances must be added to this tolerance to get the total tolerance.

Loose Tolerance .100

Tight Tolerance .001

CNC machine contouring motion is controlled using line G1 and arc G2 G3 commands. To accommodate this, CAM approximates spline and surface toolpaths by linearizing them; creating many short line segments to approximate the desired shape. How accurately the toolpath matches the desired shape depends largely on the number of lines used. More lines result in a toolpath that more closely approximates the nominal shape of the spline or surface.

Data Starving

It is tempting to always use very tight tolerances, but there are trade-offs including longer toolpath calculation times, large G-code files, and very short line moves. The first two are not much of a problem because the program calculates very quickly and most modern controls have at least 1MB of RAM. However, short line moves, coupled with high feedrates, may result in a phenomenon known as data starving.

Data starving occurs when the control becomes so overwhelmed with data that it cannot keep up. CNC controls can only process a finite number of lines of code (blocks) per second. That can be as few as 40 blocks/second on older machines and 1,000 blocks/second or more on a newer machine like the Haas Automation control. Short line moves and high feedrates can force the processing rate beyond what the control can handle. When that happens, the machine must pause after each move and wait for the next servo command from the control.

Tolerance

The machining tolerance is the sum of the tolerances used for toolpath generation and geometry triangulation. Any additional filtering tolerances must be added to this tolerance to get the total tolerance.

Loose Tolerance .100

Tight Tolerance .001

How accurately the toolpath matches the desired shape depends largely on the number of lines used. More lines result in a toolpath that more closely approximates the nominal shape of the spline or surface.

When that happens, the machine must pause after each move and wait for the next servo command from the control.

Tolerance

The tolerance used when linearizing geometry such as splines and ellipses. The tolerance is taken as the maximum chord distance.

Loose Tolerance .100

Tight Tolerance .001

Confinement

Turning operations attempt to remove all the remaining stock possible with the selected operation type. The toolpath can be contained within a specific region using confinement boundaries.

Confinement enabled

Confinement disabled

Illustrated with Turning Profile

Confinement

Confinement regions can be defined with a combination of edges, surfaces, and/or sketch points as show below.

Resulting toolpath

Illustrated with Turning Groove

Multiple Finishing Passes

Enable to perform multiple finishing passes.

Multiple Finishing Passes

Enable to specify more than one finishing pass. If Finishing Passes is enabled, but Multiple Finishing Passes is disabled, then only one finishing pass is performed.

Multiple Finishing Passes ON

Multiple Finishing Passes OFF

Finishing Smoothing Deviation

The maximum amount of smoothing applied to the finishing passes. Use this parameter to avoid sharp corners in the toolpath. Setting this parameter leaves more stock than requested at the contour corners.

Roughing Passes

Can be used to take multiple cuts around the selected profile. This activates additional parameters for controlling the Stepover and Number of cuts.

Roughing Passes disabled

Roughing Passes enabled with
a 3mm Maximum Stepover

Roughing Passes

Enabling roughing passes provides you with the ability to fine tune your grooving toolpath. Options such as grooving stepover, pecking, and additional finishing controls become available; as well as additional settings within the Roughing Passes group.

Roughing Passes disabled

Roughing Passes enabled with a
1mm Maximum Grooving Stepover

Note: With Roughing Passes disabled, the stepover for both Full & Partial Stepdown is automatically calculated based on the groove width value of the insert.

Roughing Passes

Enabling roughing passes provides you with the ability to fine tune your grooving toolpath. Options such as grooving stepover, pecking, and additional finishing controls become available; as well as additional settings within the Roughing Passes group.

Roughing Passes disabled

Roughing Passes enabled with a
1mm Maximum Grooving Stepover

Note: With Roughing Passes disabled, the stepover for both Full & Partial Stepdown is automatically calculated based on the groove width value of the insert.

Roughing Clearing Pass

Specifies that cusps left by the initial roughing passes should be cleared. Enable this setting to avoid the tool loading up with a greater than expected amount of material during the final profile pass. This can become particularly relevant with some geometries when cusps are left on the groove wall.

Roughing Clearing Pass disabled

Roughing Clearing Pass enabled
with a 1mm Finishing Stepover

The red shaded area at the left represents the stock that would be removed by Roughing Clearing Pass once enabled.

Note: The clearing pass itself is applied in the Down direction only, irrespective of the Up/Down Direction setting.

Specifies the horizontal distance between passes.
