Geometry

Closed or open boundaries can be machined by selecting Edges or Sketches. The Slot shape can be straight, circular or contain multiple curves. But it must be a continuous width slot shape.

Slot shaped areas

Slot toolpaths

Note: The Slot toolpath will only cut a clearance channel thru the center. It is not an area clearance toolpath like 2D Pocket or 2D Adaptive.

Pocket Selections

Select closed or open boundaries with Edges or Sketches. The Slot shape can be straight, circular or contain multiple curves. But it must be a continuous width slot shape.

Slot shaped areas

Slot toolpaths

Note: The Slot toolpath will only cut a clearance channel thru the center. It is not an area clearance toolpath like 2D Pocket or 2D Adaptive.

Backoff Distance

The distance to move away from the last cut, before retracting the tool.

Distance 0.0 in

Distance .200in

Repeat Finishing Pass

Enable to perform an additional finishing pass with zero (0.0) stock.
Clears the stock left over from tool deflection.
Also refered to as a Spring Pass.

Disabled
Toolpath ends at last cut.

Enabled
Additional pass along the bottom.

Maximum Ramp Stepdown

Specifies the maximum stepdown per revolution on the ramping profile. Overrides the Angle by limiting the Z depth per pass.

Value of .750in
Ramp at the Angle until Z-.750 is reached.
Fewer passes - Heavier tool load.

Value of .250in
Ramp at the Angle until Z-.250 is reached.
More passes - Lighter tool load.

Note: This is important on long slots. This parameter allows the tool load to be constrained when doing full-width cuts during ramping.

Ramp Type

Specifies how the cutter moves down for each depth cut.

Predrill
Requires the location
of a predrilled hole.

Plunge
Plunges at the start location.

Profile
Follows the slot centerline
in a zig-zag motion.

Note: Predrill requires a point selection, shown below.

Geometry

Select the profile to be engraved using Edges or Sketches. Contiguous geometry is automatically chained. This toolpath requires a closed boundary.

Select any closed area

Contour Selections

Select the profile to be engraved using Edges or Sketches. Contiguous geometry is automatically chained. This toolpath requires a closed boundary.

Select any closed area

Sharp Corner Angle

Engrave creates sharp corners in the pocket by moving the cutter along the corner intersection. If the angle between edges is greater than this value, there will not be a corner clean out move.

Part angle is 165

Sharp Corner Angle set to 160
No corner is cut

Sharp Corner Angle set to 168
Corner is cut

Geometry

Select any 2D or 3D Edges or Sketches to define the machining curve. Select one or more curves for machining. This edge can be used for single line engraving, text or edge cleanup by using the Chamfer options.

Curve Selection

Select any 2D or 3D Edges or Sketches to define the machining curve. Select one or more curves for machining. This edge can be used for single line engraving, text or edge cleanup by using the Chamfer options.

Chamfer Width

The width of the chamfer.

For edges that are not already chamfered, this is the final width of the chamfer.

For chamfered edges, this is an additional offset; similar to using negative radial stock to leave.

Chamfer Width

Chamfer Width

The width of the chamfer.

For edges that are not already chamfered, this is the final width of the chamfer.

For chamfered edges, this is an additional offset; similar to using negative radial stock to leave.

Chamfer Width

Chamfer Edge

Select the sharp edges that require a chamfer.

Selected Edges to be machined are shown in blue

Chamfer Width

The axial distance across the chamfer.

The amount to break the selected edge. Shown below in the center illustration.

Chamfer Extension - Chamfer Width - Chamfer Angle

Chamfer Extension

The distance to extend the tool past the chamfer.

Provides additional clearance past the chamfer edge. Shown below in the left illustration.

Chamfer Extension - Chamfer Width - Chamfer Angle

Chamfer Angle

The angle of the chamfered face.

The angle is referenced from the Z axis. Shown below in the right illustration.

Chamfer Extension - Chamfer Width - Chamfer Angle

Chamfer Tip Offset

This is added to the toolpath depth, while keeping the tool in contact with the selected edge by adjusting the toolpath radial offset.

Chamfer Tip Offset
Tool Tip Clearance Extension

Note: Allows you to cut past the bottom of the Chamfer edge. Keeps you from cutting with the bottom tool edge.

Chamfer Clearance

This value specifies how far the tool needs to stay away from model geometry that is not being chamfered.

Chamfer Clearance
Collision Avoidance Distance

Note: Allows you to cut the Chamfer to a blended edge, while avoiding collisions with intersecting walls.

Pass Extension

Distance to extend the passes beyond the machining boundary.

Pass Extension

Extending the passes allows for the tool to move off the material between passes so that it is not constantly engaged. This helps reduce the load on the tool for better tool life.

Pass Direction Reference

Specifies the direction where passes should begin from.

If nothing is referenced, the tool orientation's X axis is used to reference the beginning direction for passes.

Pass Direction

Specifies the direction of the milling passes.

Pass Direction @ 0 degrees

Pass Direction @ 45 degrees

A common reason why you might want to change the pass direction is to achieve better efficiency. For example, a triangular face can get machined with fewer passes if the passes run along the direction of its longest edge, as opposed to running along an arbitrary direction.

Pass Direction

Specifies the direction of the turning passes.

Pass Direction @ 0 degrees

Pass Direction @ 30 degrees

Bottom

The maximum cutting depth.

Top

Specifies the top of the stock.

Optimal Load

The maximum amount of engagement the Adaptive toolpath should maintain.

This can be considered the stepover amount, but Adaptive High Speed Machining will vary the stepover to reduce overloading the tool.

High Speed Clearing Toolpath

Traditional pocket toolpaths can overload the tool. Adaptive Clearing results in 40% faster material removal, allowing you to take longer depth cuts with full confidence. High Speed Machining - HSM, Adaptive eliminates spikes in tool engagement that could break cutters.

No HSM
High Load

HSM Removal
Minimum Load

Load Deviation

The maximum deviation of the optimal tool load. The load is never higher than the optimal load plus the deviation.

Minimum Cutting Radius

Defines the smallest toolpath radius to generate in a sharp corner. Minimum Cutting Radius creates a blend at all inside sharp corners.

Forcing the tool into a sharp corner, or a corner where the radius is equal to the tool radius, can create chatter and distort the surface finish.

Set to Zero
The toolpath is forced into
all inside sharp corners

Set to 0.07 in
The toolpath will have a blend
of .070 radius in all sharp corners.

Note: Setting this parameter leaves more material in internal corners, requiring subsequent rest machining operations with a smaller tool.

Fine Stepdown

Specifies the fine step for intermediate smoothing cuts. These steps are upwards in the direction of the tool axis.

Fine Step Increment

Fine Steps
Along the profile

These fine cuts smooth out the larger rough steps, by taking multiple smaller steps around the model profile.

Round Walls

Enable to round the extruded walls.

Machine Cavities

If enabled, the strategy ramps into pockets and machines these.

If disabled, the strategy only machines from the outside-in and leaves pockets unmachined.

Manual Stepover

Enable to set the stepover manually.

Minimum Stepover

Specifies the minimum stepover.

Prevent Full-Width Cuts

Specifies that full-width cuts should be avoided.

Maximum Tool Engagement

Specifies the maximum tool engagement for full-width cuts.

Maximum Trochoidal Radius

Specifies the maximum trochoidal radius.

Machine Shallow Areas

Specifies that extra Z-level passes should be taken in shallow areas to remove excessive cusps.

Disabled

Enabled

Illustrated with 3D Contour

Minimum Shallow Stepdown

This parameter controls the minimum allowed stepdown between the extra Z-levels. It takes precedence over the Maximum Shallow Stepover.

Maximum Shallow Stepover

This parameter controls the stepover used to detect areas where extra Z-levels should be inserted. If the normal stepdown results in a stepover of more than this value, extra levels are inserted until the stepover or the minimum stepdown is reached.

Flat Area Detection

If enabled, the strategy attempts to detect the heights of flat areas and peaks, and machine at these levels.

If disabled, the strategy machines at exactly the specified stepdowns.

Important: Enabling this feature may increase calculation time considerably.

Minimum Stepdown

Used when detecting flat areas. This is the smallest allowable stepdown to make.

Axial Offset Passes

Enable to do multiple depth cuts.

Axial offset passes are used to create multiple incremental Z passes. They work much like multiple finishing stepdowns in the 2D operations. They are useful for removing a fixed amount of stock using several passes.

4 cuts of .010 in

Three Axial Offset Passes
on multiple chains

Number Of Stepdowns

Specifies the desired number of stepdowns.

Overthickness

Additional thickness which is applied to the tool to detect passes.

The amount between the actual part radius and the actual tool radius.

Bitangency Angle

An angle in degrees, that is used to determine the number of passes along a wall or fold.

An angle representing the contact points for the tool.

Cutter paths are created along all the contact areas where it would make two simultaneous contacts with the part, at more than this angular difference.

Limit Number Of Stepovers

When disabled, the number of steps is unlimited and the result is a collapsed pencil finish of the entire surface.

Calculate Number Of Stepovers

When disabled, you can specify the number of steps and distance per step.
When enabled, the stepover and amount of stock, determines the number of cuts.

Use Reduced Feedrate

Enabled to reduce the feedrate before the final cut position.

Disabled
No Feed Change

Enabled
Feed change position

Reduced Feed Radius

Sets the radius before the final cut position where the feedrate will change.

Lowering the feedrate before the end of the cut reduces the load on the tool.

Feed change radius position

Reduced Feed

Sets the new feedrate to apply at the Feed Radius position.

Lowering the feedrate before the end of the cut reduces the load on the tool.

Feed change position

Reduced Spindle Speed

Sets the new spindle speed to apply at the Feed Radius position.

Changing the spindle speed before the end of the cut can change the load on the tool.

Speed change position

Reduced Feed

Sets the new feedrate to apply at the Feed Radius position.

Lowering the feedrate before the end of the cut reduces the load on the tool.

Feed change position

Inside/Outside Direction

Specifies if the toolpath moves inside-out or outside-in. The Shortest machining distance option uses a mixture of the ordering to achieve the shortest machining distance.

Outside -> in

Inside -> out

Link From Inside To Outside

Enable to specify whether the linking between passes should be done without particular ordering or linking should be done by ordering from inside passes to outside passes.

Angular Step

The angular step in degrees between radial passes.

Angle From

The Radial starting angle in degrees measured from the X axis as viewed from the WCS.

From Angle

Angle To

The Radial ending angle in degrees measured from the X axis as viewed from the WCS.

To Angle

Inner Limit

Sets the minimum inner radius.

No inner Radius

Inner Radius

Illustrated with 3D Spiral

Outer Limit

Sets the maximum outer radius. To cover the entire model, enter a radius equal to or greater than the model radius.

Images illustrated with the 3D Spiral toolpath:

Outer Radius = 1 in
Model Radius = 2 in

Outer Radius = 3 in
Model Radius = 2 in

Manual Center

The center of the radial passes.

Clockwise

Specifies that the spiral is clockwise.

Wrap Toolpath

Wraps the toolpath around a cylinder to machine enclosed cylindrical surfaces. Useful for machining areas that are unreachable with 3-axis machining.

Set the WCS (Work Coordinate System) to correspond to the rotary axis on your machine tool. For example, if the machine has an A rotary axis, then the X axis of the WCS needs to run along the part in the setup. The resulting toolpath can be output using axis substitution around a rotary axis, which means machining with the X, A, and Z axes (with the A axis replacing the Y axis), or can be output as full multi-axis moves.

Note: Requires a machine that has 4-axis capability.

Wrap Radius Offset

Offsets the wrap radius value. Offsetting this value controls how much material is removed from the edge of the walls. Commonly used when the walls of the crylindrical pocket are not modeled accurately for wrap machining.

When performing the wrapping, the toolpath can only be accurate at one radius, the Wrap Radius, which defaults to the radius of the selected wrap cylinder.

An offset value of 0 uses the radius from the selected wrap cylinder. In the image below, the cylindrical surface at the bottom of the tool is selected. As a result, the tool stops at the end of the bottom edge.

In the image below, the wrap radius is offset by an inch. As a result, the tool moves further into the wall.

Wrap Radius

When performing the wrapping, the toolpath can only be accurate at one radius, which is the wrap radius.

Any wall below this radius will be overcut, and any wall above this radius will be undercut.

Wrap Cylinder

Select a cylindrical surface that matches the geometry you want to generate the toolpath on.

Generally, this provides an accurate toolpath if the walls of the cylindrical pocket align with the edge of the tool.

If the walls of the pocket do not align with the tool, you can choose a different wrap cylinder, or adjust the Offset value to get the desired cut.

If you are using axis substitution, the surface selection needs to be along the rotary axis of your machine. For multi-axis machining, the surface can be along any axis as long as the resulting toolpath positions are reachable by the machine.

Note: The surface selection cannot be a cone or an irregular surface.

Tool Orientation

Overrides the tool orientation defined in the setup.

Works with all 2D and 3D operations to control 3 + 2 Axis programming.

Selected

Deselected

Tool Orientation Selection

Specifies how the tool orientation is specified.

  • Use WCS is the default, and uses the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) of the current job for the tool orientation.
  • Use Point & Plane sets a specific tool orientation for this operation from any selected point and plane as the origin and orientation, respectively.
  • Use Coordinate System sets a specific tool orientation for this operation from any coordinate system feature in the model. This uses both the origin and orientation of the coordinate system feature. Use this if your model does not contain a suitable point & plane for your operation.

Origin

Select any point or vertex as the origin of the tool orientation.

Orientation

Select any face, sketch, or plane as the orientation of the tool orientation.

Override Setup WCS

Specifies that the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) should be different from the WCS given for the setup.

Tool Orientation Selection

Specifies how the workpiece coordinate system is specified.

Origin & Orientation

Coordinate System

Stock & Orientation

Use Origin & Orientation - A sketch point or stock vertex is used to define the location of the WCS, and a plane or planar face is used to define the orientation of the WCS.

Use Coordinate System - An existing user coordinate system (UCS) is used to define both the location and orientation of the WCS.

Use Stock & Orientation - A location on the stock (Example: Top Center) is used to define the location of the WCS, and a plane or planar face is used to define the orientation of the WCS.

Model

Select to include in the toolpath calculation other bodies, faces, or surfaces, in addition to the geometry defined in the setup. Alternatively, you can override the model geometry defined in the setup and instead machine other bodies, faces, or surfaces.

A typical use of this option is to include capping surfaces that stop the milling tool from going into holes that will be manufactured by drilling operations later in the setup.

Model surfaces

Specifies the bodies, faces, or surfaces that are not already identified in the current setup that should be included in the toolpath calculation.

Include setup model

When selected, the model geometry identified in the setup is included in the toolpath calculation. When deselected, the model geometry identified in the setup is excluded from the toolpath calculation.

Avoid/Touch Surfaces

Specifies surfaces to avoid. When enabled, toolpaths stay away from the selected surfaces by a specified amount.

Disabled

Enabled

Touch Surfaces

Note: Touch Surfaces inverts the meaning of the Avoid surfaces setting. When enabled, the avoid surfaces are the ones that must be touched within the given clearance while the remaining surfaces are avoided.

Avoid/Touch Surfaces

Select the surfaces to avoid. Toolpaths stay away from the selected surfaces by the Surface Amount.

No Selection

Domes Selected

Base Surface Selected

Note: Touch Surfaces inverts the meaning of the Avoid Surfaces selection. When enabled, the avoid surfaces are the ones that must be touched within the given clearance while the remaining surfaces are avoided.

Avoid/Touch Surface Clearance

Clearance distance from the selected surfaces.

Up/Down Milling

Use this option to break each pass into segments so that each piece is machined using either downward or upward moves only. This is useful when using insert cutters that are restricted to a specific cutting direction.

Both

Down Milling

Machining Boundary

Boundaries mode specifies how the toolpath boundary is defined.

Example 1

Example 2

Illustrated using a 3D Radial toolpath

Containment modes:

Bounding box

Silhouette

Selection

None - The toolpaths machine all stock without limitation. Where possible, the tool leads in from outside of the part to avoid ramping or plunging into stock.

Bounding box - Contains toolpaths within a box defined by the maximum extents of the part as viewed from the WCS.

Silhouette - Contains toolpaths within a boundary defined by the part shadow as viewed from the WCS.

Selection - Contains toolpaths within a region specified by a selected boundary.

Note: Not all options are available for all machining strategies.

Tool Containment

Use tool containment to control the tools' position in relation to the selected boundary or boundaries.

Tool inside boundary

The entire tool stays inside the boundary. As a result, the entire surface contained by the boundary might not be machined.

Tool center on boundary

The boundary limits the center of the tool. This setting ensures that the entire surface inside the boundary is machined. However, areas outside the boundary or boundaries might also be machined.

Tool outside boundary

The toolpath is created inside the boundary, but the tool edge can move on the outside edge of the boundary.

Inside

Center

Outside

To offset the boundary containment, use the Additional Offset parameter.

Contact Point Boundary

When enabled, extends the Machining boundary limits of the cut position to where the tool touches the part, rather than the tools center position. In the illustration below the red line indicates the machining boundary edge selection, as viewed thru the tool plane. The blue line indicates the tool contact point.

Disabled
Center point determines the end of the cut.

Enabled
Contact point determines the end of the cut.

Can be used to restrict roll over on the top edge of a cut. The difference is illustrated below on a Parallel toolpath.

Disabled

Enabled

Slope

Contains toolpaths based on a range of specified angles.

0 deg - 90 deg

0 deg - 45 deg

45 deg - 90 deg

Slope angle confinement is specified by the From Slope and To Slope Angle parameters on the Geometry tab. Angles are defined from 0 deg (horizontal) to 90 deg (vertical).

Only areas equal to or greater than the values in the From Slope and To Slope areas are machined.

Most 3D finishing strategies supports slope angle confinement. One use of slope confinement is to confine a selected toolpath strategy to angles where it works best. For example, Parallel Finish is better suited to shallow areas while Contour Finish is better suited to steep areas.

From Slope Angle

From Slope angle is defined from the 0 deg (horizontal) plane. Only areas equal to or greater than this value are machined.

Slope Angle From 0 deg

To Slope Angle

To Slope angle is defined from the 0 deg (horizontal) plane. Only areas equal to or less than this value are machined.

Slope Angle To 90 deg

Contact Only

Controls whether or not toolpaths are generated where the tool is not in contact with the machining surface. When disabled, toolpaths are extended to the limits of the containment boundary and across openings in the workpiece.

Enabled

Disabled

Safe Distance

Sets the minimum distance between the tool and the part's surfaces during retract moves. Within this distance, the tool retracts with a direct move, instead of a rapid move.

To retract the tool from the part with a rapid move, reduce the Safe Distance value. The distance is measured after stock to leave is applied. If a negative stock to leave is used, make sure that safe distance is large enough to prevent any collisions.

Retraction Policy

Controls how the tool moves between cutting passes.

Full Retraction

Minimum Retraction

Shortest Path

Illustrated with Flow


Full retraction - Completely retracts the tool to the Retract Height at the end of the pass before moving above the start of the next pass.

Minimum retraction - Moves straight up to the lowest height where the tool clears the workpiece, plus any specified safe distance.

Shortest path - Moves the tool the shortest possible distance in a straight line between paths.

WARNING: Shortest path should not be used on machines that do not support linearized rapid movements where G0 moves are straight-line (versus G0 moves that drive all axes at maximum speed, sometimes referred to as "dogleg" moves). Failure to obey this rule will result in machine motion that cannot be properly simulated by the software, and may result in tool crashes.

For CNC machines that do not support linearized rapid moves, the post processor can be modified to convert all G0 moves to high-feed G1 moves. Contact technical support for more information or instructions on how to modify post processors as described.

Retraction Policy

Controls whether the tool should retract to the clearance diameter after every cutting pass, or just retract a short distance away from the job. The distance is determined by the Safe Distance value.

Full Retraction

Minimum Retraction

Set Minimum Profile Diameter

This allows a minimum profile diameter to be set. If a machining area is smaller than the specified minimum profile diameter, then it is not machined.

Minimum Profile Diameter

Specifies the minimum cavity to be cut.

Direction

Specifies the way the machining is done.

  • Climb milling
  • Conventional milling

Allow Rapid Retract

When enabled, retracts are done as rapid movements (G0). Disable to force retracts at lead-out feedrate.

Keep Tool Down

When enabled, the strategy avoids retracting when the distance to the next area is below the specified stay-down distance.

Keep Tool Down

These options can be used to avoid retracts and to avoid previously cut areas.

The Head avoids previously cut areas

Note: When a profile is cut, it is possible for the remaining slug to tilt up. If you force the head to stay down, it is possible for this slug to damage the head of the machine. With the parameters below, you can keep the head down, but set a condition where the rapid motion will avoid any place a contour has already been cut.

Maximum Stay-Down Distance

Many toolpaths will make a cut and reposition for the next cut. If the distance between positions is greater than the Maximum Stay Down value, the tool will retract between cuts. To keep the tool down between cuts, set this value greater than the longest reposition distance.

In the part shown the widest point is 1.8".

1" Maximum stay-down
the tool retracts

2" Maximum stay-down
the tool stays down

Illustrated with 2D Adaptive Clearing

Note: Regardless of the stay-down distance, the tool retracts between passes if the rapid motion violates the workpiece.

Maximum Stay-Down Distance

The distance where retracts are no longer required.

The distance between cuts is Less than 4."
The Head stays down at the Top Height.

The distance between cuts is Greater than 4."
The Head retracts to the Clearance Height.

A smaller distance will cause the head to retract to the Clearance plane. A larger value allows you to stay down at the Top Height.

Note: In the first example, you can see how the rapid movement avoids any previously cut profiles. Smaller parts can tilt, which might cause a collision with the head. Moving around previously cut profiles eliminates the possibility of a crash.

Minimum Stay-Down Clearance

Cut part edge clearance for rapid moves.

Rapid edge clearance distance of .040"

Rapid edge clearance distance of .200"

When the Head stays down at the Top Height, this clearance avoids profiles that have been cut. It is an XY clearance to the closest edge, when making a rapid move between cuts.

Both Ways

When enabled, passes are done in both directions. Disable to force climb-only machining.

Lead-In (Entry)

Enable to generate a lead-in.

Lead-In

Lead-In (Entry)

Enables a contour blend.

Lead-In

The Lead In/Out move allows you to blend onto the part profile.
Without this type of blend you could leave a mark at the starting point.

Lead-In (Entry)

Controls how the tool enters the cutting path. The radius, distance, and angle can be specified.

Linear Lead-In Length

Leads & Transitions

Controls how the tool should blend on to and off of the cut.

Linear and radial Lead-In
shown in green

Perpendicular

Replaces tangential extensions of lead-in/lead-out arcs with a move perpendicular to the arc.

Shown with Perpendicular Entry/Exit

Example A bore that has lead arcs that are as large as possible (the larger the arc the less chance of dwell mark), and where a tangent linear lead is not possible because it would extend into the side of the bore.

Vertical Lead-In Radius

The radius of the vertical arc smoothing the entry move as it goes from the entry move to the toolpath itself.

Vertical Lead-In Radius

Vertical Lead-In/Out Radius

Creates an arc in the vertical plane for blending down onto the part. The radius for vertical lead moves.

Lead-Out (Exit)

Enables a contour blend.

Controls how the tool exits the cutting path. The radius, distance, and angle can be specified.

Retract Distance

Controls the lead out move after each roughing cut. Shown below in green.

2mm Retract Distance

6mm Retract Distance

Perpendicular

Replaces tangential extensions of lead-in/lead-out arcs with a move perpendicular to the arc.

Shown with Perpendicular entry/exit

Example A bore that has lead arcs that are as large as possible (the larger the arc the less chance of dwell mark), and where a tangent linear lead is not possible because it would extend into the side of the bore.

Vertical Lead-Out Radius

Specifies the radius of the vertical lead-out.

Vertical Lead-Out Radius

Transition Type

Specifies the type of connection done between passes.

  • No contact - Sidesteps are not connected with each other on the same Z-level, but connected with a retract move.
  • Straight line - Simpler, direct connections using straight lines.
  • Shortest path - The shortest possible path between machining areas - typically a move in a straight line.
  • Smooth - Use smooth tangential movements using true arcs where appropriate.

Ramp

Enable ramps.

Shown with a 15 degree Ramp angle

Ramp Type

Specifies how the cutter moves down for each depth cut.

Plunge Outside Stock

Predrill

Plunge

To use the Predrill option, Predrill location(s) must be defined.

Zig-Zag

Profile

Notice the smooth transitions on the Zig-Zag ramp type.

Smooth Profile

Helix

Use Ramping Angle

Uses the slope angle of a helix instead of Pitch, to control the feed depth.

Pitch uses a distance per revolution depth control.

Angle controls how the tool slopes into the part.

Shown with Pitch distance

Shown with 2 Deg. Ramp

Angle

Controls the angle of the helix that leads into the cavity.

Shown with 2 Deg. Ramp

Ramping Angle (deg)

Controls the angle of the helix that leads into the cavity.

Shown with 2 Deg. Ramp

Ramp Taper Angle (deg)

Creates a cone shape entry cavity, to reduce tool load. Specified as an included angle.

Controls the starting and ending diameter of the helix that leads into the cavity.

Shown with 12 Deg. Taper

Maximum Ramp Stepdown

Specifies the maximum stepdown per revolution on the ramping profile. This parameter allows the tool load to be constrained when doing full-width cuts during ramping.

Ramp Clearance Height

Clearance above the Top Height, where the Helix Ramp will start.

Clearance to start the Helix

Helical Ramp Diameter

The maximum diameter to use for a helical entry into the cavity.

An optimal value causes the tool to overlap its center, while still creating the maximum helical bore for the entry into the cavity. The goal is for good chip evacuation. If the value is bigger than the diameter of the tool it can leave a boss standing in the center of the helix.

Value of 1.8 x the Dia.

Value of 0.8 x the Dia.

The system will determine the best location for the entry helix, unless and Entry Position is selected. (Entry Positions shown below). The complete area will always be cleared, regardless of the diameter. Note: The area width should be Tool Dia + Ramp Dia + Stock, or the helical entry will fail.

Minimum Ramp Diameter

The smallest Helix Ramp Diameter that is acceptable.

This value should always be smaller than the Helix Ramp Diameter, so the system can calculate a range that fits the available pocket or channel. Smaller diameters can reduce the chip evacuation, create jerking machine motion and can cause tool breakage.

Helical Ramp 0.100in - Min. Ramp 0.060in

Force Profile Ramp

Enable this to force a profile ramp on top of the selected contour(s).

Use this when cutting out holes, for example.

Positions

Specify the tool entry point(s).

Predrill Positions

Select points where holes have been drilled to provide clearance for the cutter to enter the material.

Predrill Location
Select the location of a predrilled hole.

Predrill Plunge Start
Toolpath starts from the hole.

Entry Positions

Helps determine the positions where the tool should lead-in, which is the move before the beginning of a cutting move.

Select points on the model to determine the lead-in positions. You can select one position or multiple positions. If you select multiple positions, the position that is the closest to a contour gets used as the approximate lead-in position.

Position 1 - Used by one contour
Position 2 - Used by multiple contours

Note: The positions you specify are approximate and may not always be the location where the tool leads in.

Exit Positions

Determines the exit position of the tool for safer machining.

Select a point to determine the exit position. The point must be as close as possible to the area you are machining, like the entrance of an open pocket for example, for the point to be detected during toolpath calculation.

If you select more than one point, the tool exits from the point that it is closest to after it has completed performing the cutting moves.

In the example below, an open pocket with an undercut is being machined. Initially, the tool retracts at the end of the pocket, which causes a collision with the geometry directly above it. Using an exit position, you can force the tool to stay down and exit the pocket so it can retract with sufficient clearance.

Machining an undercut

Tool retracts at end
Collision with part

Retract at Exit Position
Sufficient clearance

Available for 2D Pocket, 2D Contour, and 2D Adaptive.

Note: The tool performs a stay-down link move when moving to an exit position. The Maximum Stay-Down Distance must be large enough to accommodate for this move. for 2D Pocket and 2D Contour, you need to enable the Keep Tool Down check box to enter a Maximum Stay-Down Distance.

Trim Passes

Enable this to allow the passes to be trimmed back to fit the leads, where otherwise not possible, to allow the CNC machining to maintain a high feed. If disabled, forces the entire pass to be machined. This can result in sharp moves and the minimum corner radius may not be respected.

Manual Ramp Diameter

If checked, the minimum ramp diameter can be set.

Contact Ramp Angle

The maximum angle of contact ramps.

Smooth Contact Ramp

Specifies that the contact ramp should be smooth.

Remove Spikes

Enable to remove spikes in the toolpath.

Maximum Spike Angle

Specifies the angle of the passes which triggers a spike.

Smoothing Filter

Smooths the toolpath by removing excessive points and fitting arcs where possible within the given filtering tolerance.

Smoothing Off

Smoothing On

Smoothing is used to reduce code size without sacrificing accuracy. Smoothing works by replacing collinear lines with one line and tangent arcs to replace multiple lines in curved areas.

The effects of smoothing can be dramatic. G-code file size may be reduced by as much as 50% or more. The machine will run faster and more smoothly and surface finish improves. The amount of code reduction depends on how well the toolpath lends itself to smoothing. Toolpaths that lay primarily in a major plane (XY, XZ, YZ), like parallel paths, filter well. Those that do not, such as 3D Scallop, are reduced less.

Smoothing Tolerance

Specifies the smoothing tolerance.

Smoothing works best when the tolerance (the accuracy with which the original linearized path is generated) is equal to or greater than the Smoothing (line arc fitting) tolerance.

Note: Total tolerance, or the distance the toolpath can stray from the ideal spline or surface shape, is the sum of the cut Tolerance and Smoothing Tolerance. For example, setting a cut Tolerance of .0004 in. and Smoothing Tolerance of .0004 in. means the toolpath can vary from the original spline or surface by as much as .0008 in. from the ideal path.

High Feedrate Mode

Specifies when rapid movements should be output as true rapids (G0) and when they should be output as high feedrate movements (G1).

  • Preserve rapid movement - All rapid movements are preserved.
  • Preserve axial and radial rapid movement - Rapid movements moving only horizontally (radial) or vertically (axial) are output as true rapids.
  • Preserve axial rapid movement - Only rapid movements moving vertically.
  • Preserve radial rapid movement - Only rapid movements moving horizontally.
  • Preserve single axis rapid movement - Only rapid movements moving in one axis (X, Y or Z).
  • Always use high feed - Outputs rapid movements as (high feed moves) G01 moves instead of rapid movements (G0).

This parameter is usually set to avoid collisions at rapids on machines which perform "dogleg" movements at rapid.

High Feedrate

The feedrate to use for rapids movements output as G1 instead of G0.

Rest Machining

Limits the operation to only remove material that a previous tool or operation could not remove.

Rest stands for REmaining STock.

Area to machine.
Pocket shown in green.

Previous Operation.
Not all stock is removed.

With a smaller tool you can machine the entire pocket, or use Rest Machining to clear the remaining stock.

Use Rest Machining OFF.
All areas are machined.

Use Rest Machining ON.
Previously uncut areas are machined.

Requires additional information about the tool previously used to cut the boundary.

Rest Machining

Specifies that only stock left after previous operations should be machined.

Disabled

Enabled

Rest Machining

Limits the operation to only remove material that a previous tool or operation could not remove.

Rest stands for REmaining STock.

Area to machine.
Pocket shown in green.

Previous Operation.
Not all stock is removed.

With a smaller tool you can machine the entire pocket, or use Rest Machining to clear the remaining stock.

Use Rest Machining OFF.
All areas are machined.

Use Rest Machining ON.
Previously uncut areas are machined.

Requires additional information about the tool previously used to cut the boundary.

Rest Material Source

Specifies how to identify the unmachined regions of a part where there is still stock material to remove. The resulting toolpath targets only unmachined regions.

  • From previous operation(s) - Uses all toolpaths in the current setup to identify remaining unmachined regions.
  • From tool - Lets you define a tool and then identifies regions that are unreachable by the defined tool.
  • From file - Lets you specify a binary STL file that represents unmachined regions.
  • From solid(s) - Lets you specify solid bodies that represent unmachined regions.
  • From setup stock - Uses the stock defined in the setup to represent unmachined regions.

Rest Material Source

Specifies how to identify the unmachined regions of a part where there is still stock material to remove. The resulting toolpath targets only unmachined regions.

  • From previous operation(s) - Takes into account the stock removed by previous operations and machines what is remaining.
  • From bodies - Lets you specify solid bodies that represent unmachined regions.
  • From setup stock - Uses the stock defined in the setup to represent unmachined regions.

Rest Material Operation

Rest material operation.

Union Of All Dependent Operations

Union of all dependent operations.

Include All Previous Operations

Include all previous operations.

Rest Material Resolution

Specifies the rest material resolution.

Rest Material Tool Diameter

Specify the diameter of the tool previously used to cut the boundary.

Any areas not cut by this tool will be machined.

Rest Material Tool Corner Radius

Specify the corner radius of the tool previously used to cut the boundary.

Any areas not cut by this tool will be machined.

Rest Material Stock To Leave

Specifies the rest material stock to leave.

Rest Material Adjustment

Adjusts the toolpath to either include or exclude cusps, which are small amounts of unmachined material.

  • Use as computed - Uses the toolpath as computed without making any adjustments if no Adjustment Offset value is specified.
  • Ignore cusps - Ensures that small amounts of unmachined material are not included in the toolpath. Useful when there is negligible benefit in machining the small cusps when considering the added machining time. Used in combination with an Adjustment Offset value.
  • Machine cusps - Ensures that small amounts of unmachined material are included in the toolpath. Used in combination with an Adjustment Offset value.

Rest Material Adjustment Offset

Specifies the thickness of the unmachined material to be machined or ignored, depending on the Adjustment option selected.

With Machine Cusps selected, the Adjustment Offset is the minimum thickness of unmachined material that gets included in the toolpath.

With Ignore Cusps selected, the Adjustment Offset is the maximum thickness of unmachined material that gets ignored by the toolpath.

With Use as Computed selected, the Adjustment Offset works the same way as Machine Cusps when a positive value is entered, or the same way as Ignore Cusps when a negative value is entered.

Reduce Air Cutting

Reduces the amount of air cutting in the toolpath, which can often reduce machining time significantly. This applies only to scenarios where there is air underneath the stock to be machined, as shown by the illustration below:

When deselected, the edge of the stock is not detected, and excess air-cutting moves are generated.

When selected, the edge of the stock is detected, and fewer cutting moves are generated.

Deselected
Excess cutting moves

Selected
Reduced air cutting

Important: Enabling this feature can increase the calculation time considerably.

Clearance Height

This parameter specifies the clearance plane.

Clearance Height

Specifies the first height that the tool moves to on its way to the start of the toolpath.

Clearance Height
  • Retract Height: Incremental offset from the Retract Height.
  • Feed Height: Incremental offset from the Feed Height.
  • Top Height: Incremental offset from the Top Height.
  • Bottom Height: Incremental offset from the Bottom Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Bottom.
  • Stock Top: Incremental offset from the Stock Top.
  • Stock Bottom: Incremental offset from the Stock Bottom.
  • Selected Contour(s): Incremental offset from a contour selected on the model.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.

Clearance Height

Specifies the first height that the tool moves to on its way to the start of the toolpath.

Clearance Height
  • Retract Height: Incremental offset from the Retract Height.
  • Feed Height: Incremental offset from the Feed Height.
  • Top Height: Incremental offset from the Top Height.
  • Bottom Height: Incremental offset from the Bottom Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Bottom.
  • Stock Top: Incremental offset from the Stock Top.
  • Stock Bottom: Incremental offset from the Stock Bottom.
  • Selected Contour(s): Incremental offset from a contour selected on the model.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.

Clearance Height

Specifies the first height that the head moves to on its way to the start of the toolpath.

Clearance Height
  • Retract Height: Incremental offset from the Retract Height.
  • Top Height: Incremental offset from the Top Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Bottom.
  • Stock Top: Incremental offset from the Stock Top.
  • Stock Bottom: Incremental offset from the Stock Bottom.
  • Selected Contour(s): Incremental offset from a contour selected on the model.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.

Clearance height reference

Specifies the selected point, edge, or face on the model from which the Clearance Height is offset.

Clearance Height Offset

Adjusts the relative position of the height.

Enter a value or click and drag the height in the canvas.

Retract Height

This parameter specifies the retract plane.

Retract Height

Retract height sets the height that the tool moves up to before the next cutting pass. Retract height should be set above the Feed Height and Top. Retract height is used together with the subsequent offset to establish the height.

Retract Height
  • Clearance Height: Incremental offset from the Clearance Height
  • Feed Height: Incremental offset from the Feed Height
  • Top Height: Incremental offset from the Top Height.
  • Bottom Height: Incremental offset from the Bottom Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Stock Top: Incremental offset from the Stock Top.
  • Stock Bottom: Incremental offset from the Stock Bottom.
  • Selected Contour(s): Incremental offset from a contour selected on the model.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.

Retract Height

Retract height sets the height that the tool moves up to before the next cutting pass. Retract height should be set above the Feed Height and Top. Retract height is used together with the subsequent offset to establish the height.

Retract Height
  • Clearance Height: Incremental offset from the Clearance Height
  • Top Height: Incremental offset from the Top Height.
  • Bottom Height: Incremental offset from the Bottom Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Stock Top: Incremental offset from the Stock Top.
  • Stock Bottom: Incremental offset from the Stock Bottom.
  • Selected Contour(s): Incremental offset from a contour selected on the model.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.

Retract Height

Retract height sets the height that the head moves up to before the next cutting pass. Retract height should be set above the Top. Retract height is used together with the subsequent offset to establish the height.

Retract Height
  • Clearance Height: Incremental offset from the Clearance Height
  • Top Height: Incremental offset from the Top Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Stock Top: Incremental offset from the Stock Top.
  • Stock Bottom: Incremental offset from the Stock Bottom.
  • Selected Contour(s): Incremental offset from a contour selected on the model.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.

Retract height reference

Specifies the selected point, edge, or face on the model from which the Retract Height is offset.

Retract Height Offset

Adjusts the relative position of the height.

Enter a value or click and drag the height in the canvas.

Feed Height

This parameter specifies the feed plane.

Feed Height

Specifies the height that the tool moves to before changing to the feed/plunge rate to enter the part. The Feed Height should be set above the Top. A drilling operation uses this height as the initial Feed Height and the retract peck height. Feed Height is used together with the subsequent offset to establish the height.

Feed Height
  • Clearance Height: Incremental offset from the Clearance height
  • Retract Height: Incremental offset from the Retract Height.
  • Disabled: disabling the Feed Height causes the tool to rapid down to the lead-in.
  • Top Height: Incremental offset from the Top Height.
  • Bottom Height: Incremental offset from the Bottom Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Bottom.
  • Stock Top: Incremental offset from the Stock Top.
  • Stock Bottom: Incremental offset from the Stock Bottom.
  • Selected Contour(s): Incremental offset from a contour selected on the model.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.

Feed Height Reference

Feed Height Offset

Feed height offset is applied and is relative to the Feed height selection in the above drop-down list.

Top Height

Specifies the top of the stock.

Top Height

Top height sets the height that describes the top of the cut. Top height should be set above the Bottom. Top height is used together with the subsequent offset to establish the height.

Top Height
  • Clearance Height: Incremental offset from the Clearance Height
  • Retract Height: Incremental offset from the Retract Height.
  • Feed Height: Incremental offset from the Feed Height.
  • Bottom Height: Incremental offset from the Bottom Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Stock Top: Incremental offset from the Stock Top.
  • Stock Bottom: Incremental offset from the Stock Bottom.
  • Selected Contour(s): Incremental offset from a contour selected on the model.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.

Top Height

Top height sets the height that describes the top of the cut. Top height should be set above the Bottom. Top height is used together with the subsequent offset to establish the height.

Top Height
  • Clearance Height: Incremental offset from the Clearance Height
  • Retract Height: Incremental offset from the Retract Height.
  • Feed Height: Incremental offset from the Feed Height.
  • Bottom Height: Incremental offset from the Bottom Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Stock Top: Incremental offset from the Stock Top.
  • Stock Bottom: Incremental offset from the Stock Bottom.
  • Selected Contour(s): Incremental offset from a contour selected on the model.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.

Top Height

Top height sets the height that describes the top of the part. Top height is used together with the subsequent offset to establish the height.

Top Height
  • Clearance Height: Incremental offset from the Clearance Height
  • Retract Height: Incremental offset from the Retract Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Stock Top: Incremental offset from the Stock Top.
  • Stock Bottom: Incremental offset from the Stock Bottom.
  • Selected Contour(s): Incremental offset from a contour selected on the model.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.

Top Reference

Top Offset

Top offset is applied and is relative to the Top height selection in the above drop-down list.

Bottom

The maximum cutting depth.

Bottom Height

Bottom height determines the final machining height/depth and the lowest depth that the tool descends into the stock. Bottom height needs to be set below the Top. Bottom height is used together with the subsequent offset to establish the height.

Bottom Height
  • Clearance Height: Incremental offset from the Clearance Height
  • Retract Height: Incremental offset from the Retract Height.
  • Feed Height: Incremental offset from the Feed Height.
  • Top Height: Incremental offset from the Top Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Stock Top: Incremental offset from the Stock Top.
  • Stock Bottom: Incremental offset from the Stock Bottom.
  • Selected Contour(s): Incremental offset from a contour selected on the model.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.
  • To Chamfer Width: Allows the tool to drill just enough to make the chamfer width match the input parameter. The input parameter should not exceed the tool's chamfer width. The calculated height offset is dependent on the tool's parameters (diameter, tip diameter, and tip angle) and on the diameter of the hole. Acceptable selections include cylindrical faces, circles, or arcs.
  • To Chamfer Diameter: The diameter of the new hole is equal to the input parameter. Therefore, the input parameter should not exceed the tool's diameter. The calculated height offset is dependent on the tool's parameters and independent of the hole selection. Acceptable selections include cylindrical faces, circles, or arcs.

Bottom Height

Bottom height determines the final machining height/depth and the lowest depth that the tool descends into the stock. Bottom height needs to be set below the Top. Bottom height is used together with the subsequent offset to establish the height.

Bottom Height
  • Clearance Height: Incremental offset from the Clearance Height
  • Retract Height: Incremental offset from the Retract Height.
  • Feed Height: Incremental offset from the Feed Height.
  • Top Height: Incremental offset from the Top Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Stock Top: Incremental offset from the Stock Top.
  • Stock Bottom: Incremental offset from the Stock Bottom.
  • Selected Contour(s): Incremental offset from a contour selected on the model.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.

Bottom Reference

Specifies the selected point, edge, or face on the model from which the Bottom Height is offset.

Bottom Offset

Adjusts the relative position of the height.

Enter a value or click and drag the height in the canvas.

Probe Geometry Selections

Specifies what geometry is to be probed and which probing cycle to use.

Probe Mode

Lets you choose between selecting faces from the part model or the stock. Selection options change based on your choice.

Cylinder Face Selection

Probe Stock Surface(s)

Defines the faces to be probed.

In the canvas, select one of more faces on the stock. The selected faces determine the available Probe Type options. To select faces on the model, change the Probe Mode to Model.

Defines the faces to be probed.
