Use Selection Point

Forces probing at the actual point picked on the selected surface.

Arrow shows probing location
on the selected surface.

Spacing

Sets the probe spacing between points on the selected surface.

To change the spacing, in the canvas, click and drag the green arrows.

Angle along X-axis with spacing

Method

Determines the number of axes that can be transformed when calculating the part alignment. Choose a Method that is supported by your machine tool and post processor.

  • 3 Axis: Enables translation along one, two, or three linear axes.
  • 4 Axis: Enables translation along all linear axes and rotation about one rotary axis.
  • 5 Axis: Enables translation along and rotation about all axes.

Example of 3 Axis (left), 4 Axis (center), and 5 Axis (right).

Note: The axes are based on the work coordinate system defined in the setup.

Allow Translation Along X Axis

Controls whether translation can happen along the X axis.

Select to enable translation. Deselect if your machine tool or post processor is limited or you want to restrict the translation.

Note: The axis is based on the work coordinate system defined in the setup.

Allow Translation Along Y Axis

Controls whether translation can happen along the Y axis.

Select to enable translation. Deselect if your machine tool or post processor is limited or you want to restrict the translation.

Note: The axis is based on the work coordinate system defined in the setup.

Allow Translation Along Z Axis

Controls whether translation can happen along the Z axis.

Select to enable translation. Deselect if your machine tool or post processor is limited or you want to restrict the translation.

Note: The axis is based on the work coordinate system defined in the setup.

Axis of Rotation

Specifies the axis that can be rotated.

Note: The axis is based on the work coordinate system defined in the setup.

Optionally Select Existing Results

Lets you select already imported inspection results to calculate the part alignment.

Results for Calculation

Specifies the inspection results used to calculate the part alignment.

If you have already imported inspection results and want to use them to calculate the part alignment, manually select the inspection results in the Browser.

Otherwise, the part alignment is calculated when you click Get Results > Import Inspection Results and choose a machine-generated results file.

Measure Selection

The geometry you intend to measure with a manual device, such as a caliper or micrometer.

Select a hole or boss, or two walls. The nominal value for the diameter or distance is displayed.

Diameter of hole example

Distance between two walls example

When you create the Manual Inspection entry in the Browser, you can select it and click Probing > Inspect > Record Manual Inspection to record the measured value.

Upper Tolerance

Specifies the upper limit of the tolerance band. The tolerance band is the acceptable amount of deviation relative to the nominal value.

If the recorded measurement is above or below the tolerance band, the item is considered out of tolerance. For example, an upper tolerance of 0.1 mm and a lower tolerance of -0.1 mm for 15 mm hole means that the diameter must be between 14.9 mm and 15.1 mm.

Lower Tolerance

Specifies the lower limit of the tolerance band. The tolerance band is the acceptable amount of deviation relative to the nominal value.

If the recorded measurement is above or below the tolerance band, the item is considered out of tolerance. For example, an upper tolerance of 0.1 mm and a lower tolerance of -0.1 mm for 15 mm hole means that the diameter must be between 14.9 mm and 15.1 mm.

Inspection Type

Specifies the type of inspection to conduct on the physical part. You can choose from Distance, Pass/Fail, or Text.

Distance lets you measure the diameters of holes and bosses and certain distances, such as the distance between two holes or bosses, the distance between parallel surfaces, and the distance between a surface and a hole or boss. Pass/Fail lets you include a check, which does not have to be directly associated with a feature. And Text lets you specify a user-defined comment for when you want the inspector to record their observations.

Distance Type

Defines the type of distance you want to measure. The selection in the canvas determines the available options.

For certain distances, such as the distance between two holes or bosses, press Shift to multi-select the two features.

Diameter

Parallel Surfaces

Center to Center

Surface to Center

Measure Method

Specifies how you want to measure the center-to-center distance between two holes or bosses, or the surface-to-center distance between a flat surface and a hole or boss.

If your measuring instrument supports the measurement of center-to-center and surface-to-center distances, choose Direct. But if your measuring instrument does not directly support such measurement, choose From Maximum Distance or From Minimum Distance. This enables Fusion 360 to calculates the distance using other measurements.

Tool

Opens the Tool Library where you can select an existing tool, or create a new one, to use.

Tool

Opens the Tool Library, where you can select a nozzle for your work type.

Select the appropriate Tool/Nozzle for your cutting process.

Appropriate Tool/Nozzle Types
Waterjet cutting
Laser cutting
Plasma cutting

You can also select the
New Waterjet/Plasma/Laser
icon to create a custom Tool/Nozzle.

Note: The type of Tool/Nozzle you select will effect some of the toolpath options.

Tool

Opens the Tool Library where you can select an existing depositing tool or create a new one to use.

Product Link

Web site product link containing information on the tool.

Lead-In Feedrate

Controls the feedrate of the tool during the lead-in move, which is the movement of the tool as it approaches the stock, before beginning a cutting move.

To help maintain a short machine cycle time, it is recommended that the lead-in feedrate is the same as the cutting feedrate. The lead-in feedrate can be lowered for safer cutting conditions in scenarios where there is a heavy depth of cut, or if there is very little entry clearance, such as a tight gap between a tool and the walls of a pocket.

Lead-In Feedrate

Controls the feedrate of the tool during the lead-in move, which is the movement of the tool as it approaches the stock, before beginning a cutting move.

To help maintain a short machine cycle time, it is recommended that the lead-in feedrate is the same as the cutting feedrate. The lead-in feedrate can be lowered for safer cutting conditions in scenarios where there is a heavy depth of cut, or if there is very little entry clearance.

Lead-Out Feedrate

Controls the feedrate of the tool during the lead-out move, which is the movement of the tool as it leaves the stock, after a cutting move.

To help maintain a short machine cycle time, it is recommended that the lead-out feedrate is the same as the cutting feedrate. The lead-out feedrate can be increased in scenarios where a very low cutting feedrate is used. This helps the tool exit at a faster speed when its no longer engaged in a cut.

Lead-Out Feedrate

Controls the feedrate of the tool during the lead-out move, which is the movement of the tool as it leaves the stock, after a cutting move.

To help maintain a short machine cycle time, it is recommended that the lead-out feedrate is the same as the cutting feedrate. The lead-out feedrate can be increased in scenarios where a very low cutting feedrate is used. This helps the tool exit at a faster speed when its no longer engaged in a cut.

Bead Width

Specifies the width of the melted material used to deposit the features.

Small bead width during stock simulation

Large bead width during stock simulation

The bead is different to the material feedstock (such as wire or powder) that is supplied to the machine.

Depositing Feedrate

Specifies the travel speed of the deposition head when depositing the bead of material.

Deposition during stock simulation

Lead-In Feedrate

Specifies the travel speed of the deposition head when leading into a depositing move.

Lead-Out Feedrate

Specifies the travel speed of the deposition head when leading out from a depositing move.

Ramp Feedrate

Controls the feedrate of the tool as it performs a ramp move.

The ramp feedrate needs to operate at lower feeds to create safer cutting conditions. This is because a ramp move engages with more material than a normal cutting move.

Plunge Feedrate

Controls the feedrate of the tool when performing a plunge move, which is when the tool moves along its tool axis to move into, or outside, the stock.

Vertical plunge shown in red

Generally, when machining soft materials like plastics and wood and plunging into the stock, you require a slower feedrate than the cutting feedrate. If you are plunging outside of the stock, a faster feedrate than the cutting feedrate can be used.

Plunge Feedrate

The feedrate of the tool when performing a plunge move, which is when the tool moves along its tool axis to move into, or outside, the stock.

Plunge moves are shown as red segments. They are not commonly used for drilling cycles and may only appear in specific cases when using custom drilling cycles.

Plunge Feedrate

Specifies the travel speed of the deposition head when moving towards a layer to deposit the melted material.

Vertical plunge are shown in red

Feed per revolution

Determines the distance the tool moves in a linear motion for each spindle revolution.

Defines the feed as a ratio of the spindle speed ensures consistent tool load and chip formation if the spindle is changed. For example, if the recommended spindle speed is outside the range of your machine, you can lower the spindle speed and the chip formation should remain constant.

Feed per revolution

Determines the distance the tool moves in a linear motion for each spindle revolution.

Defines the feed as a ratio of the spindle speed ensures consistent tool load and chip formation if the spindle is changed. For example, if the recommended spindle speed is outside the range of your machine, you can lower the spindle speed and the chip formation should remain constant.

Description

A textual description of the tool holder.

Note: These descriptions can only be changed by editing the holder.

Vendor

The vendor or supplier of the tool holder.

Note: These descriptions can only be changed by editing the holder.

Product ID

The vendor's identifier or part number for the tool holder.

Note: These descriptions can only be changed by editing the holder.

Product Link

Web site product link, containing information on the holder.

Note: These descriptions can only be changed by editing the holder.

Reverse Z-Axis

Finishing Step

Specifies that a finishing step should be taken

Finishing Step

From Other Side

Specifies that the toolpath starts on the other side of the part.

Unselected

Selected

Lift Height

Specifies the lift distance during repositioning moves.

Lift Height 0

Lift Height .1 in

No-Engagement Feedrate

Specifies the feedrate used for movements where the tool is not in engagement on the material, but is also not retracted.

No-Engagement Feedrate

Specifies the feedrate used for movements where the tool is not in engagement on the material, but is also not retracted.

When the move between cuts is greater than the Maximun Stay-Down Distance, the tool will not retract to the Clearance Height and then feeds between the cut profiles. This parameter controls for the Feedrate for that motion.

Red Arrow Represents The Feed Motion.

Use Slot Clearing

Enable this setting to start pocket clearing with a slot along its middle, before continuing with a spiral motion towards the pocket wall.

This feature can be used to reduce linking motion at corners for some pockets.

Enabled

Disabled

Slot Clearing Width

The width of the initial clearing slot along the middle of the pocket before continuing with a spiral motion towards the pocket wall.

Slot Clearing Width

Compensation Radius Allowance

This parameter specifies a range of tool diameters that can be safely used, instead of only the tool selected for the operation.

The allowed range of tool radii start from the selected tool radius and goes up to the selected tool radius, plus the given allowance.

Make Sharp Corners

Forces a sharp toolpath intersection on all external corners.

When unchecked the toolpath will roll around all external sharp corners. This creates a toolpath that flows to avoid sudden changes in direction.

Unchecked - Rolled Corner

Checked - SharpCorner

Note: Only the toolpath is effected by this parameter. The part will always have a sharp intersection. Using a tool with a smaller nose radius can gouge the part.

Chamfer

Specifies that the contouring operation will be used to create a chamfer.

Geometry Selection Tips:

Sharp Corners

Chamfered Edges

Sharp Corners - Select the sharp corner and define the size of the chamfer using the Chamfer Width Setting.

Chamfered Edges - Select the bottom edge of the chamfer. The chamfer width is calculated automatically.

Important: All edges selected must be either the bottom edge of a chamfered face or unchamfered edges. If both edge types are selected, then the edges that already have the chamfers modeled end up with chamfers that are twice the size they should be.

Chamfer Width

Chamfer Depth

Order By Islands

Specifies the order in which depth cuts are taken when there are multiple profiles.

Disabled

Enabled

Disabled - Depth cuts are ordered by depth.

Enabled - Depth cuts are ordered by profile.

Note: Ordering cuts by island minimizes the number of rapid moves.

Up/Down Shallow Angle

Allow Stepover Cusps

When programming flat faces with a tool that has a radius in the corner, a cusp (or scallop) can be produced between stepovers.

By default, the Maximum Stepover value is overridden to insure that no stepover cusps are produced.

Allow Stepover Cusps Disabled

Allow Stepover Cusps Enabled

Above - Pocket machined with a 3/8" bullnose end mill @ .25" Maximum Stepover.

Ramp Radial Clearance

Specifies the minimum distance to the contour for the lead-in helix.

Axial Offset

Can be used to shift the selected curve up or down in the spindle axis.

Merge Hole Segments

Incremental Depth

Specifies the Z depth for each XY Circular Pocket pass.

An Incremental Depth of 2mm on a pocket that is 6mm deep, will create 3 Z level passes.

Incremantal Depth of 2mm on a 6mm deep pocket

3 depth cuts

Pecking Depth Reduction

Specifies the amount to subtract from the Pecking Depth, for each subsequent peck. Reduces the load on the drill, as the depth increases.

Multiple Pecks Shown with a 2mm Reduction

Example: Peck Depth of 8mm, a Pecking Depth Reduction of 2mm and a Minimum Pecking Depth of 4mm. The first peck will be 8mm. The second peck will be 6mm. The third peck will be 4mm.

A value of 0.0 maintains the same Pecking Depth for all moves, until the full depth is reached.

Minimum Pecking Depth

As the the Pecking Depth is reduced by the reduction amount, This value specifies a minimum amount to drill per peck.

Shown with a 4mm Minimum Depth

Example: Peck Depth of 8mm, a Pecking Depth Reduction of 2mm and a Minimum Pecking Depth of 4mm. The first peck will be 8mm. The second peck will be 6mm. The third peck will be 4mm and all subsequent pecks will be 4mm.

Pitch

Specifies the distance to step in Z while creating the helical pass around the contour.

Z distance traveled for each complete pass

Chip Break Distance

Specifies how much the tool will retract between pecks. This minimal clearance retract breaks the chip and relieves pressure on the tool tip between pecks. Shown in yellow.

Chip Break Retract Shown in yellow

Example: Pecking Depth of 8mm, an Accumulated Pecking Depth of 14mm and a Chip Breaking Distance of .50mm. The cycle will complete the first peck, retract .50mm and then proceed with the next peck.

Diameter

Specifies the final diameter of the Circular Bore.

Desired Finish Diameter

Note: This toolpath is not associative to the selected cylindrical face. Diameter changes to the model will not affect the cycle or the resulting toolpath. Only changes to the location of the cylinder, or the depth of the cylinder, will detect a change that requires a toolpath regeneration.

Stepover

Specifies the distance between cuts in the XY plane.

Distance between cuts

Rather than push the tool in a linear move in XY, the stepover is created by shifting the arc center, until the full diameter size is achieved.

Shaft & Holder

Enable to specify how the shaft and/or holder of the tool is used to avoid collisions with the workpiece.

Disabled

Enabled

Shaft And Holder Mode

Specifies how the toolpath should handle a collision between the shaft and/or holder and the workpiece.

Disabled

Trimmed

Pull away

Detect tool length

Trimmed - Sections of the toolpath that result in safe distances between the shaft and/or holder being violated are trimmed away.

Pull away - The toolpath pulls away from the workpiece to maintain a safe distance between the shaft and/or holder.

Detect tool length - The tool is automatically extended further out of the holder to maintain the specified safe distance between the shaft and/or holder and the workpiece. A message indicating how far the tool is extended out of the holder is logged.

Fail on collision - The toolpath calculation is aborted and an error message logged when the safe distance is violated.

Use Shaft

Specifies that the shaft of the selected tool will be used in the toolpath calculation to avoid collisions.

Shaft Clearance

The tool shaft always stays this distance from the part.

Use Holder

Specifies that the holder of the selected tool will be used in the toolpath calculation to avoid collisions.

Holder Clearance

The tool holder always stays this distance from the part.

Silhouette Aperture

Rest Material File

From Setup Stock

Rest Material Tool Taper Angle

Specify the taper angle of the tool previously used to cut the boundary.

Any areas not cut by this tool will be machined.

Rest Material Tool Shoulder Length

Specify the shoulder length of the tool previously used to cut the boundary.

Any areas not cut by this tool will be machined.

Fillet Radius

Specify a fillet radius.

Minimum Diameter

The smallest cylindrical diameter that can be machined.

This limits depth cuts based on cavity size. When set to zero the tool machines to the limits of where it can safely fit.

Set to Zero
cuts to full depth

Set to .320 in
Greater than, cavity dia. - tool dia.

Tip The value becomes effective when set to anything larger than the difference between the cavity dia, minus the tool diameter.

Minimum Fragment Length

Fragment Extension Distance

Smooth Ramps

When enabled, ramps are started and ended tangentially in all three axes.

Ramping is done without discontinuities in the first order derivative so that smooth curves are used instead of the usual kinks in the path.

Cusp Height

Cusp Height is the theoretical surface finish produced by successive toolpaths left by the radius of the cutter. A smaller tool diameter or a larger stepover produces a larger cusp height.

Cusp Height

Order Bottom-Up

Contour passes are usually ordered from top to bottom. Enable this check box to specify that passes should be ordered bottom-up (bottom to top).

Ordering is done so that the passes with the smallest Z-level tool orientation are done first in one operation for multiple contours. This method is very useful for machining fragile materials like graphite.

Machine Steep Areas

Specifies extra passes will be added where the surface is steep perpendicular to the machining direction. This is important for plastic injection molds where the cutting direction needs to be consistent to avoid marks on the parts.

Disabled

Enabled

Minimum Steep Stepover

Defines the minimum stepover that is used when Machine Steep Areas is enabled, regardless of the stepdown amount.

Maximum Steep Stepdown

Defines the maximum steep stepdown value.

Add Perpendicular Passes

This setting adds a set of passes perpendicular to the specified machining direction to reduce machining cusps.

Disabled

Enabled

Machine Straight On

Avoids machining along the steep areas by automatically choosing the best direction for the parallel passes.

Machine Areas Using Boundaries

When enabled, passes are generated from the confinement boundaries defined by all confinement features (machining boundaries, slope, heights). When disabled, passes are generated from the machining boundaries resulting in passes normally not following the surface.

Boundary Overlap

When using slope confinement and/or rest machining for a Scallop operation, you can enable the Machine Areas Using Boundaries check box to start offsetting the toolpath from the boundaries created by the slope and/or rest material detection.

You can specify a boundary overlap so that the boundary of the detected slope range or rest area is extended by the specified overlap amount.

Area Smoothing

Spiral Mode

Spiral

Spiral with circles

Concentric circles

Spiral creates a path that spirals out from the center point until it reaches the containment boundary or max radius.

Spiral with circles adds a circular toolpath at the minimum radius and at the maximum radius. The circular toolpath is only added if the minimum radius is larger than 0 and the maximum radius is smaller than the radius of the containment boundary.

Concentric circles produces concentric circle paths that are linked. The resulting paths form a circular pattern rather than a spiral pattern.

Morphed spiral spirals from a shape that is not round.

Number Of Offset Stepovers

Used to increase or decrease the total number of steps, offset from the selected geometry chains.

Zero offset.
Toolpath ends at the chains.

Positive 2 offset.
Toolpath is offset in from the chains.

Negative 2 offset.
Toolpath is offset out from the chains.

Contour Offset

This value is used to offset the center of the tool from the generated toolpath, by a specified distance.

Dark blue represents the original toolpath.
Light blue represents the Offset toolpath.

Morph Mode

How to synchronize the selected chains.

Simple
Best when the selected chains have an equal number of segments.

Closest
Finds the closest distance between the selected chains.

Tilt Mode

Forward Tilt

Specifies the number of degrees the tool should tilt along the direction of travel.

A positive value tilts the tool towards the direction of travel, commonly known as a lead angle. A negative value tilts the tool away from the direction of travel, commonly known as a lag angle.

Positive value
Forward tilt

Negative value
Backward tilt

Sideways Tilt

Specifies the angle by which the tool leans sideways in reference to the tool's direction of travel.

1 - Direction of travel
2 - Direction of sideways tilt

You can tilt the tool sideways to remove material with a larger portion of the tool and save on machining time. When a value is specified for the Sideways Tilt, the tool maintains this tilt angle as much as possible, as long as no potential collisions are detected.

Maximum Tilt

Specifies the maximum tilt angle that the tool cannot tilt beyond, measured from the specified tool orientation Z axis.

1 - Minimum tilt
2 - Maximum tilt

Tip: The maximum tilt can be thought of as a conical boundary around the specified tool orientation Z axis.

Tool Axis

Enables multi-axis tilting for the tool so that you can machine more areas and avoid potential collisions between the part and the tool assembly. The tool-axis tilting is determined by the specified tilt values.

Tool tilting can happen only on machines that allow multi-axis configurations. When using multi-axis tilting, it is particularly useful to machine with shorter tools that are more rigid for better surface finishes.

Tool Axis

Enables multi-axis tilting for the tool so that you can machine more areas and avoid potential collisions between the part and the tool assembly. The tool-axis tilting is determined by the specified tilt values.

Tool tilting can happen only on machines that allow multi-axis configurations. When using multi-axis tilting, it is particularly useful to machine with shorter tools that are more rigid for better surface finishes.

Tool Axis

Enables multi-axis tilting for the tool so that you can machine more areas and avoid potential collisions between the part and the tool assembly. The tool-axis tilting is determined by the specified tilt values.

Tool tilting can happen only on machines that allow multi-axis configurations. When using multi-axis tilting, it is particularly useful to machine with shorter tools that are more rigid for better surface finishes.

Tool Axis

Controls how to tilt the tool so that you can machine more areas and avoid potential collisions between the part and the tool assembly.

Tool tilting can happen only on machines that allow multi-axis configurations. When using multi-axis tilting, it is particularly useful to machine with shorter tools that are more rigid for better surface finishes.

Maximum segment length

Specifies the maximum length of a single segment, for the generated toolpath.

Stepover distance .150 in

Stepover distance .050 in

Note - A larger distance can reduce the file size, but make the cut coarse. The calculated toolpath will always be within the specified Tolerance.

Maximum Tool Axis Sweep

Specifies the maximum angular change in a single tool axis sweep, for the generated toolpath.

Angular sweep of 10 degrees

Angular sweep of 5 degrees

Note - A larger distance can reduce the file size, but make the cut coarse. The calculated toolpath will always be within the specified Tolerance.

Allow Relinking

Rest Material Overlap

This value specifies how much rest material you can ignore. Use this parameter to avoid undesired passes where there is little rest material.

Stock Offset

Specifies the distance to offset the stock contour outwards.

Stock Offset

Stock Offset

Specifies the distance the machining boundary extends beyond the stock boundary in both X & Y.

Stock Offset

Lead End Distance

Specifies the distance the leadout feed rate begins before the end of the selected geometry.

@ 0 in

@ .5 in

Note: This option is used when you desire to change the feedrate prior to breaking through at the end of the cut.

Preserve Order

When Selected, the chains/features are machined in the order they were selected.
When unselected, the program optimizes the cut order.

Preserve Order

When Selected, the chains/features are machined in the order they were selected.
When unselected, the program optimizes the cut order.

As a default Waterjet toolpaths will always be optimized to machine inside bountaries first (slugs), then machine outside boundaries. This keeps the parts from breaking free and moving during a second or third cut on the same part.

Note: See the Linking - Keep Nozzle Down parameters for more control over the movement between inside cut slugs and outside cut parts.

Maximum Angle (deg)

Specifies the maximum plunge angle for the passes.

Tool Orientation Mode

Include Drilled Holes

Include Bored Holes

Include Through Holes

Include Split Holes

Fillets

Enable to enter a fillet radius.

Minimize Tool Axis Changes

Minimize Tool Changes

Minimize Distance

Use Stepover

Enable to enter a Maximum Stepover distance.

Disable to enter a total Number of Steps.

Drive Mode

Determines if the toolpath will be driven by the Faces of the model or user selected Contours.

With Faces selected, the actual
surface will drive the Swarf Toollpath.

With Contours selected, the selected
edges will drive the Swarf Toolpath.

Selection Mode

Allows you to select the machining area by continous Faces, single Faces or Contour Pairs of chains.

Drive Mode = Surfaces
Selection Mode = Faces
Select continous surfaces.

Drive Mode = Surfaces
Selection Mode = Manual
Select the individual surfaces.

Drive Mode = Contours
Selection Mode = Contour Pairs
Select the Lower and Upper Contour
that will drive the Swarf Toolpath.
Select the Lower Chain First.

Drive Mode = Contours
Selection Mode = Manual
Select the individual Edges
that will drive the Swarf Toolpath.
Select the Lower Chain First.

Machine Other Side

Forces the toolpath to the opposite side of the machining contour.
Most likely will be needed with Flip Top-Bottom parameter change.

Flip Top-Bottom

Changes the direction the tool points by switching the Lower Contour
and the Upper Contour. Only applies when Contours are selected.

Flips the Tool Vector 180 Degrees thru the Spindle Axis.

Synchronization Mode

Cutting Mode

The cutting mode specifies how to machine down the sides.

Single Pass

From Bottom

Trim from Bottom

From Top

Trim from Top

Morph

Curve Selection

Select one or more guide curves for machining.

Geometry

Select two or more curves to define the machining area. The chains should all flow in the same direction.

Two closed chains selected.

Three open ended chains selected.

Curve Selection

Select the guide curves to machined.

Select two or more curves to define the machining area.

Two closed chains selected.

Three open ended chains selected.

Cutting Mode

The cutting mode specifies how to machine along a given contact curve.

Cutting Mode

Use this for machines that have internal Quality tables to
set the appropriate cutting feeds for the material being cut.

* Through - Auto
* Through - high quality
* Through - medium quality
* Through - low quality
* Etch
* Vaporize

Note: Etch scores the material surface without cutting thru.
Vaporize is used for burning the plastic film off of some materials.
Some of these options are not available for all machine types.
Example: You cannot Etch with a Plasma cutter.

Cutting Mode

The cutting mode specifies how to machine along the ISO parametric directions of selected surfaces.

Trim impossible - Remove impossible toolpath moves.

Fail when impossible - Fail when impossible toolpath moves are generated.

Turn when impossible - Do a "turn" away from impossible toolpath segments.

Manual Stepdowns

Top of Stock

Specifies the overall thickness of the stock.

Stock Height

Tool Offset

Specifies an extra offset along the tool axis relative to the bottom guide curve.

0.00 Tool Offset Extension

0.20 Tool Offset Extension

Minimize Axial Motion

Minimizes the changes in the axial motion of the tool's tip for smoother machining. This setting maintains the center of the tool's tip on the same plane as much as possible.

Deselected

Selected

Along Stock

Allows the tip of the tool to follow the top contour of a selected surface instead of the bottom contour.

This allows for extra control over what areas to machine and can be particularly useful if using surface extensions while programming operations.

Deselected

Selected

Pass Overlap

Specifies the distance to extend machining for a closed pass.

Maximum Fan Distance

Specifies the maximum distance at which the tool axis is allowed to transition before a change in slope is detected.

Max Fan Distance = 0 mm

Max Fan Distance = 5 mm

A larger fan distance allows the tool to start tilting before the underlying surface changes to avoid sudden changes in tool-axis motion.

Tangential Fragment Extension Distance

Extends the cut tangentially at both ends of the pass.

Tangent Extension at both ends of the cut

Tool Clearance Back

Specifies an angle that is added to the tool angle to provide clearance behind the cutting edge.

Shown with 20 deg Back Clearance and 30 deg Front Clearance

Sets the amount of relief between the part and the back edge of the cutting tool. Allows for a more gradual entry into the part and exerts less pressure on the tool.

Tool Clearance Front

Specifies an angle that is added to the tool angle to provide clearance in front of the cutting edge.

Shown with 30 deg Front Clearance and 20 deg Back Clearance

Sets the amount of relief between the part and the front edge of the cutting tool. Allows for a less dragging of the insert against the tools leading edge.

Machine Inside (Boring)

Specifies that the operation should machine the ID of the workpiece.

Disabled

Enabled

Illustrated with Turning Profile

Note: Typically this also means switching from an OD turning tool to a boring tool.

Use Tailstock

A tailstock is used to apply support to the longitudinal rotary axis of the workpiece being machined. This is particularly useful when the workpiece is relatively long and slender. Failing to use a tailstock can cause the workpiece to bend excessively while being cut and cause "chatter".

For this option to take effect, your machine needs a programmable tailstock and your post processor has to be configured to write the code your machine needs.

Once configured, you would typically see M21 (tailstock forward) at the beginning of the operation and M22 (tailstock backward) at the end with this option enabled.

Go Home

The Home position is a known Z value relative to the WCS and is defined within the Work Coordinate System (WCS) section on the Setup tab of the Setup strategy dialog.

You can force the tool to move to the Home position prior to starting the operation, or once the operation has finished. The tool will always pull out of the stock in the X axis until it reaches the Clearance height, then move to the Home position in the Z.

Don't Go Home

Go Home At Beginning

Go Home At End

Go Home At Beginning And End

Note: The Home position referred to here is different from the G28 or G53 home position defined in the Post Processor dialog with some posts. Setting both values simultaneously could create unexpected results if you are unfamiliar with your post processor and machine.

Frontside Stock Offset

Specifies the distance to machine beyond the frontside of the model.

Confinement using offsets

Negative frontside offset

Positive frontside offset

Note: This offset applies to the frontside of the model or containment region, and can be used at the same time as a backside offset.

Backside Stock Offset

Specifies the distance to machine beyond the backside of the model.

Confinement using offsets

Negative backside offset

Positive backside offset

Note: This offset applies to the backside of the model or containment region, and can be used at the same time as a frontside offset.

Roughing Overlap

Specifies how far the tool should move past the previous pass, before it begins any lead-out or retract.

The path shown in red represents a full pass.

Overlap set to 0mm

Overlap set to .5mm

Use Pecking

Pecking creates multiple steps across the length of the cutting direction. Between Pecking Depths the tool retracts along its path by the specified Pecking retract distance. Use this if your material creates long strings of chips.

Use Pecking disabled.
Single cut along the path.

18 mm Pecking Depth.
3 mm Retract between Pecks.

Tip: To see the points where the tool is pecking and retracting. Go to Simulation and under the Show Toolpath group, icon.

Peck Depth

Specifies the step distance per Peck along the length of the cutting direction. The distance to feed along the cut, between retracts.

Red arrows indicate Peck Depth segment

Tip: To see the points where the tool is pecking and retracting. Go to Simulation and under the Show Toolpath group, icon.

Peck Retract

Specifies the Retract distance between Pecks along the cutting direction.

Red arrows indicate Peck Retract segment

Tip: To see the points where the tool is pecking and retracting. Go to Simulation and under the Show Toolpath group, icon.

Use Pecking

Pecking creates multiple steps across the length of the cutting direction. Between Pecking Depths the tool retracts along its path by the specified Pecking retract distance. Use this if your material creates long strings of chips or to improve coolant flow to the tool tip.

Use Pecking disabled.
Single cut along the path.

8 mm Pecking Depth.
3 mm Retract between Pecks.

Tip: To see the points where the tool is pecking and retracting. Go to Simulation and under the Show Toolpath group, icon.

Peck Depth

Specifies the step distance per Peck along the length of the cutting direction. The distance to feed along the cut, between retracts.

Red arrows indicate Peck Depth segment

Tip: To see the points where the tool is pecking and retracting. Go to Simulation and under the Show Toolpath group, icon.

Peck Retract

Specifies the Retract distance between Pecks along the cutting direction.

Red arrows indicate Peck Retract segment

Tip: To see the points where the tool is pecking and retracting. Go to Simulation and under the Show Toolpath group, icon.

Allow Grooving

Allows the tool to move towards the center of the stock in narrow areas. If disabled, the tool can only begin cuts on the front open face of the stock. When enabled, the tool can plunge into the stock in narrow areas to create grooves.

Allow Grooving disabled

Allow Grooving enabled

Lead Mode

The lead mode settings provide very specific control of the leads. There are five options available.

Fail - Results in a failure if it is not possible to do the lead in/outs without causing a gouge. User intervention is then required to make the leads fit.

Discard passes - Discards any passes that cannot be reached with the given settings. This option leaves rest material for any following operations.

Move lead - Moves the lead position to a different location along the part until there is room, but keeps the lead as specified.

Turn lead - Changes the lead angle until there is room.

Retract lead - Is the most automatic lead mode and also the default setting. It allows linking of all parts and, in some cases, does radial retracts when there is no other alternative. This is the recommended setting.

Linear Lead-In Angle

Specifies the lead-in direction.

Linear Lead-In Angle

Specifies the entry angle of the lead-in move at the start of a cutting pass. The angle is in reference to the first cut.

Lead In shown in green.

Angle @ 0 degrees

Angle @ 45 degrees

Angle @ 90 degrees

Lead-In Extension

Specifies the lead-in extension.

Lead-In Extension

Specifies the lead-in extension value which has the effect of leading in before the point at which the cutting movement starts by the specified distance.

Lead-In Extension set to 0mm

Lead-In Extension set to 1mm

Linear Lead-Out Angle

Specifies the lead-out direction.

Linear Lead-Out Angle

Specifies the exit angle of the lead-out move at the end of a cutting pass. The angle is in reference to the last cut.

Lead Out shown in green.

Angle @ 0 degrees

Angle @ 45 degrees

Angle @ 90 degrees

Radial Extension

Controls whether to machine only the part or unfinished material too.

If selected, the toolpath extends radially up to the stock limits. If deselected, the toolpath starts and ends at the part.

Radial extension is turned off

Radial extension is turned on

Axial Extension

Controls whether to machine only the part or unfinished material too.

If selected, the toolpath extends axially up to the stock limits. If deselected, the toolpath starts and ends at the part.

Axial extension is turned off

Axial extension is turned on

Allow Lead to Cut Stock

Allows the Lead-In and Lead-Out Radius/Length/Angle to move past the containment limits of the cut boundary. This might cause the toolpath to gouge the remaining stock.

When disabled, if the toolpath passes through the remaining stock, the toolpath is not generated.

Lead-Out Extension

Specifies the lead-out extension.

Lead-Out Extension

This setting has the effect of delaying the point at which the cutter begins to lead out by the specified distance.

Lead-Out Extension set to 0mm

Lead-Out Extension set to 1mm

Maximum Grooving Stepover

Specifies the maximum grooving stepover. The final stepover is less than this value to account for the radius on the tools insert, ensuring that no cusp is left on the surface. In the image below, the Maximum Grooving Stepover value is set to 10mm so the axial distance between passes will always be as close to 10mm as possible.

Maximum Grooving Stepover set at 10mm

Grooving Pattern

Specifies the strategy used to create the groove toolpath. The geometry you are turning, the material from which your part is made, and the type of grooving insert and holder you want to use determines which option is best to use.

Full Stepdown

Partial Stepdown

Sideways With
Partial Stepdown

Full Stepdown - Removes all the material radially, before moving along the spindle axis to remove the next amount. The amount the tool steps over each time is controlled by the Maximum Grooving Stepover value.

Partial Stepdown - Removes all the material along the spindle axis before starting to remove the material at the next depth specified by the Maximum Groove Stepdown value.

Sideways With Partial Stepdown - In some materials it is better to groove from side to side since it results in smaller chips and increased tool life. For example, if the groove is wider than it is deep, using this option can result in faster overall material removal rate than the Full Stepdown or Partial Stepdown options. Tip: In a case like this, use the Both Ways option in the Direction drop-down menu on the Tool tab, as shown in the above image.

Maximum Groove Stepdown

Specifies the maximum distance the Partial Stepdown or Sideways With Partial Stepdown toolpaths can move in the X axis between each radial pass.

Maximum Groove Stepdown set at 2mm

Maximum Groove Stepdown set at 3.5mm

Backoff Distance

Specifies the distance to back off from the stock before retracting.

Use Pecking

Pecking forces the tool to cut into the material by the specified Pecking depth distance, gradually progressing down to the finished depth required. The tool then retracts along its path by the specified Pecking retract distance.

Use Pecking disabled

3mm Pecking Depth

Tip: You can easily see the points where the tool is pecking and retracting, by enabling Show points in the Toolpath group while in Simulation.

Pecking Depth

Specifies the maximum distance the tool cuts into the material before retracting to clear or break the chips. The red arrows in the image show where the tool is cutting down in increments equal to, or less than this value.

Pecking Depth

Pecking Retract

Specifies the distance the tool retracts from its pecking depth to clear or break the chips. The green arrow in the image shows where the tool is pulling out inbetween each peck.

Pecking Retract

Note: The tool retracts using the cutting feedrate.

Use Reduced Feedrate

Enable to reduce the feedrate when grooving along the X axis. Finish passes are still carried out using the original feedrate specified on the Tool tab.

The highlighted blue elements of the toolpath use the
reduced rate specified in the Reduced Feed field.

Multiple Passes

Enable to enter a stepover value.

Multiple Passes

Enable to enter a value for multiple depth cuts when Thread Milling.

Multiple Passes
Uses Multiple cuts to achieve the full thread milling depth

Geometry for Bore Milling

Select any internal or external circular Face. This can be straight walled or tapered.

Bore Mill Geometry Selection

Select any cylindrical or conical face from the model. This can be a boss for OD Bore milling or a hole for ID Bore milling. Diameter, Starting height and Bottom depth is all derived from this selection.

Geometry for Bore Milling

Select any internal or external circular Face. This can be straight walled or tapered. The heights and depths are automatically derived from the selected Face.

Bore Mill Geometry Selection

Select any cylindrical or conical face from the model. This can be a boss for OD Bore milling or a hole for ID Bore milling. Diameter, Starting height and Bottom depth is all derived from this selection.

Pitch

The distance to feed down for each 360 deg. revolution. For straight walls this value is generally larger than with tapered walls. A finer Pitch on a Tapered wall creates a smoother surface finish.

Depth Per. Revolution

Multiple Passes

Enable to enter a value for multiple side cuts when Bore Milling.

Multiple Passes
Creates multiple side cuts

Number Of Stepovers

The number of side cuts to make.

This illustration shows 2 Stepovers.

Stepover

Specifies the side cut stepover amount between passes.

The amount per each cut.

Geometry

Select the surface to apply the toolpath to the selected surface.

You can select multiple surfaces to generate a single flow toolpath. The number of stepovers specified is applied to each surface selection.

Note: Clicking the bi-directional red arrow switches the isometric direction of the toolpath, which can also be controlled from the Passes tab of this dialog.

Isometric Direction

Specifies the direction of the toolpath as Along U (similar to the X-axis in the Cartesian coordinate system), or as Along V (similar to the Y-axis in the Cartesian coordinate system).

The Isometric Direction can also be changed by clicking the bi-directional arrow on the selected surfaces.

Feed Optimization

Controls the feedrate in corners of the toolpath by using a reduced feedrate instead of the cutting feedrate to reduce shocking the tool.

Less shock on the tool can lead to a better surface finish and a longer tool life.

Maximum Directional Change

Specifies the maximum angular change allowed in the corner before the feedrate is reduced. The value should be between 0 and 180 degrees.

In the example below, when 90 degrees is specified, no change in the feedrate occurs as all corners are 90 degrees, or smaller than 90 degrees. However, when 89 degrees is specified, corners greater than 89 degrees have their feedrate reduced.

90 degrees

89 degrees

Reduced Feed Distance

Specifies the distance before a corner at which to reduce the feedrate.

The larger the value, the earlier the feedrate gets reduced before entering the corner, assuming the move prior to the corner is linear.

2mm distance

10mm distance

Reduced Feed

Specifies the reduced feedrate for the portions of the toolpath that have been identified for feed optimization.

Reduced Feed

Specifies a slower feedrate to be used when the tool is moving in the X direction while cutting material.

Only Inner Corners

Reduces the feedrate on the toolpath that covers the inner corners of the model without affecting the toolpath on the outer corners.

Deselected

Selected

Rough Final

Enable to apply a rough pass at the final depth when doing multiple depths with one or more finishing stepdowns.

Both Ways

Specifies that the operation uses both Climb and Conventional milling to machine open profiles.

Unselected

Selected

Note: This option only controls how multiple depth cuts are taken on a single open contour. It does not optimize the cut direction for multiple open contours.

Threading

Select the direction of the thread milling cycle, to create right- or left-handed threads.

right-handed threads

left-handed threads

Maximum Tool Depth

Default Spot Drill Diameter

Chamfer Size

Merge With Spot Drilling

Minimum Predrill Diameter

Increment Predrill Diameter

Stock Per Side Remaining For Finish Tool

Normalization Mode

Normalization Reference

Normalization Offset

Normalization

Threading Hand

right-handed

left-handed

Threading Hand

Create a right- or left-handed thread direction.

Thread Depth

Specifies the thread depth.

Thread Depth = T

Shown as T in the illustration, it is the difference between the Major D and Minor d diameters, divided by 2.

Thread Pitch

Specifies the thread pitch.

Thread Pitch = P

Shown as P in the illustration, it is the distance traversed for 1 complete thread. 1/Threads Per Inch (TPI) or the actual pitch for metric threads.

Thread Pitch

The distance between threads.

The distance traversed for 1 complete thread.
1/Threads Per Inch (TPI) or the actual pitch for metric threads.

Do Multiple Threads

Used for multi-lead threads. Activate and specify the number of thread leads.

Number Of Threads

Specifies the number of thread leads. Used for multi-lead threads.

Example - Specifying the number 3 will create 3 threads that start 120 degrees apart.

Infeed Mode

The infeed is the depth of cut per pass and is critical in threading. Each successive pass engages a larger portion of the cutting edge of the insert. There are three infeed mode options.

Constant infeed - With this option, the cutting force and metal removal rate can increase dramatically from one pass to the next. Example: When producing a 60 degree thread form using a constant 0.010 inch infeed per pass, the second pass removes three times the amount of metal as the first pass. The amount of metal removed continues to grow exponentially with each subsequent pass.

Reduced infeed - This option maintains more realistic cutting forces and reduces the depth of cut with each pass. Because it avoids the increased metal removal rate of constant infeed, it is the recommended setting.

Alternate infeed - Similar to the Reduced infeed, but this method alternates between feeding in from the left and right sides of the thread profile.

Constant Equal Plunges

Reduced Set To 29.5 Degrees

Alternating side feed

Alternating side feed

Infeed Angle

Specifies the infeed angle of the tool. Sometimes set to half of the included thread angle
of the insert, minus .5 degrees for clearance. Example: (60 deg. / 2) -.5 = 29.5

Infeed Set To 0 Degrees

Infeed Set To 29.5 Degrees

Feeding in on the angle reduces the load on the front edge of the tool.

Stock In Chuck

Specifies the amount of stock in the chuck.

Stock In Chuck Shifted Distance

Eject Stock

Specifies the amount of stock to eject from the current chuck.

Finish Feedrate

Feedrate used for the final finishing pass.

Reduced Feed Radius

Specifies the maximum toolpath radius used for feedrate reduction.

The larger the value, the more areas fall into the reduced feedrate threshold.

2mm radius

10mm radius

Geometry

Select any Face, Edge or Sketch to define the machining boundary.

Selecting the Outside

Note: Selecting a Face will detect all inside and outside boundaries.

Contour Selections

Select any Face, Edge or Sketch to define the machining boundary. Selecting a Face creates toolpaths on all the edges. Use Edge selection for areas with holes or pockets on the Face. Selecting the lower Edge will automatically set the reference for the cutting depth.

Chain Selection - Outside

Chain Selection - Inside

Note: Selecting a Face will detect all inside and outside boundaries.

Tip: Next to the Contour Selection button, click X to remove all current selections.

Geometry for Thread Milling

Select any cylindrical or conical face from the model. This can be a boss for OD thread milling or a hole for ID thread milling. Diameter, Taper angle, Starting height, and Bottom depth are all derived from this selection.

Select any ID or OD faces

Thread Mill Toolpath

Note: For ID thread milling the cylinder should be modeled to the Minor diameter. For OD thread milling the cylinder should be modeled to the Major diameter.

Geometry for Thread Milling

Select any cylindrical or conical face from the model. This can be a boss for OD thread milling or a hole for ID thread milling. Diameter, Taper angle, Starting height, and Bottom depth are all derived from this selection.

Select any ID or OD faces

Thread Mill Toolpath

Note: For ID thread milling the cylinder should be modeled to the Minor diameter. For OD thread milling the cylinder should be modeled to the Major diameter.

Select same plane faces

When checked, selecting a face will find all faces on the same plane, from all the parts within the stock boundary.

Select any face on any part for a match.

Note: Used to filter boundaries based on the face depth. Use the Loops filter to detect all inside or outside boundaries.

Loops Selection

Used with face selection to filter Inner or Outer chains

All Loops Selected

Outer Loops Selected

Inner Loops Selected

Note: It may be advantageous to select all Inner boundaries for a single toolpath and another toolpath for Outer boundaries. This will give you more control over Lead In/Out values for each.

Side

Used to offset selected edges or sketches

Use this to offset the contour inside or outside from the original edge or sketch geometry. Allows you to shift from the selected Sideways Compensation direction or reverse the compensation offset direction.

* Start Outside
* Start Inside
* Always Outside
* Always Inside

Contour Selections

Select the edges or faces of the model to find the chains for machining.
Select Sketches directly from the Browser Tree.

Chain Selection - Outside

Chain Selection - Inside

Note: Selecting a Face will detect all inside or outside boundaries based on the Loops option settings.

Select same plane faces

When checked, selecting a face will find all faces on the same plane, from all the parts within the stock boundary.

Select any face on any part for a match.

Note: Used to filter boundaries based on the face depth. Use the Loops filter to detect all inside or outside boundaries.

Contours

Used to filter Open and Closed chains

* All contours - Select All contours from the selected face
* Open contours - Select only Open contours from the selected face
* Closed contours - Select only Closed contours from the selected face

Loops Selection

Used with face selection to filter Inner or Outer chains

All Loops Selected

Outer Loops Selected

Inner Loops Selected

Note: It may be advantageous to select all Inner boundaries for a single toolpath and another toolpath for Outer boundaries. This will give you more control over the Piercing clearance and Lead In/Out values for each.

Side

Used to offset selected edges or sketches

Use this to offset the contour inside or outside from the original edge or sketch geometry. Can be used to Etch along the edge of a profile. Allows you to shift from the selected Sideways Compensation direction or reverse the compensation offset direction.

* Start Outside
* Start Inside
* Always Outside
* Always Inside

Note - If the Tool - Cutting Mode is set to Etch, Sideways Compensation will default to Center. Changing the Side options will not work unless Sideways Compensation is set to Left or Right.

Pierce Clearance

A distance away from the part edge to start the cut.
Allows the Plasma head, Waterjet nozzle or Laser to plunge the
initial hole into the part, without affecting the part edge.

Note: This value is in addition to the Lead In/Out distance.

Tabs

Tabs give you a way to hold the part when cutting profiles from a sheet.

Part shown with 4 Tabs

Part being held with 4 Tabs

Note: Tabs can be placed at equal spacing along the profile or at specific points selected by the user.

Tabs

Tabs give you a way to hold the part when cutting profiles from a sheet.

Part shown with 4 Tabs

Part being held with 4 Tabs

Note: Tabs can be placed at equal spacing along the profile or at specific points selected by the user.

Tab Shape

Tabs can be Rectangular or Triangular shaped.

Rectangular Tab

Triangular Tab

Tab Width

The width of material to hold the part,
when cutting profiles from a sheet.

Tab Width

Note: Tabs will be placed perpendicular to the geometry being machined.

Tab Width

The width of material to hold the part,
when cutting profiles from a sheet.

Tab Width

Note: Tabs will be placed perpendicular to the geometry being machined.

Tab Height

The height of the tab material to hold the part when cutting profiles from a sheet.

Tab Height

Cut Tab Height

Note: Tab Height is be measured up from the bottom of the cut. Keeping a thin tab height allows the user to create tabs that are easily snapped off from the sheet. Commonly referred to as Shaker Tabs.

Positioning Method

Determines how to position the tabs on the toolpath.

Contour - Uses the entire length of the contour to place tabs within. Tabs are more likely to be evenly spaced when compared with the Segment option.

Contour

Evenly spaced tabs

Segment - Uses segments, which are areas of the toolpath between two points, to place the tabs within. If the Tab Distance is larger than the segment length, then the segment is ignored, and no tab is placed within the segment.

Segment

One segment used

Tabs per Contour

Specifies how many tabs to place within each contour selection.

One tab

Three tabs

Tab Distance

Places tabs along the profile by the specified distance.

When using the Segment method, if the specified distance is larger than a toolpath segment, then no tab is placed on that segment.

Method = Contour
Distance = 25mm
4 tabs

Method = Segment
Distance = 25mm
3 tabs

Tab Positioning

Specifies how tabs are placed.

  • By Distance - Lets you specify a Tab Distance to place tabs at an equal distance around the profile. Using the Positioning Method drop-down menu, you can choose to place tabs along the contour or along segments of a toolpath.
  • Number of tabs - Lets you specify the Number of tabs to place at an equal distance around the profile.

Note: Tabs are placed perpendicular to the geometry.

Manual Tabs

In addition to any automatically generated tabs, you can add manual tabs to help secure the part in its position during the machining process.

Click anywhere along the contour to add tabs.

After adding a tab, you can adjust its position by clicking and dragging the tab:

To delete a tab that is manually placed, from the canvas, Ctrl + Left click (windows) or Cmd + Left click (mac) on the tab.

Tip: If you want tabs that are only manually specified, from the Tab Positioning drop-down menu, select Number of tabs and set Tabs per Contour to 0.

Manual Tabs

Specifies zones on the part where tabs can't be placed automatically.

Click two points on the profile of the part to specify a no tab zone. The shortest distance between the two points becomes the no tab zone. If necessary, no tab zones can overlap with each other.

Having tabs on a part can mean that further work, such as grinding, sanding, or filing is required to clean up the part. As an example, you can use the no tab zones to specify areas where you don't want any tabs to be placed as certain geometry can make it difficult to perform the necessary clean-up work afterwards.

Tip: If a tab is placed automatically in an area that is undesired, you can specify that area as a no tab zone so that no tab is placed. Instead, you can manually place a tab in that area, and then manually adjust the position of the tab slightly to a more desired area.

Tangential Extension Distance

Used on open contours to extend the beginning and end of the selected chain or multiple chains. This creates a tangent linear extension based on the angle of the start and endpoints. This is an extension of the selected geometry.

No Extension

12mm Extension

If the extension distance causes an overlap of a single chain, the intersection will be trimmed into a closed boundary.

Shown with Multiple
Finish Passes set to 2

Single pass
Long extension

Tangential Extension has options for creating a different length on each end of the chain.

Note: You can use the Stock Contours option to force the toolpath past the defined Stock or a selected boundary. Great for irregular shapes. For an additional extenstion to the toolpath, go to the Passes Tab and use the Tangential Fragment Extension Distance.

Separate Tangential End Extension

Select this option to enter a different end extension length value.

16mm Start Extension
5mm End Extension

Tangential End Extension Distance

Specifies the distance to extend the end position.

16mm Start Extension
5mm End Extension

Tangential Fragment Extension Distance

Used on open contours to extend the beginning and end of the calculated toolpath. This creates a tangent linear extension based on the angle of the start and endpoints. This extension can be used in combination with the Geometry - Tangential Extension Distance.

No Extension

12mm Extension

Overlaping extensions of a single chain, will not be trimmed.

Shown with Multiple
Finish Passes set to 2

Single pass
Long extension

Note: You can use the Stock Contours option to force the toolpath past the defined Stock or a selected boundary. Great for irregular shapes. If you need a different extension for each end of the cut, you can use Geometry Tab - Tangential Extension Distance.

Roll Around Corners

Use Helical Leads

Enable to use helical lead in/out movements instead of circular lead in/out movements.

Linear Lead Length

Specifies the length of the linear leads.

Dwell Before Retract

Select to specfiy the amount of time to dwell before making the retract move, for the Chip Break Distance. This keeps the bottom of the hole smooth for when the tool returns on the next peck.

Typically a dwelling time between 1/4 second and 1 second is sufficient.

Example: To dwell for 1/4 second, specify 0.25 or 1/4 in this field.

When post processing a drill cycle, the dwell time is specified as one of the drill cycle parameters (typically P), and in most cases it is output in milliseconds (ms).

250ms dwell time in G82

Break Through Distance

Specifies the distance above the bottom of the hole depth, where the cycle should adjust feed and speed, before breaking through the bottom. This value is measured up from the bottom of the hole.

Can be used for any material that might chip or crack as the tool breaks through the bottom of the hole.

Distance above the hole bottom

Break Through Feedrate

Controls the feedrate to apply, when the Break Through Distance is reached. This can be increased or decreased depending on the characteristics of the material being drilled.

Break Through Spindle Speed

Controls the spindle speed to apply, when the Break Through Distance is reached. This can be increased or decreased depending on the characteristics of the material being drilled.

Use Multiple Steps

Select to create multiple XY steps for the cut.

Shown with 2 steps

Number Of Steps

Specifies the number of passes in the XY plane.

Shown with 2 steps

Direction

Specifies the cut direction as a Climb or Conventional cut.

Climb Cut

Conventional Cut

Repeat Pass

Select to create an additional finish pass at the final depth.

This could be called a spring pass, to remove deflection from the cutting tool and create a smoother finish on the bottom.

Touch Check Surfaces

This setting inverts the meaning for check surfaces. When enabled, the check surfaces are the ones that must be touched within the given clearance while the remaining surfaces are avoided.

Check Surfaces

Disabled

Enabled

Go To Home

Use Fixed Lead Direction

Sets the lead directions relative to the 0 degree reference of XZ coordinate system. When disabled, the leads are relative to the cutting direction of the individual pass.

Checked XZ Reference

Unchecked Relative to the cut

Up/Down Direction

Options that control the direction of the finishing passes.

Up and Down

Only Down

Only Up

Notice how the Only Down and Only Up options result in a discontinuous finish pass; with the tool either exiting or entering the finish pass from the center of the groove.

Pass Overlap

Specifies the overlap distance used for finish passes split due to Only Up and Only Down machining directions.

Pass Overlap at 0mm

Pass Overlap set at 3mm

Setup Type

Displays the machining operation type. Example: 2D Contour, Drill, Flow.

Model Unit

Scale

Specifies the scale of the model.

Stock Mode

Specifies the size and shape of the raw stock material.

In milling, turning or mill/turn, and cutting setups, you generate toolpaths to remove stock. In additive setups, you generate toolpaths to add material to stock. The stock can be from a fixed- or relative-sized rectangle, cylinder, or tube, from a solid body, or from a preceding setup.

Fixed/Relative Size Box
Rectangular stock

Fixed/Relative Size Cylinder
Cylindrical stock

Fixed/Relative Size Tube
Tubular stock

From Solid
Additive starting stock and
irregular-shaped stock like castings

From preceding setup
Creates a stock that matches the stock defined in the previous setup. This matches the size, but not the orientation or WCS.

Note: Fixed- and relative-sized stock include options for shifting the stock reference position.

Select Axis

Controls which axis the stock rotates about. When selected, lets you select an edge on the model as the axis of rotation. When deselected, the stock automatically rotates about the Z axis of the setup’s work coordinate system (WCS).

Stock Diameter

Sets the diameter of the stock. For fixed- and relative-size tubes, this is the outer diameter.

Stock Inner Diameter

Sets the inner diameter of the tube of stock.

Length

Sets the length of the stock.

Model Position

Determines the position of the model in the stock. Center positions the model in the center of the stock. Offset from Front and Offset from Back position the model so that it is flush with the front, or back, face of the stock.

Center

Offset from Front

Model Position

Sets the distance between the model and the front, or back, face of the stock when using a Model Position of Offset from Front or Offset from Back.

Round Up to Nearest

Sets the rounding up increment for the final stock size.

Reverse Direction

Specifies which direction of the extrusion from sketch to be reversed.

Stock Offset Mode

Specifies how stock is added to the model.

No additional stock

Add stock to sides
and top-bottom

Add stock to all sides

No additional stock - No offset values are added to the stock size.

Add stock to sides and top-bottom - Symmetrical stock offset for all sides. Unique values for top and bottom offsets.

Add stock to all sides - Unique values for all offset directions.

Stock Side Offset

Specifies the additional stock on the sides.

Stock Top Offset

Specifies the additional stock on the top.

Stock Bottom Offset

Specifies the additional stock on the bottom.

Stock +X Offset

Specifies the offset of the stock.

Stock -X Offset

Specifies the offset of the stock.

Stock +Y Offset

Specifies the offset of the stock.

Stock -Y Offset

Specifies the offset of the stock.

Stock +Z Offset

Specifies the offset of the stock.

Stock -Z Offset

Specifies the offset of the stock.

Use Stock Radius

Specifies the radius of cylindrical stock instead of using an offset value.

This option is helpful when working with bar stock that is ordered at a given diameter or radius.

Stock Radius

Specifies the radius of the stock.

Radial Stock Offset

Specifies the radial offset of the stock.

Continue Machining From Previous Setup

WCS Origin

Specifies the location of the Work Coordinate System (datum) for the job relative to the stock.

WCS Origin Selection

The orientation of the WCS above is defined with the WCS orientation selection box.

Home Position

Specifies the home position along Z.

Spindle

Work Offset

Displays the number of the current work offset.

Multiple WCS Offsets

Enable to specify that the workpiece is to be duplicated.

Work Duplicates

Specifies the total number of instances of the part you want to machine.

Note: The value you enter should include the current setup, plus the desired number of duplicates.

WCS Offset Increment

Specifies the offset number increment that the post processor uses to output the correct work offset for the machine controller when using multiple work offsets.

Operation Order

Specifies the ordering of the individual operations in this setup in the NC code.

Preserve Order – orders the operations according to the layout of the toolpaths that you have generated, and processes the operations setup by setup.

Order by Operation – switches between the multiple offsets, performing each operation on each setup before continuing to the next operation.

Order by Tool – orders the operations by loading a tool and completing all the operations for that tool in each setup before continuing to the next tool.

Stock Contours

Specifies the perimeter of the stock that needs to be faced.

Disabled

Enabled

Disabled - The perimeter of the stock as defined in the Setup is used.

Enabled - Selected faces or edges are projected to the model top.

Stock Contours

When checked, the toolpath is calculated to consider the boundaries of the defined Stock or a Selected boundary. This provides additional clearance for the Lead in and Lead out moves.

Toolpath is calculated
against the Stock boundary,
shown in yellow

Toolpath is calculated
against a Selected boundary,
shown in yellow

In the above example, a single edge is selected for a Contour and additional Roughing Passes are defined. Stock Contours extends the toolpath to clear the edges of the stock area. It can also limit the number of Roughing passes within that area.

Stock Selections

Select an edge or a sketch boundary. The toolpath will start outside the selected boundary. This allows you to create a toolpath that closely fits the contour of the part.

Toolpath is calculated
against a Selected boundary,
shown in yellow

In the above example, a single edge is selected for a Contour and additional Roughing Passes are defined. Stock Contours extends the toolpath to clear the edges of the stock area. It can also limit the number of Roughing passes within that area.

Geometry

Closed or open boundaries can be machined by selecting Faces, Edges or Sketches. You can remove stock from the inside of a pocket or the outside of a standing boss.

Closed area Pocket

Open area Pocket

Standing Boss

If you select Faces that have holes or pockets, Adaptive will assume those openings are already cleared and avoid machining them. Use Edge selection for pockets with holes or pockets inside of the pocket. For standing bosses select the outer boundary of the boss and check the Stock Contours option shown below. The toolpath will be calculated between the selected boundary and the outer stock area.

Pocket Selections

Select any Face, Edge or Sketch to define the machining boundary. Use Edge selection for areas with holes or pockets inside of pockets. For standing bosses select the outer boundary of the boss and check the Stock Contours option shown below. The toolpath will be calculated between the selected boundary and the outer stock area.

Closed Pocket Face Selection

Closed Pocket Toolpath

Open Pocket Face Selection

Open Pocket Toolpath

Boss Edge Selection with Stock

Area Cleared with Boss Standing

If you select Faces with holes or pockets, Adaptive will assume those openings are already cleared and avoid machining them. Use Edge or Sketch to select the machining area.

Stock Contours

When checked, the toolpath is calculated to consider the boundaries of the defined Stock or a selected boundary. The default boundary is the Stock box specified in the Setup. You can also select Edges from the model or a Sketch boundary. This provides additional clearance for the Lead in and Lead out moves. This can limit or extend the stock machining area. Leave unchecked for closed boundary pockets.

Calculated from the Stock

A Sketch larger than the Stock

The selected area can be any size or shape

Note: This is not a containment boundary, since the tool will approach from outside the selected area.

Stock Selections

Select a closed boundary to define the machining area. You can select any Edges from the model or a Sketch boundary. This can limit or extend the stock machining area. No selection is needed to machine the Stock box specified in the Setup. Selecting a boundary larger than the stock extends the cutting area. This can be useful for irregular stock sizes. The selected machining boundary can be any shape.

Calculated from the Stock - No selection required

A Sketch larger than the Stock

The selected area can be any size or shape

Note: This is not a containment boundary, since the tool will approach from outside the selected area.

Geometry

Closed or open boundaries can be machined by selecting Faces, Edges or Sketches. You can remove stock from the inside of a pocket or the outside of a standing boss.

Closed area Pocket

Open area Pocket

Standing Boss

If you select Faces that have holes or pockets, Pocket will assume those openings are already cleared and avoid machining them. Use Edge selection for pockets with holes or pockets inside of the pocket. For standing bosses select the outer boundary of the boss and check the Stock Contours option shown below. The toolpath will be calculated between the selected boundary and the outer stock area.

Pocket Selections

Select any Face, Edge or Sketch to define the machining boundary. Use Edge selection for areas with holes or pockets inside of pockets. For standing bosses select the outer boundary of the boss and check the Stock Contours option shown below. The toolpath will be calculated between the selected boundary and the outer stock area.

Closed Pocket Face Selection

Closed Pocket Toolpath

Open Pocket Face Selection

Open Pocket Toolpath

Area Cleared with Boss Standing

If you select Faces with holes or pockets, Pocket will assume those openings are already cleared and avoid machining them. Use Edge or Sketch to select the machining area.

Stock Contours

When checked, the toolpath is calculated to consider the boundaries of the defined Stock or a selected boundary. The default boundary is the Stock box specified in the Setup. You can also select Edges from the model or a Sketch boundary. This provides additional clearance for the Lead in and Lead out moves. This can limit or extend the stock machining area. Leave unchecked for closed boundary pockets.
