A Sketch larger than the Stock

The selected area can be any size or shape

Note: This is not a containment boundary, since the tool will approach from outside the selected area.

Stock Selections

Select a closed boundary to define the machining area. You can select any Edges from the model or a Sketch boundary. This can limit or extend the stock machining area. No selection is needed to machine the Stock box specified in the Setup. Selecting a boundary larger than the stock extends the cutting area. This can be useful for irregular stock sizes. The selected machining boundary can be any shape.

Calculated from the Stock - No selection required

A Sketch larger than the Stock

The selected area can be any size or shape

Note: This is not a containment boundary, since the tool will approach from outside the selected area.

Stock Contours

No Selections Is Required For The Face Toolpath. The system automatically faces the Stock defined in the job Setup parameters. If you want to Face a specific area, use the Stock Selections option.

Facing the stock boundary

Facing the stock boundary

No selection is required to machine the default Stock.

Stock Selections

No Selections Is Required For The Face Toolpath. The system automatically faces the Stock defined in the job Setup parameters.

You can select any size or shape area to Face. This area can be an Edge selection or a Sketch selection. The stock area to machine is shown in Yellow.

Default stock area

Edge selection of Facing boundary

Chaining Tolerance

Used when chaining a boundary or contour. Any gaps closer than the chaining tolerance are automatically merged.

Advanced parameter. Only shown when advanced mode is enabled

Outer Corner Mode

When machining outer corners, it may be necessary to avoid rolling around the corner in order to leave the corner perfectly sharp. The Outer corner mode setting lets you machine outer corners in three different ways.

Roll around corner - Keeps contact with the corner throughout the motion.

Keep sharp corner - Continues the toolpath to a single point corner, losing contact with the material temporarily.

Keep sharp corner with loop - Similar to Keep sharp corner, but also performs a horizontal lead-out and lead-in at the corner.

Roll around corner

Keep sharp corner

Keep sharp corner with loop

Outer Corner Mode

When chamfering corners, it may be necessary to avoid rolling around the corner in order to leave the corner perfectly sharp.

Roll around corner - Keeps contact with the corner throughout the motion. Useful for smoother machine motion.

Keep sharp corner - Continues the toolpath to a single corner point, losing contact with the material temporarily. Useful for machines that are not suited to handle arc movements.

Roll around corner

Keep sharp corner

Pitch Diameter Offset

Creates a positive or negative diameter offset from the selected geometry.

Pitch Diameter Offset

Used to set the full depth of the thread milling toolpath.

Pitch Diameter Offset
The difference between the Major "D" and the Minor "d" diameter.
The thread depth will automatically be 1/2 of this value.

Note: Required if the hole is drawn to the Minor size,
or if the Boss/Cylinder is drawn to the Major size.

Comparison Tolerance

Used when comparing if two entities are the same, for example, if two holes have the same diameter.

Advanced parameter. Only shown when advanced mode is enabled

Number

The number used to select the tool on the CNC machine.

Length Offset

The index of the tool length offset.
This parameter is normally set when using tools with multiple tips indexed by length.

Diameter Offset

The index of the tool diameter offset.

Compensation Offset

The index of the tool compensation offset used for turning.

Manual Tool Change

Enable to force a manual tool change on machines with an automatic tool changer.

Break Control

When Enabled additional information is output to the final NC code that checks for tool breakage after use.

Note: Requires a postprocessor that supports this function in your machine.

Coolant

The type of coolant used with the tool.

Material

The tool material.

Description

A textual description of the tool.
This description is included in the tool name shown throughout the program.

Comment

A textual comment for the tool.
The comment is typically included in the post-processed output.

Vendor

The vendor of the tool.
Use this to identify the specific tool used.

Product ID

The vendors' catalog identifier for the tool.
Use this to order replacements for this specific tool.

The number used to identify the item.

Type

The type of the tool.

Orientation

Specifies the angle of the tool with respect to the cutting direction.

Set the angle based on the orientation of the tool at the machine.

0.0 degree Orientation

90. degree Orientation

180. degree Orientation

270. degree Orientation

Compensation

Specifies the toolpath compensation position.

Select the Compensation point based on how you reference your tools at the machine.

Tip Tangent

Tip

Tip Center

Insert Center

Kerf Width

Kerf is the width of the material that is removed by the process.
Process types are listed here from most precise to least precise.
Laser, Waterjet, Oxy-Fuel and Plasma.

Kerf Cutting Width

Note: Kerf is the width of the cut. Kerf can be controlled at the machine
by the size of the nozzle, speed of the cut and thickness of the material.
Consult your machine manual for the best Kerf cutting information.

Quality control

This changes how feedrates are determined for cutting.

* Machine uses feeds - feedrates can be selected by the user.
* Machine uses quality - feedrates will be output based on the
Cutting Mode selection and the machines feedrate calculation tables.

Note: Some machines use internal tables to determine feedrates
based on the required quality of the finish (Cutting Mode), material
thickness and material type.

Unit

The tool unit.

Diameter

The diameter of the cutter.

Tip Diameter

The tip diameter of the cutter.

For a pointed tip, set this value to 0.

Corner Radius

The corner radius of the cutter.

Taper Angle

The taper angle.

Tip Angle

The angle of the tool tip.
This angle is used to calculate the extra depth needed to break the tool through the material.

Flute Length

The tool flute length.

Shoulder Length

The tool shoulder length.

Body Length

The tool body length.

Shaft Diameter

The tool shaft/arbor diameter.

Thread Pitch

The pitch of the tap thread, specified as the vertical distance between the teeth of the tap.

Feed & Speed

Determines how fast the tool moves along the material (feed) and how fast the tool rotates in the spindle (speed). These parameters are interrelated by various expressions.

Following the tool manufacturer's recommendations for feeds and speeds helps to remove material at an efficient rate and ensure a longer tool life. With the material information of the tool and the stock, consult the tool manufacturer's manual for the recommended surface speed and feed per tooth, which Fusion 360 uses to determine the feeds and speeds.

Tip: Some tool manufacturers provide the actual feeds and speeds, which you can enter directly.

Feed & Speed

Defines the distance the tool travels during one revolution of the part (feed) and how fast the spindle rotates (speed). These parameters are interrelated by various expressions

Following the tool manufacturer's recommendations for feeds and speeds helps to remove material at an efficient rate and ensure a longer tool life. With the material information of the tool and the stock, consult the tool manufacturer's manual for the recommended surface speed and feed per tooth, which Fusion 360 uses to determine the feeds and speeds.

Tip: Some tool manufacturers provide the actual feeds and speeds, which you can enter directly.

Feed & Speed

Determines how fast the tool moves along the material (feed) and the rotational speed of the spindle (speed). These parameters are interrelated by various expressions.

Following the tool manufacturer's recommendations for feeds and speeds helps to remove material at an efficient rate and ensure a longer tool life. With the material information of the tool and the stock, consult the tool manufacturer's manual for the recommended surface speed and feed per tooth, which Fusion 360 uses to determine the feeds and speeds.

Tip: Some tool manufacturers provide the actual feeds and speeds, which you can enter directly.

Feed & Speed

Determines how fast the tool moves into the material (feed) and how fast the tool rotates in the spindle (speed). These parameters are interrelated by various expressions.

Feed is linear - Speed is rotary

Following the tool manufacturer's recommendations for feeds and speeds helps to remove material at an efficient rate and ensure a longer tool life. With the material information of the tool and the stock, consult the tool manufacturer's manual for the recommended surface speed and feed per tooth, which Fusion 360 uses to determine the feeds and speeds.

Tip: Some tool manufacturers provide the actual feeds and speeds, which you can enter directly.

Feed & Speed

Defines the speed at which the probe moves during the cycle.

Note: Some feedrates are predefined by the on-machine cycles and cannot be changed from Fusion 360.

Feed & Speed

Defines the speed at which the probe moves during the cycle.

Note: Some feedrates are predefined by the on-machine cycles and cannot be changed from Fusion 360.

Lead-In Feedrate

Defines the speed of the probe during lead moves, which are performed before and after the probe touches the part. Lead moves are displayed in green in the canvas.

If the probe is set up to perform two touches, the first touch is at the Lead-In Feedrate and then the second touch is at the Measure Feedrate.

Note: Increasing Lead-In Feedrate does not change the accuracy of the measurements, as it does not affect the measure moves. However, the value can cause false triggers if the acceleration and deceleration of the machine is too high, triggering the probe.

Preset

Contains any predefined Cutting Data you have created. This is a way to quickly populate the Spindle Speed and Feedrate parameters, based on your favorite settings. These Cutting Data presets are saved with the current tool.

Select a preset from the list in the pull down.

To Add a Preset:

  • Press Select to enter the Tool Library.
  • Select the Edit Tool icon.
  • On the Cutting Data tab, icon.
  • Give it a descriptive name and enter your preferred speeds & feeds.

Spindle Speed

Sets the rotational speed of the spindle, typically given in revolutions per minute (RPM). The spindle speed is typically expressed as an S code in the NC code.

Cutting with a spindle speed that is determined by using the tool manufacturer's recommendations helps ensure a good surface finish on parts. You can enter a spindle speed manually, or let Fusion 360 calculate the spindle speed when you enter a recommended surface speed.

Note: You may want to reduce the spindle speed depending on if you have a low-powered machine, lack of coolant, or clamping fixtures that have low clamping pressure.

Spindle Speed

Sets the rotational speed of the spindle, measured in revolutions per minute (RPM). Spindle speed is constant throughout the operation.

Spindle Speed is rotary motion

Cutting with a spindle speed that is determined by using the tool manufacturer's recommendations helps ensure a good surface finish on parts. You can enter a spindle speed manually, or let Fusion 360 calculate the spindle speed when you enter a recommended surface speed.

Note: You may want to reduce the spindle speed depending on if you have a low powered machine, lack of coolant, or clamping fixtures that have low clamping pressure.

Spindle Speed

Sets the rotational speed of the spindle, typically given in revolutions per minute (RPM). The spindle speed is expressed as an S code in the NC code.

Drilling with a spindle speed that is determined by using the tool manufacturer's recommendations helps ensure a good surface finish for your holes. You can enter a spindle speed manually, or let Fusion 360 calculate the spindle speed when you enter a value for the Surface Speed.

Note: You may want to reduce the spindle speed depending on if you have a low-powered machine, lack of coolant, or clamping fixtures that have low clamping pressure.

Surface Speed

Specifies the speed of the cutting tip of the tool as it goes past the material. The surface speed is expressed in units of distance along the workpiece's surface per unit of time.

Cutting with a surface speed based on the tool manufacturer's recommendations helps reduce tool wear. Fusion 360 uses the surface speed and the tool diameter to calculate the spindle speed.

Surface Speed

Specifies the speed of the material as it moves past the cutting tip of the tool. The surface speed is expressed in units of distance along the workpiece's surface per unit of time.

Cutting with a surface speed based on the tool manufacturer's recommendations helps reduce tool wear. Fusion 360 uses the surface speed and the tool diameter to calculate the spindle speed.

Maximum Spindle Speed

Specifies the maximum spindle speed limit when Constant Surface Speed is used.

With CSS, the spindle speed increases as the tool gets closer to the spindle centerline. This limits the RPM to keep large, potentially out of balance parts, from being thrown out of the chuck.

Surface Speed

Specifies the speed of a point on the outer diameter of the tool as it goes into the material.

Drilling with a surface speed based on the tool manufacturer's recommendations helps reduce tool wear. The Surface Speed is linked to the Spindle Speed and the Tool Diameter.

Surface Speed

The speed of the cutting tip of the tool as it goes past the material. The surface speed is expressed in units of distance along the workpiece's surface per unit of time.

Cutting with a surface speed based on the tool manufacturer's recommendations helps reduce tool wear. Fusion 360 uses the surface speed and the cutting point diameter to calculate the spindle speed.

Ramp Spindle Speed

Sets the speed of the spindle when performing a ramp move, which is a move that allows the tool to enter the block of material gradually.

The spindle needs to operate at lower speeds when performing a ramp move. This is because a ramp move engages with more material than a normal cutting move.

Note: The ramp spindle speed may not be supported by all post processors.

Number of Flutes

The number of cutting flutes on the tool.

Cutting Feedrate

Controls the feedrate at which the tool moves along the workpiece. The cutting feedrate is expressed in units of distance over time, and by an F code in the NC code.

Cutting with a feedrate that is recommended by the tool manufacturer helps ensure a good surface finish on parts. You can enter a cutting feedrate manually, or let Fusion 360 calculate the cutting feedrate when you enter a recommended feed per tooth.

Cutting Feedrate

Specifies the distance the cutting tool moves during one spindle revolution. The cutting feedrate is expressed in units of distance over time.

The feed mode can be set for feed/minute or feed/revolution. Cutting with a feedrate that is recommended by the tool manufacturer helps ensure a good finish on parts.

Feed Per Tooth

Specifies the amount of material each tooth removes per spindle revolution.

Cutting with a feed per tooth based on the tool manufacturer's recommendations helps remove material at an efficient rate. A feed per tooth that is too high can lead to tool breakage. A feed per tooth that is too low can cause excess vibrations and dull the sharp edges of the tool.  Fusion 360 uses the feed per tooth, the number of teeth the tool has, and the spindle speed to calculate the cutting feedrate.

Retract Feedrate

Feedrate used when retracting and not using rapid (G0) moves.

Retract Feedrate

Feedrate at which the tool moves back to the Retract Height before moving on to the next cutting pass.

The Retract Feedrate is not linked to any other value in the Tool tab and can therefore be set independently. The Retract Height can be defined in the Heights tab.

Use Constant Surface Speed

Select to control the RPM based on how fast the material should move across the cutting edge of the tool.

Engages a machine function that changes the RPM of the spindle based on the current cutting diameter. The RPM increases as the cutting tool tip moves closer to the part centerline. This keeps a consistent amount of material moving past the tool tip during the cut.

When deselected the machine will use a constant spindle speed.

Use Feed Per Revolution

Select to input the feedrate as units per revolution of the spindle.

Deselect to input the feedrate as distance over time.

Cutting Feedrate Per Revolution

Specifies the distance the tool cuts into the material for each 360 degree rotation of the spindle once the tool is fully engaged.

Lead-In Feedrate Per Revolution

Specifies the distance the tool cuts into the material for each 360 degree rotation of the spindle as the tool approaches and initially enters the material.

Lead-Out Feedrate Per Revolution

Specifies the distance the tool cuts into the material for each 360 degree rotation of the spindle as the tool exits the material.

Grooving

Use this to allow or restrict undercut toolpath motion. Can be used to keep the tool from dipping into channels along the diameter, face or end of the part.

Don't allow grooving

Allow Radial grooving

Allow Axial grooving

Allow Radial and Axial Grooving

Note: Tool geometry will determine the effectiveness of clearing an area.

Tool Orientation

Use this option if your lathe turret has a programmable B axis. Your post processor will need to support posting from this value. The toolpath pass direction is automatically rotated to suit this value to avoid tool breakage or deflection.

Tool Orientation @ 0 degrees

Tool Orientation @ -15 degrees

Tool Orientation

Use this option if your lathe turret has a programmable B axis. Your post processor will need to support posting from this value. The toolpath pass direction is automatically rotated to suit this value to avoid tool breakage or deflection.

Tool Orientation @ 0 degrees

Tool Orientation @ 45 degrees

Chamfer Angle

The angle of the chamfer measured from the Z-axis.

Chamfer Extension

Distance by which to extend the chamfer cutting pass.

Groove Side Alignment

Positions the insert with respect to the groove geometry.

Back - Positions the insert's trailing edge (2) with respect to the selected groove positions.

Middle - Positions the centerline of the insert with respect to the selected groove positions.

Front - Positions the insert's leading edge (1) with respect to the selected groove positions.

Groove Tip Alignment

Determines the radial distance that the insert should reach.

Cut-through - Extends the tool tip radially past the selected groove positions, in the negative direction for Outside grooving, and in the positive direction for Inside grooving. The extension distance equals the tool corner radius. Select Outside or Inside grooving from the Turning Mode drop-down on the Tool tab.

Tip - Stops the tool tip at the selected radial distance.

Transfer Stock

Specifies that the stock should be clamped for use on the other spindle.

Apply Back From Front

Makes the stock backside offset apply from the front side.

Fade Thread End

Enable this setting to fade out the thread at the end.

Use Cycle

Enable to output the roughing as a canned cycle for your control.

This can reduce the amount of code generated for the NC program. It will also limit some of the advanced options for the Profile Roughing toolpath, since most canned cycles only create a basic boundary cut.

Note: This may require postprocessor modifications specific to your machine control.

Use Even Stepdowns

Enable to create equal distances between machining passes.

Example: Suppose you are machining a profile with a depth of 23 mm and a maximum stepdown = 10 mm.

With Use even stepdowns enabled - you get three passes with the first value at -7.666 mm, the second at -15.3333 mm, and the third at -23 mm.

With Use even stepdowns disabled - again you get three passes, the first at -10 mm, the second at -20 mm, and the third at -23 mm.

Lead To Center

When enabled the lead in/out movement will start from the center of the hole or pocket.

Lead to Center Enabled

Allow Plunging Outside Stock

Instead of machining the material inside the contour of a selected area, enabling this parameter allows you to remove the material outside the selected contour by picking an additional stock contour.

Disable this parameter to force ramping in stock.

Minimum Tilt

Specifies the minimum tilt angle that the tool must always maintain, measured from the specified tool orientation Z axis.

1 - Minimum tilt
2 - Maximum tilt

Tip: The minimum tilt can be thought of as a conical boundary around the specified tool orientation Z axis.

Clamp From inside

Order By Step

When enabled, each roughing and finishing step is machined to the full depth before moving to the next step.

Disabled

Enabled

Use Morphed Spiral Machining

Enable to create a constant spiral move toolpath for the pocket. This can provide a smooth run on the machine.

Standard pocket toolpath

Morphed spiral pocket toolpath

Flow Mode

Check Against Model

Compensation Type

Description

Displays the machining operation type and number. Example: 2DPocket1, Bore3, Parallel6.

Position

Dwelling Depth

Specifies the depth below the stock to dwell. This can be used to clear chips for through-holes before retracting.

This is not implemented in all cycles, for all postprocessors.

Feedrate

Displays the toolpath feedrate using the current units (mm or in) per minute.

Attached Holder

Holder Comment

Holder Library

Include Obstructed Holes

Clamp From Inside

Chuck Model

Program Comment

Specifies a comment to be included in the NC code at the top of the NC program file.

Fusion 360 passes the information to post processor, and it is included in the header block of the NC code.

Continue Rest Machining

Uses the stock at the end of the previous setup to continue rest machining.

When deselected, the stock at the start of the previous setup is used.

Fixture

Select the geometry in the model that represents the fixture.

Fixture

Specifies which fixtures, such as vices, chucks, and clamps, the toolpath should avoid during machining.

Specifying fixtures helps to ensure more accurate collision avoidance between the toolpath and the selected bodies.

Fixture Attachment

Specifies the coordinate system of the fixture and components.

This is particularly useful when using third-party verification software, which needs to know the position of the fixture attach locations relative to the WCS.

Home Position

Enter a value to specify the home position along the Z axis.

Arrangement

Automatically arranges the selected components so that they fit inside the additive machine’s build volume.

Depending on the type of additive machine selected in the setup, you can choose to automatically arrange in 2D or 3D. Components that cannot be automatically arranged are left outside the build volume and are colored red.

Arrangement

Automatically arranges multiple components so that they fit inside the additive machine’s build volume.

When you finish creating the setup, you choose which components to arrange. Depending on the type of additive machine selected in the setup, you can choose to automatically arrange components in 2D or 3D. Components that cannot be automatically arranged are left outside the build volume and are colored red.

Automatic

Automatically places bodies onto the build platform of your selected machine.

A single body is placed in the center of the build platform. Multiple bodies are placed so that they do not intersect each other. If multiple bodies cannot all be placed on the build platform, some are placed outside of the build platform and colored red to show that they lie outside the build volume.

Arrange in 2D/3D

Places all the selected components within the additive machine’s build volume so that they do not intersect with each other.

If the setup is using an additive machine with FFF, SLA, or MPBF capabilities, you can arrange only in 2D, that is, on the build platform. If the setup is using an additive machine with MJF or SLS capabilities, you can arrange in 2D or 3D. For a component to fit inside the build volume, it must have at least 1 mm free space in its X, Y, and Z directions.

Arrange in 2D

Arrange in 3D

Model

Expand to select the models/solids that are considered for the toolpath calculation.

Model

Use this to specify the models/solids that are considered for the toolpath calculation.

Model Scale

Model Unit

Multiple WCS Offsets

Controls whether the toolpaths in the setup apply to a single work offset, or to multiple work offsets on the machine.

Select this option to duplicate all the toolpaths in the setup to multiple offsets that are set up on the machine. This is useful if you have identical jobs to machine. Additional settings appear for you to specify the number of instances you want to machine.

Program

Specifies NC program information.

Fusion 360 passes this information to the post processor and adds it to the header of the NC code.

Program Name/Number

Specifies the name or number of the file containing the NC code.

Fusion 360 passes this information to the post processor, and it will be the name of the file used on the machine controller.

Machine WCS

Controls how to use Work Coordinate System (WCS) offsets on the machine.

You can use a single work offset or create multiple offsets if you have identical jobs to machine.

Spindle

Select the spindle to machine the part. Only applies to machines with sub-spindle capabilities.

Primary Spindle

Secondary Spindle

Work Coordinate Offset (WCS)

Set the orientation to reflect the machining plane.

On a Mill the Z should point up. On a Lathe the Z should point thru the center line of the part.

Mill WCS Reference

Turn WCS Reference

Work Coordinate System (WCS)

Options for setting the orientation of the part.

Revolution Axis

Determines the axis of rotation for the stock. In the canvas, click an edge on the model.

Z Axis (Rotary Axis)

Select any circular edge or cylindrical face to set the Z axis orientation.

Z should point thru the center line of the part. Normally Z+ should point away from the chuck on the primary spindle

Selection shown in blue

Selection shown in blue

X Axis

Specifies the X axis orientation of the part. For simple 2 axis turned parts this may not be needed.

For parts that require live tooling operations, you can use this to set the X reference position.

X Axis Orientation

X Set to the Line

Select any edge or shetch line pointing thru Z to set the reference.

Stock Bottom Offset

Ground Stock at Model Origin

When enabled this forces the stock to be in relationship to the origin of the Model. In the Browser, expand Models - Origin, to view the Model origin.

Stock Width

The width of the raw stock in the X axis.

Stock Depth

The depth of the raw stock in the Y axis.

Stock Height

The height of the raw stock in the Z axis.

Model Position

Select the X reference for offsetting the stock block.

Model Position

Select the Y reference for offsetting the stock block.

Model Position

Select the Z reference for offsetting the stock block.

Stock Offset

Specifies the X distance to shift the stock from the selected Model Position or the Model Origin. Can be a positive or negative value.

Stock Offset

Specifies the Y distance to shift the stock from the selected Model Position or the Model Origin. Can be a positive or negative value.

Stock Offset

Specifies the Z distance to shift the stock from the selected Model Position or the Model Origin. Can be a positive or negative value.

Stock Height

Stock Offset

Backside Stock Offset

Specifies the distance to machine beyond the backside of the model.

Frontside Stock Offset

Specifies the distance to machine beyond the frontside of the model.

Stock Revolved Sketch

Stock Sketch

Stock Solid

Specifies the body as the raw stock material.

In the canvas, click a body. In additive setups, the stock is the base on which material is deposited to create a part.

Machine

Selecting the Machine Type defines which strategies will be available.

Press Select to view the available Machine Types. Picking the machining process, filters the list of machines.

Milling - Machines with rotary spindles and 2 - 5 axis of motion.

Turning - 2 axis Lathes and Lathes with mill/turn configurations.

Cutting - Waterjet, Laser or Plasma machines.

Additive - 3D printing using plastics or metal

Machine

Options for selecting a CMM (coordinate measuring machine) from the Machine Library and editing the machine configuration.

Machine

Lets you select previously used machines or pick None to remove a select machine. Selecting the machine type defines which strategies will be available.

Press Select to view the available Machine Types. Picking the machining process filters the list of machines.

Selecting the Machine Type defines which strategies will be available.

Milling - Machines with rotary spindles and 2 - 5 axis of motion.

Turning - 2 axis Lathes and Lathes with mill/turn configurations.

Cutting - Waterjet, Laser or Plasma machines.

Additive - 3D printing using plastics or metal.

Select

View the available Machine Types and select a machine from the list.

Selecting the Machine Type defines which toolpath strategies will be available. Depending on your choice, additional machine dependent parameters may be revealed. Select your machine from the list or a pick a generic machine representation.

Milling - Machines with rotary spindles and 2 - 5 axis of motion.

Turning - 2 axis Lathes and Lathes with mill/turn configurations.

Cutting - Waterjet, Laser or Plasma machines.

Additive - 3D printing using plastics or metal

Print Settings

Opens the Print Setting Library where you select which print setting to use with the selected additive machine.

A print setting is a grouping of material-specific parameters, such as layer height, that you associate with an additive machine, and it defines how a part is additively manufactured. In the Print Setting Library, you can create, edit, copy and paste, and import and export print settings for additive machines. A print setting must be chosen before you can create the additive setup.

Select

Opens the Machine Library where you can select a CMM (coordinate measuring machine).

Stock

Defines the size and shape of the raw stock material, from which a part is created.

In milling, turning or mill/turn, and cutting setups, you generate toolpaths to remove stock. In additive setups, you generate toolpaths to add material to stock. Having an accurate representation of the stock helps to create better toolpaths.

Fixed/Relative Size Box
Rectangular stock

Fixed/Relative Size Cylinder
Cylindrical stock

Fixed/Relative Size Tube
Tubular stock

From Solid
Additive starting stock and
irregular-shaped stock like castings

From preceding setup
Creates a stock that matches the stock defined in the previous setup.

Setup

Used to specify the manufacturing process.

Milling
All types of
Milling machines.

Turning
2x Lathes, Lathes with
mill/turn configurations.

Cutting
For Waterjet, Laser or
Plasma configurations.

Additive
3D printing for
metals and plastics.

Operation Type

Used to specify the manufacturing process.

Milling
All types of
Milling machines.

Turning
2x Lathes, Lathes with
mill/turn configurations.

Cutting
For Waterjet, Laser or
Plasma configurations.

Additive
3D printing for
metals and plastics.

Use External Model

Use Stock Radius

Specifies the radius of cylindrical stock instead of using an offset value.

This option is helpful when working with bar stock that is ordered at a given diameter or radius.

WCS Offset

Identifies the desired workpiece coordinate system (WCS) for the setup. It is the responsibility of the post processor configuration to map this number to the actual WCS on the machine.

WCS Offset Increment

Specifies the work offset increment used for workpiece duplication.

Operation Order

Specifies the ordering of the individual operations.

Preserve order - Specifies that features are machined in the order in which they were selected.

Order by operation - Specifies the ordering of the individual operations.

Order by tool - Specifies the ordering of operations by tool. For example, all operations that use a 3/4" diameter flat mill are machined first. Then the next set of operations that use another identical tool, a 1/4" diameter flat mill for example, are machined next.

Machining Boundary Selection

Machining Distance

Displays the total machining toolpath distance of the simulation.

Machining Time

Displays the total machining time of the simulation. Please note that the machining time is a rough estimate which can be far from the actual machining time after post processing.

Movement

Displays the type of movement (Lead-in, Ramp, Cutting, Transition) during the toolpath simulation.

Operations

Displays the total number of machining operations for the simulation.

Positioning Feedrate

Specifies the feedrate to use when positioning to the Starting Depth.

This can be greater than the cutting feedrate to save time, or less than the cutting feedrate for safety reasons.

Positioning Spindle Speed

Width

Defines the width of the machine envelope.

Shown here as X, this may vary depending on the machine type.

Width of the machine envelope.

Height

Defines the height of the machine envelope.

Shown here as Z, this may vary depending on the machine type.

Height of the machine envelope.

Depth

Defines the depth of the machine envelope.

Shown here as Y, this may vary depending on the machine type.

Depth of the machine envelope.

Tool changer

Defines the characteristics of your machines tool changing system.

Automatic tool changer capacities can be set here.

Automatic Tool Changer Magazine.

Automatic tool changer

Enable if your machine has an automatic tool changer.

Disable for machines with manual tool change capabilities.

Automatic Tool Changer Magazine.

Supports tool preload

Enable if your machine has a staging function for the tool changer.

Disable for machines without staging tool change capabilities.

Line N30 Activates tool change for Tool 1
Line N85 Preloads Tool 2 for the next tool change.

Number of tools

This can represent either the maximum number of tools available in the tool magazine or the maximum number of tools that can be programmed in the control.

Tool magazine with 20 pockets

Maximum tool length

This is the maximum tool length that can be stored in the tool magazine.

Maximum allowable tool length

Maximum tool weight

This is the maximum tool weight that can be supported by the tool change system or tool magazine.

Maximum tool diameter

This is the maximum tool diameter that can be stored in the tool magazine.

Maximum allowable tool diameter

Maximum workpiece X

This is the maximum sized workpiece that can fit on the machine in X.

Maximum X part travel

Maximum workpiece Y

This is the maximum sized workpiece that can fit on the machine in Y.

Maximum Y part travel

Maximum workpiece Z

This is the maximum sized workpiece that can fit on the machine in Z.

Maximum Z part travel

TCP Tool Center Point

Used for machines with rotary axis configurations.

When disabled, the part placement on the physical machine must match the part placement in Fusion.

When enabled, this outputs a function that allows the machine controller to remap the program, if the part is located off center from where it was programmed in Fusion.

Note: Enabling this function requires your machine control to have TCP capability. Contact your machine tool representative to verify this capability.

Setup

Displays the setup name and number.

Stock

Enable to show the stock during the simulation.

Tool

Toggles the on/off visibility of the tool.

Show Holder

Toggles the on/off visibility of the tool holder.

Show Shaft

Toggles the on/off visibility of the tool shaft.

Show Transparent

Enable to make both the tool shaft and tool holder transparent so that you can see through them.

Toolpath

Available visualization options allow the entire toolpath, all toolpath before or after the current tool position, toolpath for the operation, or toolpath tail until the current tool position to be shown during the simulation.

Show Points

When enabled, points along the toolpath are displayed. As you hover over each point, its XYZ position appears in the Position group.

Spindle Speed

Specifies the spindle speed, given in rotations per minute, to apply during operation.

Starting Depth

Because of the excessive length of a Gun Drill, a pilot hole is generally drilled, to keep the tool from walking off of the true hole position. This value specifies the positioning depth inside the pilot hole.

This positioning move is made in feed mode and an independent feedrate can be specified when moving to this depth.

Starting Depth inside the pilot hole

Resolution

Stock Type

Stop Spindle

Select to stop the spindle before and after the operation.

The spindle will start once the tool reaches the Starting Depth of the pilot hole.

Time

Displays the total machining time for each toolpath.

Tool

Displays a tool description of the tool in use during the simulation.

Automatic Name

Automatic Name

Spindle Rotation

Holder Name

Insert Name

Overall Length

Tip Length

Tip Offset

Turret

Coordinate System

Orientation

Specifies how the tool orientation is determined using a combination of triad orientation and origin options.

The Orientation drop-down menu provides the following options to set the orientation of the X, Y, and Z triad axes:

Setup WCS orientation - Uses the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) of the current setup for the tool orientation.

Model orientation - Uses the coordinate system (WCS) of the current part for the tool orientation.

Select Z axis/plane & X axis - Select a face or an edge to define the Z axis and another face or edge to define the X axis. Both the Z and X axes can be flipped 180 degrees.

Select Z axis/plane & Y axis - Select a face or an edge to define the Z axis and another face or edge to define the Y axis. Both the Z and Y axes can be flipped 180 degrees.

Select X & Y axes - Select a face or an edge to define the X axis and another face or edge to define the Y axis. Both the X and Y axes can be flipped 180 degrees.

Select coordinate system - Sets a specific tool orientation for this operation from a defined User Coordinate System (UCS) in the model. This uses both the origin and orientation of the existing coordinate system. Use this option if your model does not contain a suitable point and plane for your operation.

Surface normal & X Axis (Machining extension) - Click anywhere on a surface to set the tool orientation normal to that surface then select a face or edge to define the X Axis.

Surface normal & Y Axis (Machining extension) - Click anywhere on a surface to set the tool orientation normal to that surface then select a face or edge to define the Y Axis.

Surface Point

Click anywhere on a surface to set the tool orientation normal to that point on the surface.

Surface selection

Tool orientation normal to selection

Bounding Box Point

Origin

The Origin drop-down menu offers the following options for locating the triad origin:

Setup WCS origin - Uses the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) origin of the current setup for the tool origin.

Surface point (Machining extension) - Uses the selected surface point for the triad origin.

Model origin - Uses the coordinate system (WCS) origin of the current part for the tool origin.

Selected point - Select a vertex or an edge for the triad origin.

Stock box point - Select a point on the stock bounding box for the triad origin.

Model box point - Select a point on the model bounding box for the triad origin.

Stock Point

Select a point on the Stock Box to set the part origin.

Tool Orientation Origin

Select a point to set the part origin.

Model Point

Select a point to set the part origin.

Model Point

Select a point on the Model Box to set the part origin.

Set the X Axis for the plane.
