Flip View Z Axis

Flips the Z axis 180 degrees.

Flip The Axis Direction 180 degrees

Orientation

Set the orientation to reflect the machining plane. The Z axis should point away from the machining plane.

Note the orientation of the Z axis
and the tool spindle axis orientation.

The Orientation drop-down menu provides the following options to define the orientation of the X, Y machining plane and the Z spindle axes.

Model orientation - Uses the orientation of the current part for the WCS orientation.

Select Z axis/plane & X axis - Select a face or an edge to define the Z axis and another face or edge to define the X axis. Both the Z and X axes can be flipped 180 degrees.

Select Z axis/plane & Y axis - Select a face or an edge to define the Z axis and another face or edge to define the Y axis. Both the Z and Y axes can be flipped 180 degrees.

Select X & Y axes - Select a face or an edge to define the X axis and another face or edge to define the Y axis. Both the X and Y axes can be flipped 180 degrees.

Select coordinate system - sets the WCS orientation for the setup from a defined User Coordinate System (UCS) in the model. This uses both the origin and orientation of the existing coordinate system. Use this option if your model does not contain a suitable point and plane for your operation.

Orientation

The Orientation drop-down menu provides the following options to define the X, Y, and Z axes.

Model orientation - Uses the orientation of the current part for the WCS orientation.

Select Z axis/plane & X axis - Select a face or an edge to define the Z axis and another face or edge to define the X axis. Both the Z and X axes can be flipped 180 degrees.

Select Z axis/plane & Y axis - Select a face or an edge to define the Z axis and another face or edge to define the Y axis. Both the Z and Y axes can be flipped 180 degrees.

Select X & Y axes - Select a face or an edge to define the X axis and another face or edge to define the Y axis. Both the X and Y axes can be flipped 180 degrees.

Select coordinate system - sets the WCS orientation for the setup from a defined User Coordinate System (UCS) in the model. This uses both the origin and orientation of the existing coordinate system. Use this option if your model does not contain a suitable point and plane for your operation.

Bounding Box Point

When either the Stock box point or Model box point origin options are selected, you can then use the Bounding box point drop-down menu to specify a point (Example: Top Center) on the bounding box to locate the WCS origin.

Origin

The Origin drop-down menu offers the following options for locating the WCS origin:

Model origin - Uses the coordinate system (WCS) origin of the current part for the WCS origin.

Selected point - Select a vertex or an edge for the WCS origin.

Stock box point - Select a point on the stock bounding box for the WCS origin.

Model box point - Select a point on the model bounding box for the WCS origin.

WCS Origin

Select a point to set the part origin.

WCS Origin

Select a point to set the part origin.

Normally set to the part face or part back, but you can select any circular edge to define the origin position.

Origin

Allows you to select the Work Coordinate Origin for the part Zero.

Stock Front

Stock Back

Model Front

Model Back

User Selected Point

Chuck Front

Note: When using Chuck Front, set the Stock In Chuck amount, shown below.

Stock Point

Select a point on the Stock Box to set the part origin.

Safe Z

Set the Z retract position.

The Reference position can be from the WCS Origin or the Stock.
The Safe Z retract will position at the start or end of a toolpath.

WCS Reference
and Offset Distance

Stock Back Reference
and Offset Distance

Note: Safe Z location may be overridden in each operation, from the Passes tab

Safe Z Reference

Set the Reference position for the Safe Z. The Reference position can be from the WCS Origin, Stock Front or the Stock Back.

The Safe Z retract will position at the start or end of a toolpath.

WCS Reference
and Offset Distance

WCS Reference
and Offset Distance

Stock Front Reference
and Offset Distance

Stock Back Reference
and Offset Distance

Note: Safe Z location may be overridden in each operation, from the Passes tab

Offset

Set the Offset distance in relation to the Reference position defined above. The Reference position can be from the WCS Origin, Stock Front or the Stock Back.

The Safe Z retract will position at the start or end of a toolpath.

WCS Reference
and Offset Distance

WCS Reference
and Offset Distance

Stock Front Reference
and Offset Distance

Stock Back Reference
and Offset Distance

Note: Safe Z location may be overridden in each operation, from the Passes tab

Approach and Retract

Used to define how the tool should position at the start of the operation and the end of the operation.

The default position is in reference to the Safe Z as defined in the Setup.

Start and End Returning
to the Safe Z position

Approach Z

Defines how the tool will position in Z before the start of the toolpath.

Safe Z - The Approach position will be the same as the Safe Z position defined in the Setup.

First Toolpath Point - The Approach position will be the same as the first Z position of the toolpath.

Retract Z

Defines how the tool will position in Z after completing the toolpath.

Safe Z - The Retract position will be the same as the Safe Z position defined in the Setup.

Last Toolpath Point - The Retract position will be the same as the Last Z position of the toolpath.

Retract X

Defines how the tool will position in X after completing the toolpath.

Clearance - The Retract position will be the same as the X Clearance position as defined on the Radii tab.

Last Toolpath Point - The Retract position will be the same as the Last X position of the toolpath. Useful if the next procedure is a bar pull operation.

Override Setup Safe Z

Redefine the Reference position for the Safe Z retract.

WCS Reference
and Offset Distance

Stock Back Reference
and Offset Distance

Safe Z Reference

Set the Reference position for the Safe Z. The Reference position can be from the WCS Origin, Stock Front or the Stock Back.

WCS Reference
and Offset Distance

WCS Reference
and Offset Distance

Stock Front Reference
and Offset Distance

Stock Back Reference
and Offset Distance

Offset

Set the Offset distance in relation to the Reference position defined above. The Reference position can be from the WCS Origin, Stock Front or the Stock Back.

WCS Reference
and Offset Distance

WCS Reference
and Offset Distance

Stock Front Reference
and Offset Distance

Stock Back Reference
and Offset Distance

X Position

Displays the X position of a toolpath point.

Y Position

Displays the Y position of a toolpath point.

Z Position

Displays the Z position of a toolpath point.

Mode & Direction

Expand this group to access settings that let you control how the tool approaches the stock.

Turning Mode

Depending on the turning strategy, this setting determines whether the tool is cutting on the Outside Diameter or the Inside Diameter, as well as the approach/retract direction.

Outside

Inside

Outside - The tool approaches from/retracts to the outside of the stock and machines axially depending on the Direction setting (below).

Inside - The tool approaches from/retracts to the centerline and machines axially depending on the Direction setting (below).

Turning Mode

This setting determines whether the tool machines axially, radially or from the face, as well as the approach/retract direction.

Outside

Face

Inside

Outside - The tool approaches from/retracts to the outside of the stock and machines axially depending on the Direction setting (below).

Face - The tool approaches from the front and machines radially depending on the Direction setting (below).
Note: This option can be used for ID and OD machining.

Inside - The tool approaches from/retracts to the centerline and machines axially depending on the Direction setting (below).

Turning Mode

This setting determines whether the tool is cutting on the Outside Diameter or the Inside Diameter, as well as the approach/retract direction.

Outside

Inside

Outside - The tool approaches from/retracts to the outside of the stock and machines radially depending on the Direction setting (below).

Inside - The tool approaches from/retracts to the centerline and machines radially depending on the Direction setting (below).

Turning Mode

This setting determines whether the tool is cutting on the Outside Diameter or the Inside Diameter, as well as the approach/retract direction.

Outside

Inside

Outside - The tool approaches from/retracts to the outside of the stock and machines radially towards the centerline of the part.

Inside - The tool approaches from/retracts to the centerline and machines radially away from the centerline of the part.

Turning Mode

This setting determines whether the tool is cutting on the Outside Diameter or the Inside Diameter, as well as the approach/retract direction.

Outside (top) and Inside (bottom)

Outside - The tool approaches from/retracts to the outside of the stock and machines towards the centerline.

Inside - The tool approaches from/retracts to the centerline and machines away from the centerline.

Secondary Spindle

These parameters position the subspindle over the workpiece in the main spindle.

The subspindle chuck command can be used to support a workpiece during a cutoff, support a part to reduce vibration, perform a bar-pull operation, or to transfer the part between spindles.

Subspindle positioned over the part.

The subspindle rapids from its home position to the Feed Plane reference position, moves over the part at the specified feedrate to the Chuck plane and clamps the part.

Secondary Spindle

Returns the subspindle back to the home position.

The subspindle return command can be used to move the workpiece home for additional machining on the back side.

Subspindle returning home

The subspindle feeds from the Chuck Plane to the Feed Plane, then moves to the home position.

Secondary Spindle

These parameters retract the subspindle, at feed, by a specified distance.

The Pull command can be used to pull the bar from the spindle for additional machining.

Subspindle extracting the bar from the chuck

The subspindle feeds from the Chuck Plane by the specified distance..

Pull Distance

Defines the distance the subspindle moves from the Chuck Plane to extract the bar from the spindle.

Pull Mode

Controls how the coordinates for the shifted part should be calculated.

Compensate Toolpaths - The current origin stays active. Any new toolpath are in reference to the origin.

New wcs offset - The origin is shifted by the Pull Distance and assigned a new WCS offset.

Feedrate

Defines the speed the subspindle moves from the orange Feed Plane to the green Chuck Plane.

Feedrate

Defines the speed the subspindle moves from the Chuck Plane to the Feed Plane.

Stop Spindle During Chuck

Select to stop both spindles during subspindle transfer.

Useful for clamping the workpiece at a known angle in the subspindle, when alignment between main and subspindle is important.

Use the Spindle Orientation parameter to achieve a specific angular alignment.

Spindle Orientation

Specifies an angular shift between the main and the subspindle.

Used when you need precise alignment with the subspindle chuck jaws or a collet. Rotational adjustment is applied before clamping.

Positioned at 0 degrees

Positioned at 30 degrees

Use Part Catcher

Select to extend the machines part catcher or gripper arm, so the part can be ejected from the spindle.

Not all machines have a part catcher and post processor modifications may be required.

Feed Plane

Defines the Chuck Feed Plane.

Chuck Feed Plane Shown in Orange

The subspindle will rapid to this Z axis position, before feeding to the Chuck Plane.

Chuck Plane

Defines the Chuck Plane.

Chucking Plane Shown in Green

The Z axis position where the subspindle will clamp the part.

Feed Plane

Defines the Chuck Return Feed Plane.

Chuck Return Feed Plane Shown in orange

The subspindle feeds from the Chuck Plane to the Feed Plane, then moves to the home position.

Feed Plane Mode

Specifies the reference point for the Feed Plane Offset.

The subspindle feeds from the Chuck Plane to the Feed Plane, shown in orange, then moves to the home position. Use the Offset to shift the actual position positive or negative.

Stock Front

Stock Back

Model Front

Model Back

User Selected Point

Chuck Face

Machine Position is in reference to the machine coordinate system. No line will be displayed.

Feed Plane Mode

Specifies the reference point for the Feed Plane Offset.

The subspindle will rapid to the Feed Plane, shown in orange, then feed to the Chuck Plane. Use the Offset to shift the actual position positive or negative.

Stock Front

Stock Back

Model Front

Model Back

User Selected Point

Chuck Face

Chuck Plane is in reference to the Chuck Plane position, defined below.

Offset

Specifies an offset to apply to the Feed Plane.

Shifts the selected Feed Plane reference position by a positive or negative value.

Chuck Plane Mode

Specifies the reference point for the Chuck Plane Offset.

The subspindle will rapid to the Feed Plane, then feed to the Chuck Plane, shown in green. Use the Offset to shift the actual position positive or negative.

Stock Front

Stock Back

Model Front

Model Back

User Selected Point

Chuck Face

Machine Position is in reference to the machine coordinate system. No line will be displayed.

Offset

Specifies an offset to apply to the Chuck Plane.

Shifts the selected Chuck Plane reference position by a positive or negative value.

Open Spindle Chucks

Specifies which spindle chuck to open before returning the secondary spindle.

Keep Both Clamped - If main spindle has bar loaded and sub spindle has the workpiece, both spindles are kept clamped to continue machining.

Unclamp Primary Spindle - if the workpiece is a billet and the main and sub spindle are clamped on the part, the main spindle will need to be unclamped so the sub spindle can move with the part.

Unclamp Secondary Spindle - If the sub spindle has been used for bar pulling or supporting the workpiece, the sub spindle can now return home without the workpiece.

Pattern

Creates a pattern of toolpaths from an existing operation. This can be used to machine multiple components with a single WCS.

Pattern Type

The pattern type to use for the folder.

Linear - Patterns operations/toolpaths in a straight line, or grid.

Circular - Patterns operations/toolpaths around a rotational center.

Mirror - Creates mirror-image operations/toolpaths that are flipped about a mirror plane.

Duplication - Creates a pattern using operations/toolpaths as the source and sketch points as the targets.

Component - Available in assemblies only, this option patterns operations/toolpaths from one component to multiple components in an assembly.

Distance Type

Determines how the distance is specified for the toolpath pattern.

Extent - Lets you specify the overall distance for the toolpath pattern.

Spacing - Lets you specify the distance between instances of the toolpath in the pattern.

Extent

Spacing

Flip Direction

Inverts the axis of the pattern to place the instances on the other side of the original operation.

For symmetric linear patterns, this setting determines on which side you can place the instances asymmetrically.

Flip Direction 1

Inverts the axis of the pattern to place the instances on the other side of the original operation.

For symmetric linear patterns, this setting determines on which side you can place the instances asymmetrically.

Flip Direction 2

Inverts the axis of the pattern to place the instances on the other side of the original operation.

For symmetric linear patterns, this setting determines on which side you can place the instances asymmetrically.

Reverse

Changes the order of posting the instances in the pattern so that the original operation is output last.

The original operation is the one that you copy to create instances in a pattern. Leave Reverse unselected to output the original operation first.

Direction 1

Defines the direction of distributing instances of the operation.

Select an edge or face in your model. Alternatively, from the browser, select the X, Y, or Z axis.

To place the instances on the other side of the original operation, select Flip direction.

Original operation

Direction defined by the edge

Quantity

Defines the number of operation instances in the pattern along the selected direction.

Number of Instances

Defines the number of operation instances in the pattern.

Distance

Specifies the extent or spacing depending on the selected Distance Type.

The extent is the overall distance of the operation pattern. The spacing is the distance between instances of the operation in the pattern.

Extent

Spacing

Additional Direction

Distributes the operation instances in another direction.

Select this checkbox to create a pattern over a 2D area, like a rectangle.

Leave it deselected to distribute the operation instances in one direction.

Original operation

Pattern in one direction

Additional direction

Keep Original

Controls whether the original operation is included in the pattern.

Deselect the checkbox to exclude the original operation.

Axis

Selects the axis of rotation for the toolpath pattern.

If axes are not visible in the canvas, select the axis from the browser.

Z axis selected

Angle

Specifies the extent or spacing, in degrees, depending on the selected Distance Type.

360 degrees is set by default.

Operation Order

Specifies the ordering of the operations in the pattern.

Preserve order - Machines all operations in each instance of the pattern before moving to the next instance.

Order by operation - Machines all occurrences of each operation in the pattern before changing to the next operation.

Order by tool - Machines all operations in the pattern that use the current tool before changing tools.

Spun Profile

Some turned parts require subsequent milling operations. In these instances a turning profile needs to be generated before the milling begins. This feature allow you to generate a 2D sketch profile through the X axis of the mill/turn part which can then be used for turning.

Spun Profile Off

Spun Profile On

Spun Profile Tolerance

Specifies the tolerance for the spun profile generation.

Spun Profile Smoothing

Enable to smooth the profile.

Front Mode

Select the reference point for the Front Confinement Boundary Offset.

Stock Front

Stock Back

Selection

Model Front

Model Back

Origin - Absolute

Chuck Front is in reference to the Chuck position, as defined in the Setup.

Note: The Offset value can be positive or negative from this reference point.

Back Mode

Select the reference point for the Back Confinement Boundary Offset.

Stock Front

Stock Back

Selection

Model Front

Model Back

Origin - Absolute

Chuck Front is in reference to the Chuck position, as defined in the Setup.

Note: The Offset value can be positive or negative from the specified reference point.

Front Confinement

Front is used to limit the toolpath by Confining an area. Shown in Orange, use these parameters to select the Front Confinement area.

Front Toolpath Confinement

Back Confinement

Back is used to limit the toolpath by Confining an area. Shown in Green, use these parameters to select the Back Confinement area.

Back Toolpath Confinement

Front Confinement

Front is used to limit the toolpath by Confining an area. Shown in Orange, use these parameters to select the Front Confinement area.

Front Toolpath Confinement

Back Confinement

Back is used to limit the toolpath by Confining an area. Shown in Green, use these parameters to select the Back Confinement area.

Back Toolpath Confinement

Offset

The distance to shift the Front Confinement Boundary, from the reference point shown above. Shown in Orange, you can dynamically grab and move the position with your mouse.

Front Offset Shown as .100 (in) from the Model Front

Note: This value can be positive or negative from the reference point.

Tangential Extension

Creates a tangential extension of the geometry from the Front limit.

The orange line represents the Front limit.

Tangent extension of 0.0

Tangent extension of .300

Tangent extension of .300

Radial Extension

When enabled this extends the final cut position radially to the extents of the stock radius.

Disabled
Stops at the end of the cut

Enabled
Cut extends to the outer stock radius

Offset

The distance to shift the Back Confinement Boundary, from the reference point shown above. Shown in Green, you can dynamically grab and move the position with your mouse.

Back Offset Shown as -.250 (in) from the User Selected Edge.

Note: This value can be positive or negative from the reference point.

Tangential Extension

Creates a tangential extension of the geometry from the Back limit.

The dark green line represents the Back limit.

Tangent extension of 0.0

Tangent extension of .300

Tangent extension of .300

Turning Mode

Determines, depending on the turning strategy, whether a tool is cutting on the Outside Diameter, Inside Diameter, or Face and the approach and retract direction.

Outside grooving

Inside grooving

Face grooving

Outside grooving - The tool approaches from and retracts toward the outside of the stock and machines the model depending on the Direction setting.

Inside grooving - The tool approaches from and retracts toward the centerline and machines the model depending on the Direction setting.

Face grooving - The tool approaches from and retracts toward the front of the stock and machines the model depending on the Direction setting.

Source

Specifies how to identify the unmachined regions of a part where there is still stock material to remove. The resulting toolpath targets only unmachined regions.

From previous operation(s) - Uses all toolpaths in the current setup to identify remaining unmachined regions.

From setup stock - Uses the stock defined in the setup to represent unmachined regions.

Groove Suppression

Suppresses machining of one or more grooves.

Groove suppression is turned off

Groove suppression is turned on

This option enables you to specify one or more grooves to suppress when machining. Specify the groove by selecting the faces that enclose the groove. To use this option, turn on the Spun Profile option in the Setup dialog, on the Setup tab.

Select

Selects faces that enclose one or more grooves to suppress.

Avoid Upward Cutting

Prevents the tool from cutting groove walls in an upward direction.

Avoid Upward Cutting is turned on

The tool machines down a groove to the groove's midpoint. Then, it retracts and machines the opposite wall of the groove in a downward motion. This process repeats until all grooves are machined.

Machine Single Grooves

Specifies whether to machine the grooves whose width equals the cutting width of the insert.

Machine Single Grooves is off

Machine Single Grooves is on

High Feedrate Mode

Specifies when rapid movements should be output as true rapids (G0) and when as high feedrate movements (G1).

Preserve rapid movement - Preserves all rapid movements.

Always use high feed - Outputs rapid movements as (high feed moves) G01 moves instead of rapid movements (G0).

This parameter is usually set to avoid collisions at rapids on machines which perform "dogleg" movements at rapid.

Front Reference

Select the edge, face or vertex to reference.

Edge Selection Shown

Back Reference

Select the edge, face or vertex to reference.

Edge Selection Shown

Clearance Position

Shown in Orange, this controls the radius where the tool moves to at the start and end of the toolpath. The tool approaches and retracts from outside the stock along the Z axis to this radial clearance offset.

Containment around all the machinable stock.

Toolpath for the area shown above.

Containment restricting an inner area.

Eliminating outer toolpaths for pre-machined areas.

Note: The Clearance radius must be larger than, or equal to, the Outer radius to generate a valid toolpath.

From - Clearance Reference

Shown in Orange, sets the clearance radius reference position. The reference can be in relation to the Stock, the Model, a specified Radius, Diameter, or any of the other Radial positions. This reference position can be shifted with a positive or negative offset value.

Retract - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the Retract Position.

Stock OD - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the outside diameter of the defined Stock.

Model OD - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the outside diameter of the defined Model .

Outer radius - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the Outer radius position. The Clearance radius must be larger than the Outer radius. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Inner radius - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the Inner radius position. The Clearance radius must be larger than the Inner radius. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Model ID - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the inside diameter of the Model, as defined in the Setup. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Stock ID - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the inside diameter of the Stock, as defined in the Setup. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Selection - Select any face, vertex, or point on the model to define the Clearance radius. Use the Offset parameter to make positive or negative adjustments as needed.

Radius - This option allows you to enter a radius value in the Offset field. This value is in reference to the centerline of the part and will not recognize any associative changes to the model.

Diameter - This option allows you to enter a diameter value in the Offset field. This value is in reference to the centerline of the part and will not recognize any associative changes to the model.

Note: The Clearance radius must be larger than, or equal to, the Retract, Outer radius and Inner radius, in order to generate a valid toolpath.

Clearance Offset

Use this offset to shift the position, relative to the Reference point selected above. You can make positive or negative adjustments as needed.

In This Example:
Outer = Stock OD (Model + 1mm stock).
Retract = Outer + 5mm Offset.
Clearance = Retract + 5mm Offset.

Retract Position

Shown in Dark Green, this controls the position above the surface you plan to machine. This is the radius where the tool retracts to between cuts.

Note: The tool will only retract to this position, if the Linking - Retract Policy is set to Full Retraction.

Containment around all the machinable stock.

Toolpath for the area shown above.

Containment restricting an inner area.
Inner Radius is moved out, leaving stock.

Eliminating outer toolpaths for pre-machined areas.

Note: The Retract radius must be larger than, the Outer radius to generate a valid toolpath.

From - Retract Reference

Shown in Dark Green, sets the Retract radius reference position. The reference can be in relation to the Stock, the Model, a specified Radius, Diameter, or any of the other Radial positions. This reference position can be shifted with a positive or negative offset value.

Clearance - Sets the Retract radius in reference to the Clearance Position.

Stock OD - Sets the Retract radius in reference to the outside diameter of the defined Stock.

Model OD - Sets the Retract radius in reference to the outside diameter of the defined Model .

Outer radius - Sets the Retract radius reference to the Outer radius position. The Clearance radius must be larger than the Outer radius. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Inner radius - Sets the Retract radius in reference to the Inner radius position. The Clearance radius must be larger than the Inner radius. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Model ID - Sets the Retract radius in reference to the inside diameter of the Model, as defined in the Setup. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Stock ID - Sets the Retract radius in reference to the inside diameter of the Stock, as defined in the Setup. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Selection - Select any face, vertex, or point on the model to define the Clearance radius. Use the Offset parameter to make positive or negative adjustments as needed.

Radius - This option allows you to enter a radius value in the Offset field. This value is in reference to the centerline of the part and will not recognize any associative changes to the model.

Diameter - This option allows you to enter a diameter value in the Offset field. This value is in reference to the centerline of the part and will not recognize any associative changes to the model.

Note: The Retract radius must be smaller than, or equal to, the Clearance, but larger than the Outer radius and Inner radius, in order to generate a valid toolpath.

Retract Offset

Use this offset to shift the position, relative to the Reference point selected above. You can make positive or negative adjustments as needed.

In This Example:
Outer = Stock OD (Model + 1mm stock).
Retract = Outer + 5mm Offset.
Clearance = Retract + 5mm Offset.

Outer Position

Shown in Light Blue, this controls the outer most position of the cutting area. For OD machining the toolpath will cut from this outer surface, into the part. For ID machining this is the maximum depth of the internal machining area.

Outside Machining.
Outer = Outer most machining area.

Outside Machining.
Eliminating outer toolpaths for pre-machined areas.
Outer Radius adjusts the face of the cutting area.

Inside Machining.
Outer = Outer most machining area.
Used to limit the toolpaths area.

Inside Machining
Outer Radius adjusts the cutting depth.
Stock left, shown in yellow.

Note: The Retract radius must be larger than the Outer radius for OD work and smaller than the Inner radius ID work.

From - Outer Reference

Shown in Light Blue, sets the Outer radius reference position. The reference can be in relation to the Stock, the Model, a specified Radius, Diameter, or any of the other Radial positions. This reference position can be shifted with a positive or negative offset value.

Clearance - Sets the Outer radius in reference to the Clearance Position.

Retract - Sets the Outer radius in reference to the Retract position.

Stock OD - Sets the Outer radius in reference to the outside diameter of the defined Stock.

Model OD - Sets the Outer radius in reference to the outside diameter of the defined Model .

Outer radius - Sets the Outer radius reference to the Outer radius position. The Clearance radius must be larger than the Outer radius. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Inner radius - Sets the Outer radius in reference to the Inner radius position. The Clearance radius must be larger than the Inner radius. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Model ID - Sets the Outer radius in reference to the inside diameter of the Model, as defined in the Setup. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Stock ID - Sets the Outer radius in reference to the inside diameter of the Stock, as defined in the Setup. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Selection - Select any face, vertex, or point on the model to define the Clearance radius. Use the Offset parameter to make positive or negative adjustments as needed.

Radius - This option allows you to enter a radius value in the Offset field. This value is in reference to the centerline of the part and will not recognize any associative changes to the model.

Diameter - This option allows you to enter a diameter value in the Offset field. This value is in reference to the centerline of the part and will not recognize any associative changes to the model.

Note: The Outer radius must be smaller than, or equal to, the Retract, but larger than the Inner radius, in order to generate a valid toolpath.

Outer Offset

Use this offset to shift the position, relative to the Reference point selected above. You can make positive or negative adjustments as needed.

In This Example:
Outer = Stock OD (Model + 1mm stock).
Retract = Outer + 5mm Offset.
Clearance = Retract + 5mm Offset.

In This Example:
Inner = Stock ID.
Retract = Inner -.120 In. Offset.
Clearance = Retract -.260 In. Offset.

Inner Position

Shown in Dark Blue, this controls the inner most position of the cutting area. For OD machining the toolpath will cut down to this inner depth. For ID machining this is the starting height of the internal machining area.

Outside Machining.
Inner = Inner most machining area.

Outside Machining.
Eliminating inner toolpath areas.
Inner Radius adjusts the depth of the cutting area.

Inside Machining.
Outer = Inner most machining area.
Used to limit the toolpath area.

Inside Machining
Outer Radius adjusts the cutting depth.
Stock left is shown in yellow.

Note: The Inner radius must be smaller than the Outer radius for OD and ID work.

From - Inner Reference

Shown in Dark Blue, sets the Inner radius reference position. The reference can be in relation to the Stock, the Model, a specified Radius, Diameter, or any of the other Radial positions. This reference position can be shifted with a positive or negative offset value.

Clearance - Sets the Inner radius in reference to the Clearance Position.

Retract - Sets the Inner radius in reference to the Retract position.

Stock OD - Sets the Inner radius in reference to the outside diameter of the defined Stock.

Model OD - Sets the Inner radius in reference to the outside diameter of the defined Model .

Outer radius - Sets the Inner radius reference to the Inner radius position. The Clearance radius must be larger than the Inner radius. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Model ID - Sets the Inner radius in reference to the inside diameter of the Model, as defined in the Setup. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Stock ID - Sets the Inner radius in reference to the inside diameter of the Stock, as defined in the Setup. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Selection - Select any face, vertex, or point on the model to define the Clearance radius. Use the Offset parameter to make positive or negative adjustments as needed.

Radius - This option allows you to enter a radius value in the Offset field. This value is in reference to the centerline of the part and will not recognize any associative changes to the model.

Diameter - This option allows you to enter a diameter value in the Offset field. This value is in reference to the centerline of the part and will not recognize any associative changes to the model.

Note: The Inner radius must be smaller than, or equal to, the Clearance, but larger than the Inner radius and Inner radius, in order to generate a valid toolpath.

Inner Offset

Use this offset to shift the position, relative to the Reference point selected above. You can make positive or negative adjustments as needed.

In This Example:
Outer = Stock OD (Model + 1mm stock).
Retract = Outer + 5mm Offset.
Clearance = Retract + 5mm Offset.

In This Example:
Inner = Stock ID.
Retract = Inner -.120 In. Offset.
Clearance = Retract -.260 In. Offset.

Clearance Position

Shown in Orange, this controls the radius where the tool moves to at the start and end of the toolpath. The tool approaches and retracts from outside the stock along the Z axis to this radial clearance offset.

Containment around all the machinable stock.

Inner shift to reduce the toolpath area.

Toolpath result from the above settings.

Note: The Clearance radius must be smaller than the Inner radius to generate a valid toolpath.

From - Clearance Reference

Shown in Orange, sets the clearance radius reference position. The reference can be in relation to the Stock, the Model, a specified Radius, Diameter, or any of the other Radial positions. This reference position can be shifted with a positive or negative offset value.

Retract - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the Retract Position.

Stock OD - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the outside diameter of the defined Stock.

Model OD - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the outside diameter of the defined Model .

Outer radius - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the Outer radius position. The Clearance radius must be larger than the Outer radius. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Inner radius - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the Inner radius position. The Clearance radius must be larger than the Inner radius. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Model ID - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the inside diameter of the Model, as defined in the Setup. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Stock ID - Sets the Clearance radius in reference to the inside diameter of the Stock, as defined in the Setup. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Selection - Select any face, vertex, or point on the model to define the Clearance radius. Use the Offset parameter to make positive or negative adjustments as needed.

Radius - This option allows you to enter a radius value in the Offset field. This value is in reference to the centerline of the part and will not recognize any associative changes to the model.

Diameter - This option allows you to enter a diameter value in the Offset field. This value is in reference to the centerline of the part and will not recognize any associative changes to the model.

Note: The Clearance radius must be smaller than the Retract, Outer radius and Inner radius, in order to generate a valid toolpath.

Clearance Offset

Use this offset to shift the position, relative to the Reference point selected above. You can make positive or negative adjustments as needed.

In This Example:
Inner = Stock ID.
Retract = Inner -.120 In. Offset.
Clearance = Retract -.260 In. Offset.

Retract Position

Shown in Dark Green, this controls the position above the surface you plan to machine. This is the radius where the tool retracts to between cuts.

Note: The tool will only retract to this position, if the Linking - Retract Policy is set to Full Retraction.

Containment around all the machinable stock.

Inner shift to reduce the toolpath area.

Toolpath result from the above settings.

Note: The Retract radius must be above, the Inner radius to generate a valid toolpath.

From - Retract Reference

Shown in Dark Green, sets the Retract radius reference position. The reference can be in relation to the Stock, the Model, a specified Radius, Diameter, or any of the other Radial positions. This reference position can be shifted with a positive or negative offset value.

Clearance - Sets the Retract radius in reference to the Clearance Position.

Stock OD - Sets the Retract radius in reference to the outside diameter of the defined Stock.

Model OD - Sets the Retract radius in reference to the outside diameter of the defined Model .

Outer radius - Sets the Retract radius reference to the Outer radius position. The Clearance radius must be larger than the Outer radius. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Inner radius - Sets the Retract radius in reference to the Inner radius position. The Clearance radius must be larger than the Inner radius. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Model ID - Sets the Retract radius in reference to the inside diameter of the Model, as defined in the Setup. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Stock ID - Sets the Retract radius in reference to the inside diameter of the Stock, as defined in the Setup. Use the Offset parameter to make adjustments as needed.

Selection - Select any face, vertex, or point on the model to define the Clearance radius. Use the Offset parameter to make positive or negative adjustments as needed.

Radius - This option allows you to enter a radius value in the Offset field. This value is in reference to the centerline of the part and will not recognize any associative changes to the model.

Diameter - This option allows you to enter a diameter value in the Offset field. This value is in reference to the centerline of the part and will not recognize any associative changes to the model.

Note: The Retract radius must be smaller than, or equal to, the Clearance, but larger than the Outer radius and Inner radius, in order to generate a valid toolpath.

Retract Offset

Use this offset to shift the position, relative to the Reference point selected above. You can make positive or negative adjustments as needed.

In This Example:
Inner = Stock ID.
Retract = Inner -.120 In. Offset.
Clearance = Retract -.260 In. Offset.

Minimum Cutting Radius

The smallest toolpath radius to generate in a sharp corner. This creates a blend at the sharp corners.

If the intersection is sharp or if the corner radius is equal to the tool radius, this can create chatter and distort the surface finish.

Minimum Radius 0.0mm

Minimum Radius 1.0mm

Minimum Radius 3.0mm

Note: Setting this parameter leaves more material in internal corners, requiring subsequent rest machining operations with a smaller tool.

Optimal Load

The maximum amount of engagement the Adaptive toolpath should maintain.

This can be considered the stepover amount, but Adaptive High Speed Machining will vary the stepover to reduce overloading the tool.

Traditional toolpaths can overload the tool in corners. Adaptive Clearing results in faster material removal and eliminates spikes in tool engagement that could break cutters.

Optimal Load 1.5mm

Optimal Load 3.0mm

Note: This value must be less than the tool radius.

Clearance Position

Shown in Orange, this controls the radius where the tool moves to at the start and end of the toolpath. The tool approaches and retracts from outside the stock along the Z axis to this radial clearance offset. Tip: Click the colored bar and drag.

Outer = Stock OD
Clearance = Outer + 5 mm Offset.

Outside Machining Toolpath.
Resulting machined boundary.

Outer = Stock OD - 6.5 mm
Clearance = Stock OD + 5 mm Offset.

Outside Machining Toolpath.
Resulting machined boundary.

Note: The Clearance radius must be larger than, or equal to, the Outer radius to generate a valid toolpath.

Clearance Offset

Use this offset to shift the position, relative to the Reference point selected above. You can make positive or negative adjustments as needed. Tip: Left click the colored bar and drag.

In This Example:
Outer = Stock OD
Clearance = Outer + 5mm Offset.

Outer Position

Shown in Light Blue, this controls the outer most position of the cutting boundary. For OD machining the toolpath will cut from this outer surface, into the part. For ID machining this is the material face of the internal machining boundary. Tip: Left click the colored bar and drag.

For Outside Machining.

Outer most machining boundary.
Outer = Stock OD is common.

Outside Machining Toolpath.
Resulting machined boundary.

For Inside Machining.

Max. depth of the machining boundary.
Outer = Stock OD is common.

Inside Machining Toolpath
Resulting machined boundary.

Note: The Retract radius must be larger than the Outer radius for OD work and smaller than the Inner radius ID work.

Outer Offset

Use this offset to shift the position, relative to the Reference point selected above. You can make positive or negative adjustments as needed. Tip: Left click the colored bar and drag.

In This Example:
Outer = Stock OD
Clearance = Outer + 5mm Offset.

In This Example:
Outer = Stock OD
Inner = Model ID + .50 in Offset.
Clearance = Inner -.25 in Offset.

Inner Position

Shown in Dark Blue, this controls the inner most position of the cutting boundary. For OD machining the toolpath will cut down to this inner depth. For ID machining this is the starting height of the internal machining area. Tip: Left click the colored bar and drag.

For Outside Machining.

Inner most machining boundary.
Inner = Model ID is common.

Outside Machining Toolpath.
Resulting machined boundary.

For Inside Machining.

Starting height of the machining boundary.
Inner = Model ID + hole radius or Face.

Inside Machining Toolpath
Resulting machined boundary.

Note: The Inner radius must be smaller than the Outer radius for OD and ID work.
