Tool Limit

Limits the X axis position in reference to Radii Limits or the Contact point of the tool nose radius.

The dark blue line represents the Inner Radius limit.

Cutting Edge sets a hard limit for the X position of the cut. This limit is determined by the Inner Radius, for OD machining, or the Outer Radius, for ID machining.

Cutting Edge limit

Contact Point positions the nose radius of the tool to the tangent point of the cut. A larger nose radius will create a greater overlap.

Tangent Contact point limit

Tool Limit

Limits the Z axis position in reference to Back Mode position limits or the Contact point of the tool nose radius.

The dark green line represents the Back Mode limit.

Cutting Edge sets a hard limit for the Z position of the cut. This limit is determined by the Back Mode position.

Cutting Edge limit

Contact Point positions the nose radius of the tool to the tangent point of the cut. A larger nose radius will create a greater overlap.

Tangent Contact point

Edge Break

When selected it activates options to Chamfer or Fillet the back edge of the part. The treatment is done before the cut off is complete.

No Edge Break

Chamfer the corner

Fillet the corner

Edge Break Type

Select the type of corner treatment. Add a Chamfer or Fillet to the back edge of the part. This treatment is done before the cut off is complete.

Chamfer the corner

Fillet the corner

Chamfer Width

Specify the distance across the Chamfer.

Axial Chamfer distance

Chamfer Angle

Specify the Angle of the Chamfer, measured from the horizontal axis.

Chamfer Angle

Fillet Radius

Specify the Fillet size for the corner.

Fillet Radius

Distance to Cut Below Inner Radius

This is an adjustment to a Face or Part cut to position the tool nose past the Inner Radius position. Use this to cut past the Centerline of the part.

Cut up to the CenterLine

Cut past the CenterLine

Form Mill

Form Mill allows you to create a custom shaped tool by using an imported cad drawing or a sketch. Most tooling manufacturers have CAD drawings available on their web sites.

The boundary should be 2D, flat and closed. Broken lines, like construction lines, are not allowed.

Once created the tool will be saved to the current Document in the Tool Library. You can open the Tool Library to add additional cutting parameters or descriptions. Move the tool to any Local or Cloud library for future use.

2D Tool Profile

Tool Cutting

Tool Profile

Select any 2D Profile from an imported CAD file or a Sketch. This profile should be drawn as 1/2 of the tool and be a flat 2D layout. Construction lines are not allowed and the boundary should be a closed profile.

Sketch Profile

Selected Profile

Note: You may experience a problem chaining if the boundary is not closed or has entities that overlap. Trim or Extend the intersections to close the boundary.

Tool Axis

Select the line segment that represents the center line of the tool. This is the line the profile gets rotated around.

When selected, a red arrow will appear pointing towards the bottom or Z- direction of the tool. If the red arrow is not pointing negative thru the spindle axis, use the Flip Axis parameter.

Tool Axis
Selection

Tool Axis
Direction

Note: Hidden or Construction lines are not allowed.

Flip Axis

Check if the red arrow is not pointing negative thru the spindle axis. The arrow indicates the bottom or Z- direction of the tool.

Tool Points Negative
Thru the Spindle Axis

Compensation Point

The compensation point is used to drive the tool along the contours, which are selected during toolpath creation. The Sideways Compensation parameter of a toolpath specifies which side of the tool the compensation point sits on.

Bottom Center
Comp. Point

Corner Edge
Comp. Point

If no compensation point is selected, Fusion 360 automatically selects one. Vertically, the compensation point is level with the tip of the tool (Z0 location). Horizontally, the compensation point aligns with the maximum diameter of the tool. In the image below, the compensation point is represented by the red dot.

Tool Library
Tool preview

For center-line cutting on operations such as Trace, set the Sideways Compensation to Center in the operation dialog.

Drill Wizard Hole Selection

Select hole features from the current plane or multiple planes. The Wizard will automatically create the appropriate drilling strategy. Includes filters for limiting hole selection.

Tool Plane
Selection

Multi-axis
Selection

The default is to search for holes in the current active plane, where the Z axis represents the hole centerline. Multi-axis selections will create 3+2 positioning for 4th axis rotary or full 5 axis machines.

Multi-Axis Machining

Includes holes in other planes. The default searches for holes in the current active plane, where the Z axis represents the hole centerline.

Deselected
Only current plane

Selected
Multi-axis selection

Multi-axis selections create 3+2 position for 4th axis rotary or full 5 axis machines. Use Find by Angle to restrict tilting motion.

Find by Angle

Sets a limiting angular range for selecting the holes to machine. Angles are set from the vertical spindle axis.

Angles measured from spindle axis

Angles for through holes

Minimum 0
Maximum 30

Minimum 35
Maximum 70

Multi-axis selections creates 3+2 position for 4th axis rotary or full 5 axis machines. Use Find by Angle to restrict tilting motion.

Minimum Angle

Sets a low limiting range for selecting the holes to machine. Angles are set from the vertical spindle axis.

Angles measured from spindle axis

Angles for through holes

Minimum 0
Maximum 30

Minimum 35
Maximum 70

Multi-axis selections creates 3+2 position for 4th axis rotary or full 5 axis machines.

Maximum Angle

Sets a high limiting range for selecting the holes to machine. Angles are set from the vertical spindle axis.

Angles measured from spindle axis

Angles for through holes

Minimum 0
Maximum 30

Minimum 35
Maximum 70

Multi-axis selections creates 3+2 positions for 4th axis rotary or full 5 axis machines.

Organize Operations

Lets you choose to order by tool changes or hole size.

Minimize tool changes The selected tool is used completely before making a tool change for the next operation.

Group by size Each hole becomes a group with multiple operations.

Sort Groups into folders

Puts each hole feature into a unique folder.

Each hole folder contains multiple operations.

Use Fewest Spot Drills Possible

Uses a single spot drill for all hole sizes.

When deselected, small holes use small spot drills.

Find by Diameter

Sets a limiting range for selecting holes based on diameter.

Set the Maximum Diameter value for the holes to include.

Minimum Diameter

Sets a low limiting range for selecting holes based on diameter.

Set the smallest diameter value to include in the selection.

Maximum Diameter

Sets a high limiting range for selecting holes based on diameter.

Set the largest diameter value to include in the selection.

Thread Size Tolerance

Adds an allowable amount of variation to the diameter of threaded holes. Increase the tolerance to increase the choice of Thread Types available in the Hole Groups tab.

Based on the diameter of a threaded hole, Hole Recognition lists appropriate Thread Types with a range of major and minor diameters. Increasing the tolerance might be useful if the Thread Type you want to use is not listed in the Hole Groups tab.

Limit Depth

Used to set a limiting range for selecting holes based on their depth.

Set the Minimum Depth value and the Maximum Depth value for the holes to include.

Minimum Depth

Used to set a low limiting range for selecting holes based on their depth.

Set the smallest depth value to include in the selection.

Minimum 0 to
Maximum .75

Minimum .8 to
Maximum 1.25

Maximum Depth

Used to set a high limiting range for selecting holes based on depth.

Set the largest depth value to include in the selection.

Minimum 0 to
Maximum .75

Minimum .8 to
Maximum 1.25

Tool Libraries

Select which tool libraries to search when matching tools to hole features.

Check Box shows
selected Libraries

Note: Check - Automatically Create Tools - for generic or non-standard tool sizes.

Automatically Create Tools

When selected tools will be created to match non-standard hole features.

If no Tool Libraries are selected, new tools will be created for all hole features.

Geometry

Steep and Shallow will analyze the geometry curvature and blend 2 toolpaths together. Steep is represented by a Contour toolpath and Shallow is represented by a Scallop type toolpath.

Steep Contour Area

Shallow Area

Steep and Shallow

Avoid Flats

Automatically detects and avoids generating a toolpath over flat areas of the model. Flat areas are detected when they are perpendicular to the Z axis of the tool orientation.

You may want to avoid machining flat areas if you are using a tool that is not suited for flat areas, such as a ball end mill. The flat areas can be machined by a future operation with a more suitable tool, such a flat end mill.

Deselected

Selected

Threshold Angle

The angle measured from the horizontal plane that sets the division between the Shallow areas and the Steep areas of the model.

Steep areas with slopes larger than the angle use a Contour style toolpath. Shallow areas with slopes smaller than the angle use Parallel or Scallop style toolpaths. This is the divider between near flat machining surfaces and side machining surfaces.

30 Deg. Threshold

60 Deg. Threshold

Note: This is not a containment boundary, since the tool will approach from outside the selected area.

Recognise Areas As

Determines if the model is treated as having only shallow areas, only steep areas, or a combination of both.

Steep and shallow - Recognizes the entire model as containing steep areas and shallow areas. A threshold angle determines which areas are steep and which are shallow.

Shallow only – Recognizes the entire model as containing shallow areas, which lets you create a Parallel or Scallop toolpath, and access additional features such as the ability to optimize perpendicular passes.

Steep only – Recognizes the entire model as containing steep areas, which lets you create a Contour toolpath, and access additional features such as the ability to machine undercuts.

Steep and Shallow

Shallow only
Optimized passes

Steep only
Machining undercuts

Tip: You can generate a toolpath over the entire model, or use the Machining Boundary or Slope containment options in the Geometry tab to target a specific area.

Overlap Distance

The amount to extend the toolpath past the Threshold Angle. The Overlap distance is used to blend between the Steep and Shallow areas.

Model curvature

Zero value. Steep and Shallow share the edge

Overlap distance is shown between the dark lines

Note: By default, The Overlap Distance value is three times the Stepover value.

Maximum Remaining Stock

An estimated value used to produce a safer order of machining passes between two nearby steep walls when Steep first is selected as Priority.

When uneven stock material remains from a previous operation between two steep walls, cutting to a large depth on just one of the steep walls creates a heavy load on the tool as it interacts with left-over material around it. It is better to cut alternately between the two steep walls to avoid damaging the tool.

Maximum Remaining Stock is used to reorder the toolpath such that two steep walls near each other are machined at the same Z-level before proceeding to the next Z-level.

Estimate a value that is greater than the distance between toolpath segments around both walls. The tool and model geometry affects when and where the reordering takes place.

Maximum Remaining Stock = 2mm
Steep walls are machined exclusively.

Maximum Remaining Stock = 4mm
Steep walls are machined simultaneously.

In this example, changing the Maximum Remaining Stock value from 2 mm to 4 mm reorders the machining passes.

Note: If no Maximum Remaining Stock value is entered, a default minimum value of 10% of the tool's radius is used.

Order by Depth

Machines the Priority selection by Z-level. One Z-level is completely machined before descending to the next.

When deselected, the Priority selection region is machined in its entirety before moving onto the next region.

Priority = Top First
Order by Depth disabled

Priority = Top First
Order by Depth enabled

Priority = Steep First
Order by Depth disabled

Priority = Steep First
Order by Depth enabled

Priority

Selects the cut order of the Steep and Shallow areas.

Top First
Cut all tops first

Steep First
Cut all sides first

Steep Passes

Controls the contour cuts for the Steep and near vertical walls.

Machine Undercuts

Uses contour passes to machine undercut areas that are otherwise unreachable, because of overhanging geometry. Undercuts can be machined using 3 axes or 5 axes.

For 3-axis machining, you can use tools such as a lollipop, disc, barrel, or dovetail tool to reach undercut areas.

For 5-axis machining, you can use a wider range of tools, including a ball-nosed tool. In addition to selecting Machine Undercuts, you also need to use the settings in the Multi-Axis tab to generate a 5-axis toolpath.

3-axis undercut machining

5-axis undercut machining

Generally, using 5-axis motion when machining undercuts gives you the ability to reach more areas in a single operation, which can save on programming time.

Continuous

Replaces consecutive, closed toolpath contours with a continuous toolpath. This results in a spiral-style toolpath.

This minimizes the number of tool-lifts resulting in cutting passes with no steps between each pass, giving a better surface finish.

Disabled
Tool-lifts on each step

Enabled
Spiral style toolpath

Shallow Passes

Controls the Scallop or Parallel cuts for the Shallow top surfaces.

Type

Specifies whether to use Parallel or Scallop passes in shallow areas.

Parallel passes are a pattern of parallel lines, whereas Scallop passes are concentric offset contours.

Parallel passes

Scallop passes

Continuous

Replaces consecutive, closed toolpath contours with a continuous toolpath. This results in a spiral-style toolpath.

This minimizes the number of tool-lifts resulting in cutting passes with no steps between each pass, giving a better surface finish.

Disabled
Concentric cuts

Enabled
Continous cuts

Order

Determines the order of cutting passes:

Inward - Passes begin on the outside and move inwards.

Outward - Passes begin on the inside and move outwards.

Inward

Outward

Optimize Open Pockets

Gives the tool more freedom to approach a part from the open sides of a pocket, resulting in better cutting conditions, such as:

  • Reducing cuts that take place with the full-width of the tool for better tool life.
  • Reducing sharp corners in the toolpath, which result in fewer changes in direction, reducing potential dwell marks and improving the surface finish.

When deselected, the tool does not enter from outside of the part, which is useful when you want to avoid any clamps or fixtures that are in the way. There are also less tool-lifts, which makes it faster for machining softer materials like foam, where the cutting conditions are not as critical.

Deselected

Selected

Smooth Offsets

Replaces sharp corners in the toolpath with rounded passes.

Sharp corners can slow down the tool noticeably, which can leave dwell marks on the part. Rounded corners help maintain better load conditions on the tool by letting it glide smoothly over the part.

Disabled

Enabled

Remove Cusps at Junctions

Creates a centreline pass over sharp corners in the toolpath to remove any excess material.

Depending on the outer profile geometry of the model, sharp corners can be generated as a Scallop toolpath offsets inwards. Excess material can be left behind between the apexes of the sharp corners, where the distance between the apexes is larger than the programmed Stepover value.

Disabled

Enabled

Fixed Direction

Lets you specify an angle for the direction of Parallel passes.

When deselected, the most suitable angle is automatically calculated, based on the shape of the shallow areas.

Wall Clearance

The distance Parallel passes stay clear of adjacent steep walls. This helps avoid dwell marks on the part.

Wall Clearance

Direction

Specifies if material is removed using climb milling, conventional milling or a combination of both.

Climb milling

Conventional milling

Both Ways
  • Climb milling pulls the tool into the part.
  • Conventional milling pushes the tool away from the part.
  • Both Ways alternates cut direction.

Direction

Specifies if material is removed using climb milling or conventional milling or a combination of both.

Climb milling

Conventional milling
  • Climb milling pulls the tool into the part.
  • Conventional milling pushes the tool away from the part.
  • Both Ways alternates cut direction.

Optimized Perpendicular Passes

On areas steeper than 45 degrees, the parallel passes are replaced by perpendicular passes to improve toolpath coverage.

Deselected
large gaps between passes

Selected
Improved toolpath coverage

Use Multi-Axis

Specifies that the tool should tilt such that it is always normal to the underlying surface.

You can change the additional tilt settings to change how the tool tilts with respect to the underlying surface.

Tool Axis Mode

Specifies the primary way that the tool should tilt when machining the part.

Vertical - Aligns the tool with the specified tool orientation.

Lead and lean - Tilts the tool axis by specifying lead and lean angles. A lead and lean angle of 0 aligns the tool axis so that it is always perpendicular to the surface it contacts. A lead angle tilts the tool in the direction of the cut. A lean angle tilts the tool sideways from the direction of the cut. An example of when you should use lean and/or lead angles is to tilt the tool axis to avoid cutting with the center of a ball-nosed tool.

From Curve - The tip of the tool points away from a sketched curve.

To Curve - The tip of the tool points towards a sketched curve.

From Point - The tip of the tool points away from a sketched point.

To Point - The tip of the tool points towards a sketched point.

Vertical

Lead and lean = 0
1 - Direction of travel
2 - Lead angle tilt direction
3 - Lean angle tilt direction

Tool Axis Mode

Specifies the primary way that the tool should tilt when machining the part.

Vertical - Aligns the tool with the specified tool orientation.

From Point - The tip of the tool points away from a sketched point.

To Point - The tip of the tool points towards a sketched point.

From Curve - The tip of the tool points away from a sketched curve.

To Curve - The tip of the tool points towards a sketched curve.

Vertical

Guiding Curve

Select a curve or line, which you can sketch in the Design workspace, to position the tip of the tool towards or away from.

The tip of the tool uses the section of line or curve that is closest to it to guide the tool.

Sketched line or curve for selection

From curve

To curve

Guiding Point

Select a point, which you can sketch in the Design workspace, to position the tip of the tool towards or away from.

From point

To point

Lead / Lag Angle

Tilts the tool forwards (lead) or backwards (lag) with reference to the direction of travel.

Specify a non-zero angle to avoid cutting with the center of a ball-nosed tool on flat areas.

1 - Direction of travel

1 - Direction of travel
2 - Lead / Lag Angle = +15 degrees

1 - Direction of travel
2 - Lead / Lag Angle = -15 degrees

Lean Angle

Tilts the tool sideways with reference to the direction of travel.

1 - Direction of travel
2 - Sideways tilt direction

You can use a lean angle to tilt the tool axis slightly towards the part to cut with a larger area of the tool. In the example below, cutting with a larger area of the tool lets you use larger stepdown values, resulting in a reduction in machining time.

Lead / Lag Angle = 0
Lean Angle = 0
Stepdown = 0.5 mm

Lead / Lag Angle = 0
Lean Angle = -88
Stepdown = 1 mm

Override Tilt Angle

Maintains the tool-axis tilt at a preferred angle wherever possible.

When machining a steep wall, if a tool is constantly changing its tilting angle unnecessarily, it can leave behind undesired marks on the part. Enable Override Tilt Angle and specify a Preferred Angle to help maintain a constant tilt angle to obtain a better surface finish and reduce the risks of collisions.

No Override
Tool tilts freely

Override Tilt Angle used
Tool stays at a Preferred Angle

Note: The tool stays at the Preferred Angle and may only change its tilt angle when it is necessary to avoid a collision (if Collision Avoidance is enabled).

Preferred Angle

Maintains the tool axis at the specified preferred angle.

The Preferred Angle is measured from the specified tool orientation (if you do not specify a tool orientation in the Geometry tab, then the Setup Z axis is where the Preferred Angle is measured from). Where possible, maintaining the tool axis at a constant angle provides a better surface finish and helps maintain the programmed feed rate.

The preferred angle can be thought of as a conical boundary around the specified tool orientation.

Preferred Angle measured from tool orientation Z axis

To determine where the tool sits on the conical boundary, non-vertical Primary Mode settings provide the tool with an initial tilting direction, as they would if you weren't using the Override Tilt Angle. From the initial tilting direction, the tool axis moves to align with the edge on the boundary that it is closest to.

Initial tilt direction

Closest conical boundary edge

Collision Avoidance

Tilts the tool to avoid collisions between the shaft or holder and the part.

Specify Shaft & Holder clearances (in the Tool tab of this dialog) and select an option from the Avoidance Mode list to specify the direction in which the tool should tilt when avoiding a collision.

Disabled
Collision between holder and part

Enabled
Collision avoided

Warning: Collision avoidance checks only for collisions between the shaft or holder and the part. Use toolpath simulation to check for collisions against the stock.

Avoidance Mode

Sets the direction in which the tool should tilt when avoiding a collision.

Automatic: Automatically selects the direction in which to tilt the tool away from the part until the collision is avoided. Useful for parts that contain lots of features, but it may increase the time needed to calculate the toolpath. Available only when Vertical is selected as the Primary Mode for the tool axis.

For simpler parts, the following To and From options can provide smoother tool axis movement and use less time to calculate the toolpath.

When avoiding a collision:

From point: Tilts the tip of the tool in a direction that is away from a point.
To point: Tilts the tip of the tool in a direction that is towards a point.
From curve: Tilts the tip of the tool in a direction that is away from a curve.
To curve: Tilts the tip of the tool in a direction that is towards a curve.

Note: If the tool needs to tilt beyond the Maximum Tilt tool axis limit to avoid a collision, then that portion of the toolpath is removed.

Guiding Point

From Point

To Point

Guiding Curve

From Curve

To Curve

Smoothing Distance

Specifies the distance over which any sudden axis tilting can be smoothed to provide a better surface finish.

The larger the smoothing distance, the more gradual the transition.

Smoothing Distance = 2 mm

Smoothing Distance = 30 mm

Note: The axis of the tool is shown in yellow above to display how changing the Smoothing Distance affects the motion of the tool.

Smoothing Angle

Sets the maximum angle that the tool axis can deviate from its Primary Mode Tool Axis to provide smooth transitions while moving along the Smoothing Distance. The Smoothing Angle takes effect when there are changes in the machine's A and C, or B and C axes.

This example shows the effect of Smoothing Angle when using a Primary Mode of lead/lag 5 deg, lean 0 deg:

Smoothing Distance = 60 mm
Smoothing Angle = 2 deg
Lead/lag and lean angles can deviate by 2 deg
Sudden change of direction at the corner

Smoothing Distance = 60 mm
Smoothing Angle = 30 deg
Lead/lag and lean angles can deviate by 30 deg
Smoother transition at the corner

Maximum Tilt

Specifies the maximum tilt limit that the tool cannot tilt beyond, measured from the Reference Z.

1 - Minimum tilt
2 - Maximum tilt

Tip: The maximum tilt can be thought of as a conical boundary around the Reference Z.

Tool Axis Limits

Specifies angular limitations of the machine tool, which limits the tilting angle of the tool while cutting a multi-axis toolpath.

Specify a minimum and maximum tilt angle to keep the tool axis within. You may want to limit the tool axis to not tilt beyond a certain angle to avoid colliding into, for example, something you have retrofitted inside your machine tool.

Machine Inflinced Flats

Machines flat areas that are inclined in reference to the tool axis. When deselected, only flat areas that are perpendicular to the tool axis get machined.

Deselected

Selected

Tool Axis Limits

Determines where the machine's angular limits are measured from.

  • Setup Z - Sets the angular limits from the Z axis of the setup.
  • Tool Orientation - Sets the angular limits from the Z axis of the tool orientation.

Tip: In scenarios where you change the tool orientation to machine an area, you can use the Setup Z to set the tilt angle limits so that you can contain the toolpath to predictable regions.

Tool Axis Limits

Specifies what reference when setting the tool's tilting angles.

  • Setup Z axis - Sets the tilt angles using the Z axis of the setup.
  • Tool Orientation Z axis - Sets the tilt angles using the Z axis of the tool orientation.

If the Z axis is vertical, then all horizontal areas with respect to it are at a 0 degree inclination.

Tip: In scenarios where you change the tool orientation to machine flat areas that are slightly inclined, you can use the Setup Z to set the tilt angle limits so that you can contain the toolpath to predictable regions.

Minimum Tilt

Specifies the minimum allowable tilt angle of the tool from the Reference Z.

If the Z axis reference is vertical, then a minimum tilt angle of zero degrees machines all horizontal surfaces.

Minimium Tilt = 0 degrees
Maximum Tilt = 30 degrees

Maximum Tilt

Specifies the maximum allowable tilt angle of the tool from the Reference Z.

Minimium Tilt = 35 degrees
Maximum Tilt = 45 degrees

Minimum Tilt

Specifies the minimum tilt limit that the tool cannot tilt below, measured from the Reference Z.

1 - Minimum tilt
2 - Maximum tilt

Tip: The minimum tilt can be thought of as a conical boundary around the Reference Z.

Limit Type

Maximum Tilt - Specify a Maximum Tilt angle that the tool axis should not tilt beyond. You can use the limit specified by the machine tool manufacturer. Alternatively, determine a safe limit if you have retrofitted something inside your machine tool.

Areas Beyond Limit

Determines what to do with areas of the toolpath that exceed the machine's tilt limits:

  • Trim toolpath - Remove the portion of the toolpath that tilts the tool beyond the tilt limits. Use this option if your tool axis angle is critical for your surface finish and then complete machining the part using another setup.
  • Machine at tilt limit - Select to keep the tool axis at the tilt limit upon reaching it. Use this option to continue machining with the toolpath in the current Setup if the tool axis angle is not critical for your surface finish.

In the example below, with Trim toolpath selected and Maximum Tilt Angle set to 90 degrees, nothing is trimmed as the tool axis always stays within 90 degrees. When the Maximum Tilt Angle is set to 65 degrees, the portion that tilts the tool axis beyond 65 degrees is trimmed.

Maximum Tilt = 90 degrees
Trim toolpath

Maximum Tilt = 65 degrees
Trim toolpath

With Machine at tilt limit selected, the toolpath is kept, but machined at the maximum tilt limit of 65 degrees.

Maximum Tilt = 65 degrees
Machine at maximum tilt

4th Axis Orientation

Specifies the orientation of the rotary axis.

The Orientation drop-down menu provides the following options to set the orientation of your rotary axis:

Setup X Axis - Uses the X axis of the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) of the current setup as the rotary axis. As a result, the tool always points perpendicular to X.

Setup Y Axis - Uses the Y axis of the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) of the current setup as the rotary axis. As a result, the tool points perpendicular to Y.

Setup Z Axis - Uses the Z axis of the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) of the current setup as the rotary axis. As a result, the tool points perpendicular to Z.

Model orientation - Uses the coordinate system (WCS) of the current part as the rotary axis.

Select rotary axis - Select a plane to set the rotary axis perpendicular to. You can also select an edge to set the rotary axis parallel to.

Select coordinate system - Sets a specific rotary axis orientation for this operation from a defined User Coordinate System (UCS) in the model. This uses both the origin and orientation of the existing coordinate system. Use this option if your model does not contain a suitable point and plane for your operation.

Rotary Axis

Select a plane to set the rotary axis perpendicular to. You can also select an edge to set the rotary axis parallel to. Remember that the tool axis is always perpendicular to the rotary axis.

The example below shows selecting a plane to set the rotary axis perpendicular to, and shows the resultant toolpath, which has the tool axis always parallel to the plane. The tool axis cannot tilt into or out of the plane.

Selecting a plane
Rotary axis perpendicular to plane

Tool axis direction aligns with plane

Smoothing

Smooths the toolpath to reduce the machining time and improves the surface finish of a part.

Depending on your machine tool, to achieve smoother motion, you can choose to:

  • Reduce the number of points on a toolpath by replacing multiple lines in curved areas with arcs; or
  • Replace old points with new points, which are evenly spaced along the toolpath wherever possible.

Smoothing off

Fit arcs

Evenly spaced points

Note: The smoothing tolerance is half the tolerance specified for the toolpath by default.

Smoothing Mode

Specifies how to smooth the toolpath.

Smoothing turned off

Fit Arcs applied

Fit arcs - Replaces multiple lines in curved areas with arcs while keeping within the toolpath tolerance. If the tolerance cannot be met, the arcs are not applied. Fitting arcs will reduce the size of the G-code file, making it useful for older machines with slower CNC controllers that work better with smaller file sizes.

Evenly spaced points

Evenly spaced points - Appropriate for newer machines with faster CNC controllers that are able to handle a large number of points.

1 - Removes old points and inserts new points along cutting moves and arranges them such that they are equally spaced apart wherever possible. Adding new points may increase calculation time to generate a toolpath, however, the equally spaced points mean significant time reductions can be achieved on the machine tool.

2 - Points may be more closely clustered around corners to keep within the toolpath tolerance.

Maximum Spacing

Specifies the maximum distance between consecutive points on a cutting move.

Maximum Spacing

Lead-In Radius

Specifies the radius for lead-in moves.

Lead-In Radius

Vertical Lead-In Radius

The radius of the vertical arc smoothing the entry move as it goes from the entry move to the toolpath itself.

Vertical Lead-In Radius

Lead-Out Radius

Specifies the radius for lead-out moves.

Lead-Out Radius

Vertical Lead-Out Radius

Specifies the radius of the vertical lead-out.

Vertical Lead-Out Radius

Layers per element

Controls the mesh resolution by specifying the number of powder layers grouped together to form the smallest element.

Enter a value between 5 and 25. The higher the value, the larger the voxel (volume element) size and the coarser the mesh.

To ensure mesh convergence, specify a value so that there are at least two elements through the thinnest cross-section of the mesh. A three-part mesh study is required to prove mesh convergence.

Example of a mesh that does not meet the minimum of two elements through the thinnest cross-section.

Coarsening Generations

The maximum number of times that the elements of the mesh are coarsened at, and immediately below, the current deposition layer.

Enter a value between 0 and 6. The higher the value, the coarser the mesh. The value must be less than, or equal to, the Max Adaptivity Level.

Coarsening is the combining of smaller elements in areas where there is low detail. If the geometry is not suitable to coarsening, the mesh is not adapted. Elements representing fine detail in critical areas is determined by the number of Layers per Element.

Max Adaptivity Level

The maximum number of times that the elements of the mesh are coarsened away from the deposition area and within the build platform.

Enter a value between 0 and 6. The higher the value, the coarser the mesh. A value of 0 coarsens only the top layer of the build platform.

Coarsening is the combining of smaller elements in areas where there is low detail. If the geometry is not suitable to coarsening, the mesh is not adapted.

Platform Thickness

The distance between the top and bottom of the build platform.

Enter a value between 1 and 200 mm or between 0.0394 and 7.8740 inches.

Platform Heating

Specifies whether the build platform is heated or not.

  • None: The build platform is not heated, or the temperature is not known.
  • Initial: The build platform is pre-heated to a specific temperature.
  • Controlled: The base of the build platform keeps a constant temperature during the entire manufacturing process.

Temperature

The temperature of the build platform.

Enter a value between 0 and 1000 Celsius or between 32 and 1831 Fahrenheit.

Automatically Calculate Support Volume Fraction

Specifies whether the volume fraction for homogenized support structures is manually, or automatically, set.

Select to use an automatic volume fraction.

Deselect to manually set a volume fraction.

Lattice-type support structures are homogenized rather than meshed directly. Homogenization creates a volumetric representation, scaling the material properties by an automatically calculated volume fraction. The volume fraction is the ratio of the actual support volume over the homogenized volume.

Manual Volume Fraction

The fraction of the volume of the homogenized supports to the volume of the actual supports.

Enter a value between 0 and 1. For example, a value of 0.15 means that the volume of the homogenized supports is 15% of the volume of the actual supports.

Link Feedrate

Defines the speed of the probe during link moves, which are performed before and after the probe leads in and then touches the part. Link moves are displayed in yellow in the canvas.

Lead-In Feedrate

Defines the speed of the probe during lead moves, which are performed before and after the probe touches the part. Lead moves are displayed in green in the canvas.

Note: Increasing the Lead-In Feedrate does not change the accuracy of the measurements, as it does not affect the measure moves. However, the value can cause false triggers if the acceleration and deceleration of the machine is too high, triggering the probe.

Measure Feedrate

Defines the speed of the probe during measure moves, which is when the probe touches the part. Measure moves are displayed in blue in the canvas.

Note: The Measure Feedrate must match the calibration feedrate on the machine to ensure the best accuracy.

Positions

Specifies contact points to be probed.

In the canvas, click the model to specify. Click and drag a contact point to reposition it. Hold the Shift key and click a contact point to delete it.

Order

Lets you choose the order that the specified contact points are probed.

You can have the points probed in the order that you created them. Or choose an optimized order that minimizes the distance that the probe travels along the X and Y axes. If you choose an optimized order and you create, reposition, or delete a point, the order is automatically updated.

Order by Selection

Optimize XY Travel

Reverse Order

Swaps around the order that the specified contact points are probed, so that the point that is probed first is instead probed last.

Selected

Deselected

Surface Offset

Specifies the positive or negative distance from the surface of the model, from which contact points are measured.

This compensates for known differences between the thickness of the part and the model. The offset is applied normal to the surface at the contact point, with positive values in the direction of the probe.

Upper Tolerance

Specifies the upper limit of the tolerance band.

The tolerance band is the acceptable amount of deviation relative to the nominal value. If a point is above or below the tolerance band, the point is considered out of tolerance.

Lower Tolerance

Specifies the lower limit of the tolerance band.

The tolerance band is the acceptable amount of deviation relative to the nominal value. If a point is above or below the tolerance band, the point is considered out of tolerance.

Select Same Diameter

Selects all the holes and bosses that have the same diameter as the currently selected hole or boss. For example, selecting a single 15 mm diameter hole automatically selects three other holes with the same diameter.

If you multiselect holes or bosses of different diameters, all holes or bosses of those diameters are selected. If holes or bosses with the same diameter are added later, regenerating the operation automatically includes the added holes or bosses in the probing cycle.

Only Same Depth

Deselects any holes or bosses of the same diameter that do not share the top-to-bottom distance of the currently selected hole or boss. These holes or bosses are not included in the probing cycle.

Only Same Z Top Height

Deselects any holes or bosses of the same diameter that do not share the Z top height of the currently selected hole or boss. These holes or bosses are not included in the probing cycle.

Check for Occlusions

Deselects any holes or bosses of the same diameter that cannot be probed because of the current tool orientation. These holes or bosses are not included in the probing cycle.

For example, if a hole is on the underside of a part and the probe cannot reach it, the hole is not probed.

Check for Occlusions

Deselects any holes of the same diameter that cannot be drilled because of the current tool orientation.

For example, if a hole is on the underside of a part and the drill cannot reach it, the hole is not drilled.

Deselected

Selected

Containment Boundary

Deselects any holes or bosses of the same diameter that are not within the specified containment boundary.

Click an edge or sketch on the model or stock to specify the containment boundary.

Order by Depth

Specifies that holes or bosses are probed starting with those at the lowest Z height.

Order

Lets you choose the order that the selected holes or bosses are probed.

You can have the holes or bosses probed in the order that you selected them or choose an optimized order that minimizes the distance that the probe travels. You can also choose to probe holes or bosses from the center and outwards or probe them in the X or Y direction. If you select or deselect a hole or boss, the order is automatically updated.

Order Selected

Optimize Order

Order Inside-Out

Order by X

Bidirectional

Probes holes or bosses bidirectionally, as opposed to unidirectionally, when Order by X or Order by Y has been selected. For example:

Order by X

Order by X and Bidirectional

Reverse Order

Swaps around the order that selected holes or bosses are probed, so that the hole or boss that is probed first is instead probed last.

Selected

Deselected

Approach

Specifies the distance from the contact point at which the probe starts to approach the part for measurement.

Overtravel

Specifies the maximum distance the probe can move beyond the expected contact point and still record a measurement. If no contact is made within this distance, the probe returns an invalid measurement.

From

Specifies what the Clearance Height is offset from. The Clearance Height is the first height that the probe moves to on its way to the start of probing. It is also the height that the probe returns to after probing is finished.

Choose to offset from another height; the top or bottom of the model or stock; a selected point, edge, or face on the model; the top of the lowest probed surface; or the origin.

From

Specifies what the Retract Height is offset from. The Retract Height is an intermediate height between the Clearance Height and the Bottom Height.

Choose to offset from another height; the top or bottom of the model or stock; a selected point, edge, or face on the model; the top of the lowest probed surface; or the origin.

Position

Specifies the acceptable value of deviation in position of the geometric feature. This bilateral tolerance is the amount that the position of the geometric feature can vary from its nominal position and still be considered in tolerance.

A geometric feature whose deviation is beyond this value is considered out of tolerance. For example, when probing the location of a boss feature, the positional tolerance can be thought of as the allowable deviation in the X and Y of the center point of the feature.

Probing the position of a boss

Deviation of the center point
1 - Deviation in X axis.
2 - Deviation in Y axis.

Size

Specifies the acceptable value of deviation in size of the geometric feature. This bilateral tolerance is the amount that the size of the geometric feature can vary above or below the expected dimension and still be considered in tolerance.

A geometric feature whose deviation is beyond this value is considered out of tolerance. For example, when probing the diameter of a boss feature, the size tolerance can be thought of as a minimum and maximum diameter band around the actual diameter.

Probing the diameter of a boss

Size tolerance band

Angle

Specifies the acceptable value of deviation in angle of the geometric feature. This bilateral tolerance is the amount that the angle of the geometric feature can vary and still be considered in tolerance.

A geometric feature whose deviation is beyond this value is considered out of tolerance. For example, when probing a face using Angle Along Y-Axis, the angle is measured from the face to the plane that is normal to the Y axis.

Probing the angle of a face

Angle tolerance
1 - Plane normal to Y axis.

Out of Position Action

Enables the specified action when a measured contact point is out of tolerance.

When deselected, no action is taken.

Action

Instructs the machine tool to stop probing, and displays a message on the controller, when a measured contact point is out of tolerance.

Out of Position Action

Enables the specified action when the geometric feature's position is out of tolerance.

When deselected, no action is taken.

Action

Instructs the machine tool to stop machining, and displays a message on the controller, when the geometric feature's position is out of tolerance.

Wrong Size Action

Enables the specified action when the geometric feature's size is out of tolerance.

When deselected, no action is taken.

Action

Instructs the machine tool to stop machining, and displays a message on the controller, when the geometric feature's size is out of tolerance.

Askew Action

Enables the specified action when the geometric feature's angle is out of tolerance.

When deselected, no action is taken.

Action

Instructs the machine tool to stop machining, and displays a message on the controller, when the geometric feature's angle is out of tolerance.

Update Tool Wear

Specifies whether to update the tool-wear compensation stored in the controller of the machine tool.

Tools wear away as they are used. The physical size of the tool gets smaller and the edge of the cutter becomes blunt causing deflection. Updating the compensation counteracts tool wear, so that subsequent machining operations remain accurate.

Operation

Specifies the reference machining operation used to update the tool-wear compensation.

In the Browser, select the machining operation whose tool you want to update. This should be the operation that has just machined the feature you are probing. If this probing operation uses a Probe Type other than Z Surface, the reference machining operation must use a Compensation Type of Control, Wear, or Inverse Wear.

Minimum Update Threshold

Specifies the smallest deviation in the tool, above which tool-wear compensation is updated.

Enter a positive value. For example, a value of 0.05 mm means that the tool wear is updated only when the tool's deviation is 0.05 mm or more. A value of zero always updates the compensation.

Error Correction %

Specifies, as a percentage of the tool's deviation, how much the tool-wear compensation gets updated.

Enter a value between 0 and 100. For example, if a tool's deviation is 0.05 mm and the error correction is 80%, the tool-wear compensation is updated as 0.04 mm.

WCS

Activates the ability to update the active Work Offset for probing.

This has no direct visual effect in the system, but sends codes to the post processor to control changes to the NC output.

Override Driving WCS

Controls which coordinate system drives this probing operation.

When selected, the probe is driven from a different coordinate system (WCS Override) to that defined in the setup (WCS Offset). The WCS Override for this probing operation is not updated, but the WCS Offset for subsequent machining operations is updated. This locks the coordinate system for the probe.

Example of updated WCS Offset (1=G54), but unchanged WCS Override (2=G55), for multiple parts:

Override Driving WCS selected

When deselected, the probe is driven from the same coordinate system as that defined in the setup (WCS Offset). The WCS Offset for this probing operation and subsequent machining operations is updated.

Example of updated WCS Offset (1=G54) for multiple parts:

Override Driving WCS deselected

WCS Override

The number of the coordinate system that drives this probing operation. The number matches a specific G-code, which is defined by the post processor.

WCS To Be Updated

The number of the coordinate system in the setup, which will be updated based on the results of this probing operation. The number matches a specific G-code, which is defined by the post processor.

Print Results

Enables probing results to be output to the machine's display, a file on the machine control, or an external device.

This function depends on the ability of the post processor, the machine control, and the machine's probing cycle macros. A common use is to save the data to a file on the local system.

Increment Component

Separates the results in the report using an incremented numbering system. It increments the part number in the results while resetting the feature number. This is useful when probing the same geometric feature on multiple parts.

When deselected, the feature number is incremented but not the part number. This is useful when probing multiple geometric features on a single part. These functions depend on the abilities of the post processor and the machine's probing cycle macros.

Link Feedrate

Defines the speed of the probe during link moves, which are performed before and after the probe leads in and then touches the part. Link moves are displayed in yellow in the canvas

Lead-In Feedrate

Defines the speed of the probe during lead moves, which are performed before and after the probe touches the part. Lead moves are displayed in green in the canvas.

If the probe is set up to perform two touches, the first touch is at the Lead-In Feedrate and then the second touch is at the Measure Feedrate.

Note: Increasing Lead-In Feedrate does not change the accuracy of the measurements, as it does not affect the measure moves. However, the value can cause false triggers if the acceleration and deceleration of the machine is too high, triggering the probe.

Measure Feedrate

Defines the speed of the probe during measure moves, which is when the probe touches the part.

If the probe is set up to perform two touches, the first touch is at the Lead-In Feedrate and then the second touch is at the Measure Feedrate.

Note: The Measure Feedrate must match the calibration feedrate on the machine to ensure the best accuracy.

From

Specifies what the Bottom Height is offset from. The Bottom Height is the final probing depth. This reference and the Offset value establish the true probing depth. The position is to the contact point of the probe.

Choose to offset from another height; the top or bottom of the model or stock; a selected point, edge, or face on the model; the top of the lowest probed surface; or the origin.

Offset

Adjusts the relative position of the height. This position represents the tip, not the contact point (side) of the probe.

Enter a value or click and drag the height in the canvas.

From

Specifies what the Clearance Height is offset from. The Clearance Height is the first height that the probe moves to on its way to the start of probing. It is also the height that the probe returns to after probing is finished.

Choose to offset from another height; the top or bottom of the model or stock; a selected point, edge, or face on the model; the top of the lowest probed surface; or the origin.

Offset

Adjusts the relative position of the height.

Enter a value or click and drag the height in the canvas.

From

Specifies what the Retract Height is offset from. The Retract Height is an intermediate height between the Clearance Height and the Bottom Height.

Choose to offset from another height; the top or bottom of the model or stock; a selected point, edge, or face on the model; the top of the lowest probed surface; or the origin.

Offset

Adjusts the relative position of the height.

Enter a value or click and drag the height in the canvas.

From

Specifies the first height that the tool moves to on its way to the start of the toolpath.
  • Retract Height: Incremental offset from the Retract Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Bottom.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.

From

Specifies the height that the tool moves up to before the next layer of passes.
  • Clearance Height: Incremental offset from the Clearance Height.
  • Model Top: Incremental offset from the Model Top.
  • Model Bottom: Incremental offset from the Model Bottom.
  • Selection: Incremental offset from a point (vertex), edge, or face selected on the model.
  • Origin (Absolute): Absolute offset from the origin defined in the Setup dialog or in the Tool Orientation group of this dialog.

Type

To inspect the surface of a part and compare the measurements to nominal values, you must first align the CAD model to the part.

Aligning the CAD model to the part locks the three axes of translation and three axes of rotation.

Alignment Type

The method used to align the CAD model to the physical part. Both methods use different combinations of features to lock the three axes of translation and three axes of rotation.

3 Planes: Uses three planes. No two planes can be parallel.

Plane and 2 Circles: Uses a plane, the line between two circles, and the center of one of the circles. The two circles must be parallel to the plane.

Plane 1

The first plane needed to align the CAD model to the part.

In the canvas, click a flat face on the CAD model.

Plane 2

The second plane needed to align the CAD model to the part.

In the canvas, click a flat face on the CAD model. Choose a face that is non-parallel to Plane 1.

Plane 3

The third plane needed to align the CAD model to the part.

In the canvas, click a flat face on the CAD model. Choose a face that is non-parallel to Plane 1 and Plane 2.

Name

The first circle needed to align the CAD model to the part.

In the canvas, parallel to Plane 1, click the edge of a circle on the CAD model.

Circle 2

The second circle needed to align the CAD model to the part.

In the canvas, parallel to Plane 1, click the edge of another circle on the CAD model. The circle must be different to the one used for Circle 1.

Result

The results after measuring the features.

Rotary Axis

Set the Rotary Axis orientation such that it matches your machine's rotary axis setup.

Orientation

Specifies the orientation of the rotary axis to match how your part is set up on the machine.

Setup X Axis - Uses the X axis of the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) of the current setup as the rotary axis.

Setup Y Axis - Uses the Y axis of the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) of the current setup as the rotary axis.

Setup Z Axis - Uses the Z axis of the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) of the current setup as the rotary axis.

Model orientation - Uses the coordinate system (WCS) of the current part as the rotary axis.

Select rotary axis - Select a flat face to set the rotary axis perpendicular to, or select a circular face to set the center of the face as the point the rotary axis runs through.

Select coordinate system - Sets a specific rotary axis orientation for this operation from a defined User Coordinate System (UCS) in the model. This uses both the origin and orientation of the existing coordinate system. Use this option if your model does not contain a suitable point and plane for your operation.

Origin

The Origin drop-down menu offers the following options for locating the rotary axis:

Setup WCS origin - Uses the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) origin of the current setup for the rotary axis.

Model origin - Uses the coordinate system (WCS) origin of the current part for the rotary axis.

Selected point - lets you select a vertex or an edge for the rotary axis.

Rotary Axis

Select a flat or circular face, or an edge to set the orientation of your rotary axis.

Selecting a flat face sets the rotary axis orientation perpendicular to that face.

Selecting a circular face sets the rotary axis orientation parallel to the axis of the center of that face.

Selecting an edge sets the rotary axis orientation parallel to that edge.

Angular Limits

Controls the angular containment of a toolpath. Angular limits can be applied to circular and line style toolpaths only.

Specify a From Point to set where machining passes begin from and then use the End Point Mode to control where the machining passes should end.

Angular limits
Selecting From and To Point

Line style toolpath with angular limits

From Point

Click a point on a model to specify where the angular containment of the toolpath should begin from.

From Point

To Point

Click a point on a model to specify where the angular containment of the toolpath should end.

To Point

After your selection, a pointer appears to show you where the tool enters the containment boundary to begin cutting.

Tool entry location

End point mode

Select a mode to specify the end point of the angular containment for the toolpath.

Full 360 - Select to machine the entire part, beginning the first pass from your selected start point.
Select end point - Select to let you click a point on the model to specify the end point for the angular containment.
Specify end angle - Select to let you input an angle, which measured from the From Point.

Full 360

Select end point
Yellow dots illustrating From and To Point

Specify end angle
To Angle = -45 degrees

To Angle

Specifies the end angular position around the rotary axis for machining passes.

To Angle = 90 deg

To Angle = -90 deg

To Angle = 120 deg

Flip Sector

Inverts the current angular containment selection.

Flip Sector deselected

Flip Sector selected

Style

Specifies the style of the machining passes for better control.

Spiral - Machines the part in a continuous cut along the length of the part. To ensure a clean finish, a full circle is cut at the two ends.
Line - Moves the tool along the rotary axis in straight lines, with the rotary axis used only at the end of each pass to reposition the part.
Circular - Rotates the part with the tool at a fixed position, effectively machining a circle. The tool then steps over the required amount and machines the next circle.

Spiral

Line

Circular

Spiral side view

Line side view

Circular side view

Tool Offset

Avoids using the center of a tool to cut the part.

Offsets the contact point of the tool with the part, which is the center of the tool by default, to a specified value so you can machine with the flutes of a tool instead of its center.

In the example below, the Tool Offset moves the tool from its start position in the direction of the Y axis.

Contact point
Center of the tool
Tool Offset = 0 mm

Contact point
Flute of the tool
Tool Offset = 15 mm

Tool Offset = 0 mm

Tool Offset = 15 mm

Stepover

Specifies the angular stepover between passes on a line-style toolpath.

Angular Stepover

Collision Avoidance

Automatically tilts the tool around the rotary axis to avoid collisions between the shaft or holder and the part. If the collision cannot be avoided with 4-axis motion, the colliding part of the toolpath is trimmed away.

In the Tool tab, specify Shaft & Holder clearances so that collision avoidance can prevent the tool from getting too close to the part.

In the example below, the yellow arrow shows the direction of the passes, and the orange arrow shows the direction the tool tilts, which is around the rotary axis, to avoid the collision.

Collision avoidance OFF
Holder collides with part

Collision avoidance ON
Collision avoided

Smoothing Distance

The distance over which any sudden axis tilting can be smoothed to provide a better surface finish.

The larger the smoothing distance, the more gradual the transition.

Smoothing Distance = 2 mm

Smoothing Distance = 30 mm

Note: The axis of the tool is shown in yellow above to display how changing the Smoothing Distance affects the motion of the tool.

Lead-In Extension

Specifies the length for the lead-in extension move.

Lead-In Extension

Lead-In Radius

Specifies the radius for the lead-in move.

Lead-In Radius

Lead-Out Radius

Specifies the radius for the lead-out move.

Lead-out Radius

Lead-Out Extension

Specifies the length for the lead-out extension move.

Lead-Out Extension

Trim Type

Select a tool to use for trimming:

Polygon - Lets you place points to create a polygon over an area of a toolpath.
Plane - Lets you specify a plane to cover an area of a toolpath.
Boundary - Lets you select a closed contour on the model to use as a boundary over an area of a toolpath.

Planes and boundaries are associative to the model, meaning they can be regenerated if the model changes.

Polygon

Plane

Boundary

Note: When trimming, use the orthographic view. Right-click the ViewCube and select Orthographic.

Polygon points

Click positions over an area of a toolpath to place points that create a polygon.

Once you create a polygon, a preview extrusion appears along the direction of the initial view to help visualize the area of the toolpath it is covering.

Points placed over a toolpath

Preview extrusion of the polygon

Use the Points Editor to help you place your points.

Points Editor

1 - Click Accept to complete creating the polygon.
2 - Click Cancel to undo any changes since the last Accept.
3 - Click Delete to remove the active polygon.
4 - Use Insert Point Mode to add more points by clicking near or on an existing line. You can click and hold to drag the additional points to change the shape of the polygon.
5 - Use Delete Point Mode to click on points to delete them.
6 - Click Restore View to return to the initial view you were on when you first started to place points.

Keep

Specifies which side to keep. Keeping both sides splits a toolpath into two separate toolpaths, which you can then apply further modifactions to.

Polygon example

Keep Inside

Keep Outside

Note: If you are using a plane to perform the trim, the toolpath to be kept is highlighted in blue and the toolpath to be removed is highlight in red.

Plane Normal

Choose the setup axes, tool orientation axes, or a selection as the reference for the trimming plane.

The example below shows how selecting the Setup Z Axis sets the plane perpendicular to that axis.

Setup Z Axis

Selection

Select geometry in the canvas, such as faces or edges, to use as a reference for the plane.

For example, a face selection creates an offset plane and an edge selection creates a plane that is perpendicular to the edge.

Face selection

Edge selection

Plane Origin

Snaps the plane to the location of the specified origin.

For example, when selecting an edge as the Plane Normal, using Center of Selection snaps the plane to the center of the edge.

Center of selection

Plane

Snaps the plane to a selected point on the model.

Plane Offset

Offsets the plane to change the area of the toolpath that is to be trimmed.

Use the drag handle in the canvas, or enter a negative or positive offset value.

Boundary

Select one or more closed contours on the model to specify the trimming boundaries.

After specifying a boundary, a preview extrusion appears to let you visualize the trimming boundary.

Flatten Direction

Flattens the boundary in the specified direction so that it can be used to calculate the trim.

The example below shows how changing the flatten direction affects the area that gets trimmed.

Boundary

Flatten to Setup Z Axis

Flatten to Setup Y Axis

Selection

Select geometry in the canvas, such as faces or edges, to specify the flatten direction.

For example, a face selection flattens the curve to that face, and an edge selection flattens the curve so that it is perpendicular to that edge.

Face selection example

Edge selection example

Bounday Offset

Offsets the specified boundary.

A positive value offsets the boundary outwards and a negative value offsets the boundary inwards.

5mm boundary offset

Tool Containment

Controls the extent to which a toolpath is trimmed based on its boundary conditions.

Tool center on boundary - Trims the toolpath such that the center of the tool can be on the boundary. This setting ensures that the entire surface inside the boundary is machined. However, areas outside the boundary might also be machined.

Tool inside of boundary - Trims the toolpath such that the entire tool stays inside the boundary. As a result, the entire surface contained by the boundary might not be machined.

Tool outside of boundary - Trims the toolpath such that the tool edge can move on the outside edge of the boundary.

Center

Inside

Outside

Selection

Click a pass or segment in the canvas to select it. Use window or crossing selection to select multiple passes or segments.

Tip: Click and drag from left to right to select all passes or segments that are entirely enclosed by the window (window selection). Click and drag from right to left to select all passes or segments that are crossed by the window (crossing selection).

Passes
Window selection
(Left to right)

Passes
Crossing selection
(Right to left)

Segments
Window selection
(Left to right)

Segments
Crossing selection
(Right to left)

Selection

Filters the selection type between passes and segments of a toolpath.

Passes
Entire cutting move

Segments
Part of a cutting move

Invert Selection

Inverts the current selection of passes and segments.

Useful for speeding up the selection process by selecting a few passes or segments that you want to keep, then inverting the selection so that the remainder passes or segments are selected for deletion.

Normal selection

Inverted selection

Selection

Click in the canvas to create a line that intersects closed passes at the desired new tool-entry positions.

To delete a line, click the line in the canvas then press the Delete key.

Tool Display Controls

Enable to activate the tool display and set the display options.

Tool

Select the segment of the tool or holder to display.

Flute - Displays the cutting edge of the tool.
Shaft - Displays the cutting edge and upper section of the tool.
Holder - All the above plus the tool holder, if one is defined.

Flute

Shaft

Holder

Transparent

Enable to make the tool translucent. Convenient for seeing the part and cut, thru the tool.

Disabled

Enabled

Transparent

Enable to make the tool translucent. Convenient for seeing the part and cut, thru the tool.
