Toolpath Display Controls

Enable to activate the toolpath display and set the display options.

Show Points

Enable to display a point at the end of each cut position. Useful for analyzing toolpaths with multiple small segments.

Disabled - No points

Enabled - Points shown

Show Points

Enable to display a point at the end of each cut position. Useful for analyzing toolpaths with multiple small segments.

Disabled - No points

Enabled - Points shown

Toolpath Display Mode

Controls which sections of the cutting moves will be displayed and in what order.

All toolpath - Displays all selected toolpaths.
Before position - The toolpath positions before the move is displayed.
After position - The toolpath is displayed before the move. The move erases the path.
Operation - Displays only the current operation.
Tail - Displays a trail from the last position.

All

Before

After

Operation

Tail

Stock Display Controls

Enable to activate the stock display and set the display options.

Stock Display Mode

This controls the performance of the simulation.

Standard - Displays 2 axis thru 5 axis toolpaths, with support for undercuts and collision detection.

Fast for 3X only - Faster than Standard and offers additional Colorization options. Only for 3 axis toolpath verification. Does not support collision detection.

Stock Colorization

Controls how the stock material is displayed.

Material - The workpiece appearance is selected from the Material drop-down menu.
Operation - Displays a unique color for each toolpath operation.
Tool - Displays a unique color for each cutter path by tool number.
Comparison - Uses colors to indicate if there is excess material, gouged material, or if the stock is in-tolerance.

Material

Operation

Tool

Comparison

Material

Select a material type to display for the Simulation, to enhance visibility.

Applies when using Colorization - Material.

Shown with Ceramic selected

Transparent

Enable to make the stock model translucent.

Convenient for seeing the part model thru the stock model.

Transparent Enabled

Transparent

Enable to make the stock model translucent.

Convenient for seeing the part model thru the stock model.

Transparent Enabled

Stop on collision

Enable to force the simulation to stop if a collision or gouge is detected.

Stock to leave

Specifies how much stock has been left on the model.

Excess material and gouges are measured from this value, above the models actual surface. A value of zero displays deviations directly from the model surface.

Applies when using Colorization - Comparison.

Tolerance

The tolerance above and below the Stock to leave, beyond which material is considered excess or gouged.

Applies when using Colorization - Comparison.

Viewpoint

Controls how you view the simulation.

Machine base - Maintains the view such that the base of the machine appears stationary on-screen while the rotary and linear axes, the tool, and the model move relative to it.
Model - Maintains the view such that the model appears stationary on-screen while the tool moves relative to it.
Tool - Maintains the view such that the tool appears stationary on-screen while the model moves relative to it. Use this option when zooming in to view the movement of the tool more closely. Also useful for visualizing threading operations or rotary operations.

Machine base

Model

Tool

Note: The Machine base option is available only when using a machine during simulation.

4-axis Limit

Generates a 4-axis toolpath instead of a 5-axis toolpath.

The Flow strategy takes the WCS Z Axis (if no tool orientation is set) or the tool orientation Z axis as the rotary axis. The tool gets locked onto the plane that is perpendicular to the rotary axis.

Manufacturing Model

Select a Manufacturing Model that is to be considered for the toolpath calculation.

An example of using multiple Manufacturing Models is to model the work-holding equipment and stock for the top side of a part, and then to model a slightly different work-holding arrangement for the bottom side of the part.

Setup 1
Manufacturing Model 1

Setup 2
Manufacturing Model 2

Tip: In the Browser, hover over a Setup to see which Manufacturing Model is associated with that Setup.

Turn

Changes the direction in which the Z axis tilts. The Turn manipulator is always perpendicular to the Setup Z axis.

Turn manipulator

Tilt

Tilts the Z axis in the direction set by the Turn manipulator.

Tilt manipulator

Align to View

Automatically enters Turn and Tilt values so that the Z axis points towards the current view.

Initial tool orientation

Align to View

Accessibility Analysis

Uses the currently set tool orientation to check for areas that will be inaccessible for the tool.

Inaccessible areas are highlighted in red, making it useful to check for undercut areas.

Off

On

Position

Positions the part and any fixturing onto the machine's table.

Part Attach Point

Sets the attach point that is used to connect the part to the table's attach point.

Selected point - Select a point on the geometry that is visible in the canvas.

Model box point - Select a point on the model's bounding box.

Fixture box point - Select a point on the fixture's bounding box.

Stock box point - Select a point on the stock's bounding box.

Note: If Fixture box point is selected but no fixtures are defined in the Setup tab, the model's bounding box is used instead.

Selected Point

Select a point on the geometry that is visible in the canvas.

You can also select a straight or circular edge to use the center point of the edge.

Model Point

Select a point on the model's bounding box.

Fixture Point

Select a point on the fixture's bounding box.

The fixture is selected in the Fixture group, found in the Setup tab.

Stock Point

Select a point on the stock's bounding box.

Table Attach Point

Select a point on the table to offset the part attach point from.

X Distance

Offsets the part attach point from the table's attach point in the X direction.

Y Distance

Offsets the part attach point from the table's attach point in the Y direction.

Z Distance

Offsets the part attach point from the table's attach point in the Z direction.

Extension Method

Extends open chain selections to the extent of the stock bounding box to determine a closed contour, which is used to calculate a toolpath for open pockets.

When the extended open chains intersect before reaching the bounding box, a closed contour is not created and consequently toolpath calculation cannot be completed.

Depending on the geometry of the open pocket, choose between three types of extension methods:

Tangent - Extends all chain selections tangentially.
Closest boundary - Extends all chain selections in the direction closest to the bounding box.
Parallel - Extends the intersecting chain selections in a way that they are parallel when they reach the bounding box. The remaining chains are extended tangentially.

Tangent

Closest boundary

Parallel

Note: The Extension Method applies to selections for open pockets only and does not affect closed pockets.

WCS Offset

Specifies the number of the coordinate system on the machine controller. Fusion 360 passes this information to the post processor.

Note: The WCS Offset value starts at 0, which is the first work offset on the machine controller. For example, on a Fanuc-based machine, the post processor interprets 0 as using G54.

Format

The format of the G-code.

WCS

The G-code of the coordinate system that drives the operations in this setup.

Type

Generates a toolpath that resembles either the Pocket or Parallel strategy.

Pocket - Useful for machining complex geometry, such as multiple circular regions. Passes are offset from one another. Options are available to optimize the toolpath over open pockets and generate a spiral-style toolpath for continuous machining.

Parallel - Useful for machining simpler geometry, such as long rectangular regions. Passes are arranged in straight lines and do not have corners. Corners in the toolpath often slow down the machine and may cause marks on the surface.

Pocket

Parallel

Automatic Directoin

Automatically determines the most suitable direction for passes by taking into account the underlying flat region. Generally, this reduces the overall number of passes required.

A reduction in the number of passes means fewer entry or exit. The benefit of reducing the entry or exit moves is that you are more likely to keep to the estimated machining time.

Automatic Direction

Manual Pass Direction

Specifies the direction for all passes.

A manual pass direction of 0 degrees runs parallel to the x-axis of the WCS. A pass direction of 90 degrees runs parallel to the y-axis of WCS.

An example of when you might use a manual pass direction instead of an automatic direction is when the automatic direction results in passes that run up to a wall, causing the tool to touch the wall multiple times and leaving undesired marks.

Automatic Direction
Tool touches wall multiple times

Manual Pass Direction = 90 deg

Optimize Open Pockets

Gives the tool more freedom to approach a part from the open sides of a pocket. This results in more efficient entry moves such as a short tangential extension instead of a ramp move, and better cutting conditions, such as:

  • Reducing cuts that take place with the full-width of the tool.
  • Reducing sharp corners in the toolpath.

When deselected, the tool is restricted from entering from the outside of a part, which is useful when you want to avoid any clamps or fixtures that are in the way. There are also less tool-lifts, which makes it faster for machining softer materials like foam, where the cutting conditions are not as critical.

Deselected

Selected

Continuous

Generates a spiral-style toolpath that has minimal link moves between passes, resulting in a better surface finish.

Deselected

Selected

Stepover

Specifies the horizontal distance between passes.

Stepover distance

Smoothing Deviation

A percentage of the stepover between 0% and 25% by which the toolpath can deviate from its specified stepover to reduce sharp corners in the toolpath.

The smoothing applies to inner cuts and does not affect the final profile cut.

Smoothing Deviation = 0%

Smoothing Deviation = 25%

Profile Cut Direction

Specifies if material is removed using climb milling, conventional milling, or alternating between both.

Climb Milling

Conventional Milling

Climb vs. Conventional Milling

Climb milling can be thought of as the cutter rolling along the surface that it is cutting. This generally gives a better finish in most metals, but requires good machine rigidity. Using this method, chips start at maximum thickness and get thinner towards the end of the cut, meaning more heat in the chip and less in the part.

With conventional milling, the cutter is rotating away from the surface it is cutting. This method is more commonly used with manual or less rigid machines. It does have some advantages, and can even give a better finish when machining certain materials including some woods.

Cut Interior Both Ways

Reduces machining time by alternating between climb and conventional milling on inner cuts (illustrated by the yellow arrows).

The final cut is specified by the Profile Cut Direction (illustrated by the orange arrow).

When deselected, the Profile Cut Direction determines the direction of all cuts.

Deselected

Selected

Multiple Depths

Generates passes at multiple depths.

If the depth of the stock is quite large in relation to the tool, you can cut the material at multiple depths to remove a fixed, smaller amount of stock each time to avoid overloading the tool.

Deselected

Selected

Total Depth

The total depth of stock to be machined.

Maximum Stepdown

The maximum distance between consecutive Z-level of passes.

Use the Finishing Stepdown for a final cut that is a shallower cut. As the cut is shallow, there is less tool deflection, which gives a better surface finish.

Final Stepdown

The distance between the two final passes.

This distance is typically smaller than the specified stepdown for the toolpath to achieve a finishing cut.

Finishing Pass

Adds a pass just before the final stepover.

The final stepover is where the tool engages the floor but also nearby side walls. Having an additional pass helps give a finer cut and a better surface finish.

Deselected

Selected

Filter Flats Smaller Than

Avoids machining flat areas that are smaller than the specified value.

The specified value is used by the strategy as the diameter of a circle that is used to evaluate the flat faces. If the circle does not fit anywhere on a flat face, the face gets filtered out.

It is useful to filter out flat areas that are long and thin, such as chamfers, when the tool you are using is unsuitable to machine chamfers.

1 mm chamfers

Filter value of 0.5 mm
Chamfers are machined

Filter value of 1.5 mm
Chamfers are avoided

Note: The filter option is available only when Machined Inclined Flats is selected in the Multi-axis tab.

Finishing Stepover

The distance between the two final passes, which is typically smaller than the stepover value.

Ignore Holes

Generates a toolpath over holes without needing to patch the hole surfaces.

This avoids having unnecessary gaps in the toolpath and generates a toolpath that has less changes in direction, resulting in a better surface finish.

Deselected

Selected

Max Hole Size

Machines over holes that are smaller than the specified hole diameter.

In the example below, the hole on the top has a 30 mm diameter and the hole on the bottom has a 50 mm diameter.

Entering a Max Hole Size value of 40 mm means a toolpath is generated over the top hole and nothing is generated over the bottom hole.

Top hole = 30 mm
Bottom hole = 50 mm

Rest Machining

Determines the remaining stock to machine.

Area to machine.
Pocket shown in green.

Previous Operation.
Not all stock is removed.

Rest finishing operation
Previously uncut areas are machined.

Source

Specifies how to find the stock that is remaining:

From previous operations takes into account the stock removed by previous operations and machines what is remaining. Recommended to use when previous operations have used a variety of tools. Any edits to previous operations after this toolpath is generated would invalidate this toolpath.

From previous tool finds all material that was unreachable by a previous tool. Recommended to use when previous operations have used similar tools.

Tip: On the Manufacture workspace toolbar, click Inspect > Minimum Radius Analysis to see what areas are accessible by different-sized tools.

Previous tool

Opens the tool library to specify which previous tool to consider as the source.

Enlarge Tool by

Offsets the profile of the Reference Tool by the specified amount. This gives a larger reference tool, which detects more remaining stock.

When the reference tool's cutting geometry is the same size as a corner, the reference tool reaches all of the corner in some regions, and in other regions, it may not reach the entirety of the corner. This can result in fragmanted areas of toolpath throughout the corner. To avoid this, you can increase the size of the reference tool, which results in detecting more material and generating a more desirable toolpath.

Reference tool
Same size as corner

Reference tool
Enlarged by 1 mm

Detection Limit

Ignores regions of rest material that are smaller in depth than the specified value. The benefit of cutting these regions is very small when compared with the extra machining time.

Note: The specified value must be larger than the Tolerance value of the toolpath.

Extend Areas By

Extends detected rest material areas so that they overlap with surrounding areas that were machined by a different tool.

Machining the overlapping areas blends the areas together, which improves the surface finish.

Threshold Angle

The angle measured from the horizontal plane that sets the division between steep and shallow areas of the model.

Steep areas with slopes larger than the angle use steep passes and shallow areas with slopes smaller than the angle use shallow passes.

Priority

Prioritizes which area of the part to machine first.

Top first - Machines the top of the part first before moving to the bottom.

Steep first - Machines steep areas first before moving to flatter areas.

Steep Passes

Controls the cuts for steep areas.

Shallow Passes

Controls the cuts for shallow areas.

Type

Specifies the type of passes to use for steep areas.

Along - Passes run along the direction of the rest material. For example, if you are machining an internal corner, the passes will run along the internal corner.

  • With maximum stepover - The stepover adjusts itself to always remain within the rest material area, so that the surface finish of the surrounding area is not affected. The maximum stepover occurs at the widest part of the rest material. If the rest material narrows down, the stepovers move closer together, leaving less material to cut on each stepover and potentially causing the tool to rub on the part.
  • With constant stepover - A constant stepover is maintained throughout the rest material area so that you get a constant chip thickness, meaning better cutting conditions. If the rest material narrows down, the outermost passes may encroach the surrounding area that is already machined, potentially causing marks to the surface finish.

Across - Passes run across the direction of the rest material. For example, if you are machining an internal corner, the passes will run across the internal corner.

Type

Specifies the type of passes to use for shallow areas.

Along - Passes run along the direction of the rest material. For example, if you are machining an internal corner, the passes will run along the internal corner.

  • With maximum stepover - The stepover adjusts itself to always remain within the rest material area, so that the surface finish of the surrounding area is not affected. The maximum stepover occurs at the widest part of the rest material. If the rest material narrows down, the stepovers move closer together, leaving less material to cut on each stepover and potentially causing the tool to rub on the part.
  • With constant stepover - A constant stepover is maintained throughout the rest material area so that you get a constant chip thickness, meaning better cutting conditions. If the rest material narrows down, the outermost passes may encroach the surrounding area that is already machined, potentially causing marks to the surface finish.

Across - Passes run across the direction of the rest material. For example, if you are machining an internal corner, the passes will run across the internal corner.

Cut Direction

Specifies if material is removed using climb milling or conventional milling or a combination of both.

Climb milling

Conventional milling
  • Climb milling pulls the tool into the part.
  • Conventional milling pushes the tool away from the part.
  • Both Ways alternates cut direction.

Cut Direction

Specifies if material is removed using climb milling or conventional milling or a combination of both.

Climb milling

Conventional milling
  • Climb milling pulls the tool into the part.
  • Conventional milling pushes the tool away from the part.
  • Both Ways alternates cut direction.

Stepover

Specifies the spacing between cuts.

Stepover

Specifies the spacing between cuts.

Stepover

Specifies the spacing between cuts.

Stepover

Specifies the spacing between cuts.

Up/Down Milling

Use this option to break each pass into segments so that each piece is machined using either downward or upward moves only. This is useful when using insert cutters that are restricted to a specific cutting direction.

Up/Down Milling

Use this option to break each pass into segments so that each piece is machined using either downward or upward moves only. This is useful when using insert cutters that are restricted to a specific cutting direction.

Contour Mode

Determines whether pockets are selected manually using Selected pockets, or automatically, based on their geometry, using Pocket recognition.

Selected pockets - Use this option when you are machining a part with low complexity that has only a few pockets.

Pocket recognition - Use this option when you are machining a complex part that has numerous pockets, which also vary in size. Pocket recognition can save you time by automatically selecting pockets based on their geometry. Specify the geometry limits based on your tool's geometry.

Note: During pocket recognition, only closed pockets are considered. The closed pockets are selected by their edges, and not their faces.

Minimum Corner Radius

Specifies the minimum radius that the internal corners of a pocket need to have for the pocket to be included in the selection.

The minimum corner radius value should match, or be greater than, the radius of the tool that you are machining with, so that the tool can fit into the corner.

Note: All the internal corners of a pocket need to be within the minimum and maximum corner radius values for the pocket to be included in the selection.

Maximum Corner Radius

Specifies the maximum radius that the internal corners of a pocket can have for the pocket to be included in the selection.

Note: All the internal corners of a pocket need to be within the minimum and maximum corner radius values for the pocket to be included in the selection.

Minimum Pocket Depth

Specifies the minimum depth that a pocket needs to have for the pocket to be included in the selection.

The pocket depth is relative for each pocket and is measured as the distance between the top and the bottom of the pocket.

Maximum Pocket Depth

Specifies the maximum depth that a pocket can have for the pocket to be included in the selection.

The pocket depth is relative for each pocket and is measured as the distance between the top and the bottom of the pocket.

Include Holes

Includes holes and circular pockets in the selection.

The minimum and maximum corner radius and pocket depth limits also apply to holes and circular pockets. The corner radius refers to the radius of the holes and circular pockets.

Deselected

Selected

Minimum Hole Diameter

Specifies the minimum diameter that holes and circular pockets need to have for them to be included in the selection.

The Minimum corner radius excludes holes and circular pockets that are not reachable by the tool, after which the Minimum hole diameter limit can be used to determine which holes or circular pockets you want to include in the selection.

In the example below, the hole in the top-left corner of the part is not included because its radius is smaller than the minimum corner radius limit.

Min hole diameter = 0 in

Min hole diameter = 1 in

Base Selection

Determines the selection for the base surface on which to deposit the features.

Base Type

Specifies the form of the base surface on which to deposit the features.

  • Plane: A flat surface in the XY plane.
  • Cylinder: A cylindrical surface.
  • Surface of Revolution: A surface generated by revolving a curve around the X axis.
  • Arbitrary: A free-form surface.

Note: If the base surface is based on a cylinder, or a surface of revolution, the X axis must align with the axis of revolution.

Base

Defines the base surface.

In the canvas, click one or more faces.

Plane

Cylinder

Surface of Revolution

Arbitrary

Feature Selection

Determines the selection for the features.

Feature

Defines the features that you want to deposit.

In the canvas, click bodies or the faces of bodies.

Plane

Cylinder

Surface of Revolution

Arbitrary

Passes

Options for generating toolpath passes.

Infill

Adds infill passes inside the feature.

The additive toolpath slices the features in layers. Each layer is made up of perimeter passes, infill passes, or both.

Infill passes only

Perimeter passes only

Infill and perimeter passes

Stepover Allowance

Specifies the percentage deviation from the horizontal stepover.

The stepover gets adjusted to allow a more even deposition across the base surface. For example, if the stepover is 10 mm and the stepover allowance is 10%, the stepover can vary between 9 mm and 11 mm.

0%

10%

Direction

Controls whether depositing during infill passes happens in one direction only or in both directions.

One Way

Two Ways

Start Corner

Specifies the start position of infill passes in relation to the WCS.

Upper Left

Upper Right

Lower Left

Lower Right

Angle

Specifies the angle of infill passes on the first layer. The angle is measured counterclockwise from the X axis around the Z axis.

0 Degrees

45 Degrees

90 Degrees

Angular Pattern

Controls how infill passes are repeated as the layers progress upwards.

Rotate at 45 degrees

Alternate at 45 degrees

Rotation Angle

Specifies the increase in angle for each successive layer of infill passes. The angle is measured counterclockwise from the X axis around the Z axis.

25 degrees

45 degrees

Alternate Angle

Specifies the angle for every other layer of infill passes. The angle is measured counterclockwise from the X axis around the Z axis.

45 degrees

90 degrees

Start Position

Controls the direction of travel for infill passes along the X axis.

Example of infill passes traveling along a cylinder-type base surface from a start position of minimum X (left) and from a start position of maximum X (right):

Minimum X

Maximum X

Rotary Direction

Controls the direction of travel for infill passes, as perceived by looking down the X axis.

Example of infill passes traveling across a cylinder-type base surface in a clockwise (left) and counterclockwise (right) direction:

Clockwise

Counterclockwise

Style

Controls whether infill passes are along or across the X axis.

Along

Across

Perimeter

Adds perimeter passes around the feature.

The additive toolpath slices the feature in layers. Each layer is made up of perimeter passes, infill passes, or both.

Infill passes only

Perimeter passes only

Infill and perimeter passes

Order

Controls whether the perimeter passes are added before or after the infill passes.

Gap Width

Specifies the space between the perimeter passes and the infill passes.

Extent

Controls how any added thickness is applied to the edge of the feature.

  • Number of Passes: Lets you specify a number of extra passes offset outwards and inwards of the perimeter passes.
  • Distance: Lets you specify a distance outward and inward of the perimeter passes and automatically add as many extra passes as possible based on the stepover.

Offset outwards

Offset inwards

Offset outwards and inwards

Outward Offsets

Specifies the number of extra passes offset outwards from the perimeter passes. A positive, non-zero value adds thickness outside the wall of the feature.

One extra pass offset outward

Inward Offsets

Specifies the number of extra passes offset inwards from the perimeter passes. A positive, non-zero value adds thickness inside the wall of the feature.

One extra pass offset inward

Minimum Outward Distance

Specifies the distance offset outwards from the perimeter passes. Within this offset, extra passes are automatically added based on the stepover.

Minimum Inward Distance

Specifies the distance offset inwards from the perimeter passes. Within this offset, extra passes are automatically added based on the stepover.

Direction

Controls the order of depositing when there are extra perimeter passes offset outwards or inwards.

Rotation within Layer

Specifies the increase in angle of the start position for perimeter passes on the same layer. The angle is measured counterclockwise from the X axis around the Z axis.

Varying the start positions prevents a visible seam from forming on the deposited bead.

Example of 0 degrees causing a seam

Rotation between Layers

Specifies the increase in angle of the start position for perimeter passes on successive layers. The angle is measured counterclockwise from the X axis around the Z axis.

Varying the start positions prevents a visible seam from forming on the deposited bead.

Example of 0 degrees causing a seam

Layering

Determines options for setting the distance between the base surface and the first layer of passes and the distance between each successive layer of passes.

The additive toolpath slices the feature at intervals, called layers, which are offset from the base surface. A bead of melted material is deposited on top of successive layers to construct the feature.

Offset from Base

Specifies the distance between the base surface and the first layer of passes.

Layer Thickness

Specifies the distance between each successive layer of passes.

Tool Axis

Adds extra tool-axis controls, such as how far the tool can tilt forwards, or backwards, and sideways.

Tool-axis controls help to keep the head of the deposition tool at a certain angle during deposition.

Forward Tilt

Specifies the number of degrees that the tool should tilt forwards (positive) or backwards (negative) with reference to the direction of travel.

Sideways Tilt

Specifies the number of degrees that the tool should tilt sideways with reference to the direction of travel.

Mode

Controls the tool axis for perimeter passes.

  • Base Surface Normal: Keeps the tool axis normal to the base surface.
  • Towards Previous Layer: Aligns the tool axis tangent to the surface slope.

Feature Type

Specifies the type of feature that is automatically selected.

Holes only - Only selects holes that are within the specified diameter ranges. Bosses are ignored.
Bosses only - Only selects bosses that are within the specified diameter ranges. Holes are ignored.
Both - Selects holes and bosses that are within the specified diameter ranges.

Holes only

Bosses only

Both

Stand-Off Distance

Specifies the distance between the deposition head and the toolpath.

Shield Gas Flow Rate

Specifies the flow rate of the inert gas that protects the deposited material from atmospheric contamination.

Current

Specifies the electric current used during the deposition process.

Voltage

Specifies the voltage used during the deposition process.

Wire Feedrate

Specifies the speed of the wire that feeds into the melt pool.

Use Preset Program Number

Overrides the specified process inputs with a preset selected on the machine controller.

Preset Program Number

Specifies the number used to select the corresponding preset on the machine controller.

Carrier Gas Flow Rate

Specifies the flow rate of the gas that carries the powder.

Powder Flow Rate

Specifies the unitless flow rate of the powder that feeds into the melt pool. The unit of measurement comes from the machine.

Auxiliary Gas Flow Rate

Specifies the flow rate of the additional gas. This flow rate is optional because not all machines have an auxiliary gas.

In some machines, this is the flow rate of the gas that protects the optics of the laser.

Power

Specifies the power of the laser.

Reorder to Minimize Tool Changes

Reorders operations across multiple setups to minimize the number of tool changes. The actual order of operations in each individual setup remains the same.

Fixed Tilt for Cone Machining

Uses a conical machining plane instead of a circular one.

Deselected
Circular plane

Selected
Conical plane

As a result, you can machine conical surfaces by tilting the tool such that it is normal to the conical surface.

This reduces the number of stepdowns required when roughing, and does not leave behind excess stock when finishing conical surfaces.

Deselected
Excess stock

Selected
Surface fully machined

Cone Angle

Tilts the tool by a specified Cone Angle, which is measured between the conical surface and the rotary axis.

The angle can be either positive or negative, depending on the cone shape and the direction of the rotary axis.

Positive Cone Angle

Maximum Stepdown

Specifies the distance between consecutive passes that are evenly spaced.

Note: When Automatic Stepdown is selected, the stepdowns vary in height, for which this value becomes a maximum limit.

Maximum Stepdown

Specifies the distance between consecutive passes that are evenly spaced.

Note: When Automatic Stepdown is selected, you get varying stepdowns, for which this value becomes a maximum limit.

Minimum Final Cutting Radius

Defines the radius of the toolpath in inner corners for the final stepdown.

This final value is typically smaller than the minimum cutting radius, which means the tool is forced deeper into sharp corners to remove more material than previous passes. This reduces the amount of material that future operations need to remove.

Set to Zero
The toolpath is forced into
all inside sharp corners

Set to 0.07 in
The toolpath will have a blend
of .070 radius in all sharp corners.

Stepdown on Floors

Adds an extra stepdown on cylindrical faces to help remove as much as material as possible when roughing. Where a stepdown already coincides with a cylindrical face, no additional stepdown is added.

The image below illustrates additional passes that coincide with the cylindrical floors. Note that the image does not show the actual toolpath.

Deselected

Selected
Extra stepdowns on floors

Note: If Fixed Tilt for Conical Machining is selected, then stepdowns are added to coincide with conical faces.

Stepdown on Floors

Adds an extra stepdown on cylindrical faces to help remove as much as material as possible when roughing. Where a stepdown already coincides with a cylindrical face, no additional stepdown is added.

The image below illustrates additional passes that coincide with the cylindrical floors. Note that the image does not show the actual toolpath.

Deselected

Selected
Extra stepdowns on floors

Note: If Fixed Tilt for Conical Machining is selected, then stepdowns are added to coincide with conical faces.

Cutting Moves Approach

The Front and Back limits, specified in the Geometry tab, often define the extents of the stock material.

1 - Back limit
2 - Front limit

In some cases, it is important to extend cutting moves beyond the Front limit. For example, when machining a model model that has an inclined surface at the front. The center of the cutting tool would need to be outside of the front limit to cut the end of the model with the edge of the tool.

Beyond Front Limit
Deselected
Edge not fully machined

Beyond Front Limit
Selected
Edge machined

Extending the cutting moves beyond the front limit also increases toolpath safety as it allows the tool to plunge further away from the stock and then safely move into the stock.

Beyond Front Limit

Allows the cutting moves to extend beyond the Front Limit by the tool radius.

Image shown with Beyond Front Limit selected, from the Lead and Link Moves group, in the Linking tab.

Deselected

Selected

An example of when you may want to extend the cutting moves slightly beyond the front limit is when you have a large tool with a small stepover. This ensures the first cut of the tool has the right amount of material engagement. If the cutting moves do not go beyond the front limit, the first cut of the tool engages with a large amount of material, which can cause tool damage.

Large tool engagement

Safer tool engagement

Beyond Back Limit

Allows the cutting moves to extend beyond the Back limit by the tool radius.

In most cases, there could be remaining stock or fixtures that are beyond the Back limit, which means you may want to restrict the tool from going beyond the Back limit for safety reasons.

Note: The Back limit is specified in the Geometry tab.

Lead and Link Moves Approach

Controls whether leads and link moves can be placed further beyond the Front or Back limits. The limits are specified in the Geometry tab.

1 - Back limit
2 - Front limit

Beyond Front Limit

Allows lead and link moves to occur beyond the Front limit in the stock region.

This increases toolpath safety as it allows the tool to plunge further away from the part and then move into the stock.

Deselected

Selected

Warning: With this option, lead and link moves are restricted from occurring in the stock region. Lead and link moves may still occur outside of the stock region.

Note: If Beyond Front Limit is selected from the Cutting Moves Approach group in the Passes tab, the leads and links extend slightly beyond the Front limit to accommodate for the cutting moves even if Beyond Front Limit is deselected.

Beyond Back Limit

Allows lead and link moves to occur beyond the Back limit in the stock region.

Deselected

Selected

In most cases, there could be remaining stock that is beyond the Back limit. You may want to restrict lead and link moves from occurring in this stock region for safety reasons.

Warning: With this option, lead and link moves are restricted from occurring in the stock region. Lead and link moves may still occur outside of the stock region.

Transition type

Specifies the type of connection move between passes that are nearby each other on the same radial plane.

  • No contact - Uses a retract move to connect the passes. The retraction distance may depend on the Retraction Policy.
  • Straight line - Uses a straight line to connect the passes.
  • Smooth - Uses smooth tangential movements to connect the passes.

No contact
Retraction Policy = Full

No contact
Retraction Policy = Min

Straight line

Smooth

Transition type

Specifies the type of connection move between passes that are nearby each other on the same radial plane.

  • No contact - Uses a retract move to connect the passes. The retraction distance may depend on the Retraction Policy.
  • Straight line - Uses a straight line to connect the passes.
  • Smooth - Uses smooth tangential movements to connect the passes.

No contact
Retraction Policy = Full

No contact
Retraction Policy = Min

Straight line

Smooth

Order by Depth

Performs all the possible cutting moves at one depth before stepping down to machine at the next depth.

Useful in the case where you have two pockets divided by a small rib. If you machine an entire pocket and then proceed to machine the next pocket, there is no support for the rib and it may deflect as the tool machines close by.

Deselected

Machining both pockets at the same time at set depths means the rib is supported by material on either side and is less likely to deflect.

Selected

Note: Generally, ordering by depth increases the total machining time.

Order by Depth

Performs all the possible cutting moves at one depth before stepping down to machine at the next depth.

Useful in the case where you have two pockets divided by a small rib. If you machine an entire pocket and then proceed to machine the next pocket, there is no support for the rib and it may deflect as the tool machines closeby to it.

Deselected

Machining both pockets at the same time at set depths means that the rib is supported by material on either side and is less likely to deflect.

Selected

Note: Generally, ordering by depth increases the total machining time.

Style

Specifies the style of the machining passes.

Offset - Offsets the surrounding geometry. Useful for machining parts with multiple complex features.

Offset

Offset and Spiral - Uses the Offset style when the area is surrounded by geometry features and uses the Spiral style over areas that are purely cylindrical. This provides smoother motion on the rotary axis, which helps maintain the programmed feedrate.

Offset and Spiral

Tool Offset

Offsets the tool centerline to help cut with the edges of the tool rather than its center.

Tool Offset

Tool Diameter = 0.3 in
Tool Offset = 0 in

Tool Diameter = 0.3 in
Tool Offset = 0.14 in

The tool offset is applied in the opposite direction to the rotation direction of the rotary axis. When the rotation direction changes, to help prevent any damage, the tool automatically changes position by performing a linear movement without rotary movement.

Automatic stepdown

Adjusts the stepdowns to coincide with cylindrical surfaces so that material is removed efficiently.

The stepdowns remain within the Maximum Stepdown value.

Deselected
Even Stepdowns

Selected
Adjusted Stepdowns

Exclude Small Areas

Avoids machining small areas to prevent damaging the tool or the part.

Useful for avoiding small pockets for example, particularly in cases where the tool is non-center cutting, which prevents you from plunging into the pocket, while there is also insufficient space to ramp into the pocket. This allows you to use a smaller tool in a future operation to machine the small area safely.

Exclude Small Areas

Excludes areas from the toolpath calculation that are smaller than the specified value, which is a percentage of the tool diameter.

Threshold of 80%
Both pockets machined

Threshold of 85%
Only one pocket machined

Tip: To avoid areas that are slightly larger, you can use higher threshold values, such as 150%.

Machine Over Gaps

Generates a toolpath over small gaps.

Useful for reducing machining time by generating a continuous toolpath, preventing unnecessary linking moves that would otherwise occur over the gaps.

Gaps in stock

Gaps in toolpath
Longer machining time

No gaps in toolpath
Shorter machining time

Max Gap Size

Machines over gaps that are smaller than the specified size.

Retraction Policy

Controls the connection moves between cutting moves when:

  • Moving from one pocket to another
  • Moving from one radial cut to another through a stepdown.

Images shown with a Rapid Distance of 20 mm, an Entry Distance and Exit Distance of 10 mm, and a Safe Distance of 9 mm. Generally, if the safe distance is at a greater height than the entry or exit distance, the tool always performs a full retraction move for better safety.

Moving from one pocket to another:

Full Retraction

Minimum Retraction

Moving from one radial cut to another through a stepdown:

Full Retraction

Minimum Retraction

Note: With each stepdown, the retraction move is at a slightly lower height than the previous retraction move. This is because the retraction move is a specific distance instead of a set height to always retract to.

Retraction Policy

Controls the connection moves when moving from one pocket to another.

Images shown with a Rapid Distance of 40 mm, an Entry Distance and Exit Distance of 20 mm, and a Safe Distance of 10 mm. Generally, if the safe distance is at a greater height than the entry or exit distance, the tool always performs a full retraction move for better safety.

Full Retraction

Minimum Retraction

Note: Unlike the Rotary Pocket strategy, the Rotary Contour strategy does not perform retraction moves between stepdowns. Instead, it performs smooth transition moves:

Rapid Distance

Specifies the total distance the tool uses to approach the surface it is machining.

The portion of the move that is yellow is performed at the rapid feedrate. The portion of the move that is red, defined by the Entry Distance, is performed at the cutting feedrate.

Note: If the Exit Distance or Safe Distance is larger than the Rapid Distance, then the value that is the largest is used by the strategy to specify the Rapid Distance.

Entry Distance

Specifies the distance at which the tool begins to approach the part using the cutting feedrate.

This applies to lead moves and ramping moves. The example below shows the effect of increasing the Entry Distance when using a helical ramp.

Small Entry Distance

Large Entry Distance

Note: If you use a Rapid Distance value of 10 mm for example, and an Entry Distance distance of 3 mm, then 7 mm of the entry move is performed at the rapid feedrate, and the remaining 3 mm at the cutting feedrate.

Exit Distance

Specifies the distance the tool uses to leave the part at the cutting feedrate.

Note: If the Rapid Distance or Safe Distance is larger than the Exit Distance, then the value that is the largest is used by the strategy to specify the Exit Distance.

Entry Distance

Specifies the minimum distance the tool should maintain between itself and the part when performing link moves.

Safe Distance

Increased Safe Distance

Add geometry

Lets you select geometry from the canvas based on selection filters for quicker selections. The available selection filters may vary for each strategy.

Tip: You can reuse geometry selections from other operations. To reuse the selections, with the Select button active, in the Browser, expand an operation's node then click the geometry selection.

Remove geometry

Removes the currently selected item from the list.

Tip: To navigate between items, press the Up or Down keyboard shortcuts. To delete the selected item, press Del.

Warning

The geometry selection has missing references. Missing references are shown in the Canvas as dashed red lines.

Settings

Click to edit the geometry selection options.

Linked

This geometry is linked to another operation.

If you want to edit the selection, from the Canvas, click the selection.

Warning

Missing selections.

Tool select

Opens the Tool Library dialog where you can select an existing tool or create a new one.

Tools suitable for this operation include:

  • Ball nose
  • Lollipop
  • Flat end
  • Chamfer
  • Tapered
  • Spot drills

Lollipop tool

Ball nose tool

Chamfer tool

Flat end tool
Multi-axis machining

Edges to Deburr

Specifies how to select the edges to deburr.

Automatic - The strategy automatically finds sharp edges on the part. This is the quickest selection method. To include rounded edges in the selection, select the Include Rounded Edges checkbox.

Selection - Lets you manually select the edges to deburr.

Minimum Edge Angle

Ignores edges that have an angle that is smaller than the specified value.

You can adjust this value to ensure that only edges that you want to deburr are selected.

The angle is measured between a straight line and an edge:

Minimum edge angle
45 degrees

Min Edge Angle = 40 deg
Edge machined

Min Edge Angle = 50 deg
Edge ignored

Include Rounded Edges

Includes edges that need deburring despite being modeled as small fillets.

The size of the fillets that this option detects is affected by the Edge Width, Edge Height or Edge Radius values from the Passes tab.

Rounded edge

Deselected
Avoids rounded edge

Selected
Machines rounded edge

Note: Including rounded edges may significantly increase calculation time.

Edges to Exclude

Select the edges that should not be machined.

Selection

Select the edges to deburr.

Clearance Type

Specifies the type of clearance area to use.

The clearance area is determined to be a safe location where the tool goes to after performing a cutting move to position itself for the next cutting move.

The Automatic option lets the strategy select the best clearance option based on the geometry of the model.

Plane

Cylinder

Sphere

Deburr Edges by

Specifies how to deburr the edges:

  • Chamfering - Adds a small chamfer between two edges.
  • Filleting - Adds a small fillet between two edges. Requires the Multiple Passes checkbox to be selected.

Chamfering

Filleting

Note: For larger chamfers and for all fillets, it is recommended to use Multiple Passes.

Edge Shape

Controls how much material is removed from an edge.

Chamfering:

  • Constant Width - The distance between the two edges of the chamfer remains the same for each edge.
  • Constant Height - The depth of the chamfer remains the same for each edge.

Filleting:

  • Constant Width - The distance between the two ends of the fillet remains the same for each edge.
  • Constant Radius - The radius of the fillet remains the same for each edge.

Chamfering
Constant width

Chamfering
Constant height

Filleting
Constant width

Filleting
Constant radius

Edge Width

Specifies the width of the small fillet or chamfer.

The width remains the same for each edge, although the depth of the cut may change depending on the geometry.

Chamfering
Constant width

Filleting
Constant width

Edge Height

Specifies the depth of the chamfer.

The depth remains the same for each edge, although the width of the chamfer may change depending on the geometry.

Chamfering
Constant height

Edge Radius

Specifies the radius of the fillet.

The radius remains the same for each edge, although the width of the fillet may change depending on the geometry.

Filleting
Constant radius

Unreachable Corners

Specifies what to do when the tool encounters inner corners that it cannot reach because of the geometry of the tool.

Do not deburr - Moves the tool to the next edge of the inner corner after it can no longer machine any more of the current edge. As a result, burrs remain on some inner corners. Use this option to prioritise a faster cycle time over deburring more of the internal corners.

Unreachable corner

Burrs on inner corners

Cut with tip of tool - Attempts to cut more of the inner corner by using more of the tip of the tool. This removes as much material as possible from inner corners.

Cutting with tip of tool

Inner corners deburred

Note: To use the Cut at Fixed Point on Tool feature, you need to select Do not deburr.

Add Loops for Smooth Motion

Adds a loop to the sharp-edge of the toolpath where it has attempted to cut inner corners.

This results in smoother motion when transitioning between edges.

Deselected

Selected

When viewed from the side view, you can see the loop is slightly raised from the surface of the part to avoid touching the surface.

Loop Radius

Specifies the radius of the loop. Generally, a larger radius, where possible, provides smoother motion.

Loop Radius

In some cases, the specified loop radius may not be achievable because of geometry constraints. In these cases, the loop radius may get reduced:

Resized loop

Machining Type

Specifies the number of machine axes to use when deburring.

Generally, using multi-axis machining allows you to reach more areas in one operation. For 4- and 5-axis machining, you require a machine tool that is capable of multi-axis machining.

  • 3-axis machining - Useful for deburring parts that are prismatic, which has edges that are easily reachable by the tool.
  • 4-axis machining - Useful for deburring cylindrical parts.
  • 5-axis machining - Useful for deburring complex parts that require the tool to tilt to reach more areas.

3-axis machining

4-axis machining

5-axis machining

Note: Collision checking is performed using shaft and holder clearances from the Tool tab.

Cut at Fixed Point on Tool

Uses a fixed point along the tool's flute for cutting.

Useful for using a point on the tool that has experienced the least wear for optimal cutting conditions.

For tools such as conical tools, using a point closer to the holder of the tool provides a larger effective cutting diameter. Using a point further up in the tool may provide better cutting conditions, however it will also make the tool stick out a lot more, making some areas unreachable.

Note: You have to cut at a fixed point when using certain tools such as flat end mills.

Point along Flute

Specifies the point along the flute to use as the cutting point.

The larger the percentage, the further up towards the holder, of the flute that gets used.

5%

45%

Note: You can specify values between 5% and 95%.

Primary Mode

Specifies the primary mode of the tool axis. Depending on the model's geometry, select the option that allows you to reach the most areas with the tool.

Primary Mode for 4-axis machining:

  • To rotary axis - The tip of the tool always points to the rotary axis.
  • To rotary axis with tilt - Firstly, the tip of the tool points to the rotary axis. And then, the tool tilts towards the rotary axis.
  • Zero lead angle with tilt - Firstly, the tool aligns with the average angle between the two edges. And then, the tool tilts towards the rotary axis.

To rotary axis

To rotary axis with tilt

The image below illustrates the Zero lead angle only, but the with tilt setting works the same way as shown in the To rotary axis with tilt image above.

Zero lead angle

Primary Mode for 5-axis machining:

  • Lead - Tilts the tool in the direction of travel.
  • Tilt to Z - Tilts the tool to any location on a conical boundary that is around the tool orientation Z axis.

Lead

Tilt to Z

Preferred Tilt Angle

Preferred Angle for 4-axis machining:

Tilts the tool towards the rotary axis by an angle, which is measured from the tool orientation Z axis.

Preferred Angle for 5-axis machining:

Tilts the tool to the tool orientation Z axis by the specified angle. A Preferred Tilt Angle of 0 aligns the tool with the tool orientation Z axis.

This angle can be thought of as a conical boundary around the tool orientation Z axis.

Fixed Tilt while Cutting

Fixes the tilt angle while performing a cutting move, generally by locking the A or B machine axis.

Any change in tool axis is performed in the linking moves that occur between the cutting moves.

This provides smooth motion while cutting, which helps the tool cut closer to the programmed feedrate.

Deselected

Selected
Fixed tool axis

Lead Angle

Tilts the tool in the direction of the cut using a positive angle, referred to as a lead angle. You can also tilt the tool away from the direction of cut using a negative angle, referred to as a lag angle.

Useful for tilting the tool to avoid cutting with a center of a ball-nosed tool for example.

Lag
Negative angle

Lead
Positive angle

Retraction Policy

Controls how the tool moves between cutting passes.

Full Retraction - Retracts the tool to the Clearance Area before moving to the next cutting move. This is the safest retraction option, however, it results in a larger retraction move.

Smooth Retraction - Retracts the tool in a smooth motion, which is a shorter retraction. The tool uses the Full Retraction option when the smooth retraction cannot be achieved safely.

Full Retraction
Clearance Type = Plane

Smooth Retraction

Note: The Full Retraction depends on the Clearance Type, which is specified in the Heights tab.

Orientation

Specifies the orientation of the rotary axis to match how your part is set up on the machine.

Model orientation - Uses the coordinate system (WCS) of the current part as the rotary axis.

Setup X Axis - Uses the X axis of the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) of the current setup as the rotary axis.

Setup Y Axis - Uses the Y axis of the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) of the current setup as the rotary axis.

Setup Z Axis - Uses the Z axis of the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) of the current setup as the rotary axis.

Select rotary axis - Select a flat face to set the rotary axis perpendicular to, or select a circular face to set the center of the face as the point the rotary axis runs through.

Select coordinate system - Sets a specific rotary axis orientation for this operation from a defined User Coordinate System (UCS) in the model. This uses both the origin and orientation of the existing coordinate system. Use this option if your model does not contain a suitable point and plane for your operation.

Origin

The Origin drop-down menu offers the following options for locating the rotary axis:

Setup WCS origin - Uses the workpiece coordinate system (WCS) origin of the current setup for the rotary axis.

Model origin - Uses the coordinate system (WCS) origin of the current part for the rotary axis.

Selected point - lets you select a vertex or an edge for the rotary axis.

Contours Selection

Lets you select an open or closed contour.

The image bellow shows the use of an open contour (left) and a closed contour (right).

Contours Selection

Lets you select an open or closed contour.

The image bellow shows the use of an open contour (left) and a closed contour (right).

Contours Selection

Lets you select open or closed contours.

Face Contours Selection

Lets you select a face, from which all the contours that are bounding the face are automatically selected.

When you select a face, you have the option to automatically select other faces that are on the same plane.

Silhouette

Lets you select a body and use its silhouette, which is the boundary defined by the outline of the body, when viewed from the Z axis of the Work Coordinate System (WCS).

Sketch Profiles

Lets you select sketches or parts of a sketch.

Pockets

Lets you select open or closed pockets.

When you select a pocket, you have the option to automatically select other pockets that are on the same plane.

Pocket Recognition

Lets you automatically select pockets based on dimensions such as corner radii and pocket depth.

Selection

Select contours on the model.

Mode

Changes the contour selection to open or closed.

Open Chain - Lets you select individual contours.

Closed Chain - Lets you select a contour and automatically finds nearby contours to provide a closed contour selection.

Reverse

Reverses the direction of the red arrow, determining which side of the contour gets machined.

For internal pockets, the red arrow should point counter clockwise. For external features such as bosses, the contour arrow should point clockwise.

Tip: You can also click the red arrow in the canvas to flip its direction.

Extension Method

Extends open chain selections to the extent of the stock bounding box to determine a closed contour, which is used to calculate a toolpath for open pockets.

When the extended open chains intersect before reaching the bounding box, a closed contour is not created and consequently toolpath calculation cannot be completed.

Depending on the geometry of the open pocket, choose between three types of extension methods:

Tangent - Extends all chain selections tangentially.
Closest boundary - Extends all chain selections in the direction closest to the bounding box.
Parallel - Extends the intersecting chain selections in a way that they are parallel when they reach the bounding box. The remaining chains are extended tangentially.

Tangent

Closest boundary

Parallel

Note: The Extension Method applies to selections for open pockets only and does not affect closed pockets.

Curve chains

Select contours on the model.

Extension Type

Specifies how much to extend to beginning and the end of the contour.

  • To boundary - Extends the contour ends to the stock boundary as defined in the setup.
  • Distance - Lets you specify a start and end distance.

Start Extension Length

Specifies how much to extend the beginning of the contour, from where the tool enters to machine the contour.

End Extension Length

Specifies how much to extend the end of the contour, from where the tool leaves after finishing machining the contour.

Face Contours Selection

Select Faces on the model.

Loops

Used with face selection to filter Inner or Outer chains

All Loops Selected

Outer Loops Selected

Inner Loops Selected

Note: It may be advantageous to select all Inner boundaries for a single toolpath and another toolpath for Outer boundaries. This will give you more control over Lead In/Out values for each.

Side

Used to offset selected edges or sketches

Use this to offset the contour inside or outside from the original edge or sketch geometry. Allows you to shift from the selected Sideways Compensation direction or reverse the compensation offset direction.

Pocket Selections

Select pockets from the model.

Select Setup Model

Includes the silhouette from the model selected in the setup.

Bodies or Faces

Select bodies or faces from the canvas.

Sketch selection

Select full sketches or partial sketches from the canvas.

Stepover Calculation

Determines how to calculate the stepover of the toolpath.

On surface - Uses the surface of the model to calculate the stepover. This option can detect and machine undercuts.

From tip of tool - Considers the tool's cutting geomtry when calculating the stepover. This option is useful for machining areas where the tool cannot contact all the points on a surface because of the shape of its cutting geometry. For example, an area where the internal corner radius is smaller than the tool's radius.

Using this option lets you use the Spiral option for continuous machining.

Note: From tip of tool is not suitable for machining undercuts.

Insert and holder

Specifies the clearance between the model and different sections of the turning tool, such as the holder or the insert.

The clearances take effect when machining undercut areas, such as grooves with areas that are unreachable by the tool, especially if the material in the groove was not removed previously through a roughing operation.

Insufficient clearances

Sufficient clearances

Clearance From

Specifies which section of the tool to measure the clearances from:

  • Back of Holder - Sets the clearance from the back of the holder. Use this option if the holder accurately represents the tool used on the machine.
  • Back of Insert - Sets the clearance from the back of the insert. Use this option if the holder does not accurately represent the tool used on the machine.

Back of Holder

Back of Insert

Clearance

Specifies the clearance distance between a section of the tool and the model.

Example below shown with Back of Holder selected from the Clearance From drop-down menu.

2 mm

5 mm

Clearance From

Specifies which section of the tool to measure the clearances from:

  • Back of Holder - Sets the clearance from the back of the holder. Use this option if the holder accurately represents the tool used on the machine.
  • Back of Insert - Sets the clearance from the back of the insert. Use this option if the holder does not accurately represent the tool used on the machine.

Back of Holder

Back of Insert

Note: For the clearance to take effect, from the Passes tab, select the Machine Undercuts checkbox.

Clearance

Specifies the clearance distance between a section of the tool and the model.

Example below shown with Back of Holder selected from the Clearance From drop-down menu.

2 mm

5 mm

Note: For the clearance value to take effect, from the Passes tab, select the Machine Undercuts checkbox.

Machine Undercuts

Allows the tool to enter areas where it previously wouldn’t have been able to because of undercut areas.

For example, if you use a profile finishing toolpath to finish a groove, the tool does not fully enter the groove as it assumes that there is material beneath it that it cannot reach because of the geometry of the cutting tip.

Profile finishing toolpath
Machine Undercuts deselected

Unreachable stock
Because of tip geometry

If you use a tool to rough out the groove area, you can then select the Machine Undercuts checkbox to allow the tool for the profile finishing toolpath to finish more areas of the groove.

Roughing the groove

Profile finishing toolpath
Machine Undercuts selected
